Posted: May 4, 2014
												If you liked the table top game, or any table top game... then buy this game.  The graphics are...ok... the gameplay is good... but the story is fantastic.  It felt simultaneously home grown and professionally constructed. I felt like I was at a table game, participating in one of the mostl finely constructed stories I had ever played.  It starts small, with a seemingly inocuous event and ends huge.  The story is a work of art.  And speaking of works of art...  The mod tool is one as well.  Included is a single tool with which to build your own stories. It's powerful, easy (enough) to use, the tutorial videos are great, and it includes tons of assets. All in all it's really smart.  Which is going to be my final review for this game.  Shadow Run: Returns... Smart.

Posted: July 25, 2013
												Okay I started playing at 8 pm and stopped at 3 am playing it without pause. Not because i wanted to, but because I am so tired right now. This game is in one word: awesome! If you played the pen and paper rpg you will recognize that the rulesystem is quite different to it. Its more dumbed down. But this is not bad. Actually its a question of gamedesign. And works quite good. This game lacks so many things. No voice acting no thrilling graphic style (all graphics are handdrawn). But this game has one thing i have missed in so many games the last couple of months. The just another mission effect. I couldn't stop playing.The story is great. The writting is compelling (and there is a lot of text since there is no voice acting what so ever). It inherits the spirit of the first 2 Shadowrun rulesets. Version 1 and 2 maybe 3 with all its coolness and glory. If you ever liked the old Shadowrun, buy this masterpiece.

Posted: July 28, 2013
												This game is absolutely great from top to bottom. The main game is a well written and well paced piece of murder mystery cyberpunk action, made with great writing and interesting characters. The writing is so good, in fact, that even characters that show up just once or twice feel really memorable. The graphic style and musical design are top notch and really help make the experience into a cohesive whole. The gameplay is a solid tactical RPG experience that's fun to play, if a bit on the easy side more often than not. The few downsides to the game start with the lack of manual saving. The game automatically saves at checkpoints (probably to prevent save scumming like some other tactical games) which can sometimes be frustrating. The locked angle camera usually is okay, but there are times where it's a problem. Some people will call a 12 hour, very linear main campaign a problem too, but I personally think that it's better to have 12 high-quality hours than 20-25 with lots of filler. So it's not perfect, but it's damned well done. And the inclusion of an editor means that in the end we'll hopefully see a lot more great content from the community.

Posted: December 25, 2013
												I marathoned this game. It is fantastic. It reminds me of Infinity Engine games like Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's Gate, only the combat is much easier to wrap your head around. The setting is cyberpunk (William Gibson and Neal Stephenson specifically) mixxed with high fantasy. The module that is included in the game is a fun story, but don't be surprised if you call out plot points well before they happen. I've only played through it once, but my class choice (decker) seemed pretty useless in most situations. I am hoping Harebrained Scheme puts out a few more modules of their own.There is a module creator and it looks like the community has put out quite a bit of content on their own. I'm looking forward to sinking a few hours investigating that over the weekend.

Posted: August 15, 2013
												While an insanely simple and easy game the storytelling is completely awesome and absobring. The included campaign (you can get lots more from the workshop) plays exactly like a book, it's dead linear, it plays on your imagination of sounds and smells... and I'm totally into cyberpunk books. I love this game, well worth the money.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												While I like this game a lot, others may not, depending on what they're expecting.If you are expecting any edition of the tabletop role-playing game, or the Genesis or SNES console games, you will be disappointed.  Shadowrun: Returns plays something like a simplified version of tabletop rules that never actually existed.I liked the plot, combat, and music.Opinions on the plot vary widely.  If you have an aversion to reading, this game is not for you.  Almost all of the plot is delivered via screens of text upon entering an area, or text dialogs.  There is no voiceover.  Some people complain of purple prose, or that it seems to have been written by someone that is immature, but the writing is superior to that in most video games, including most other RPGs.  I personally do not perceive any of these problems, and have never seen examples cited.Screenshots do not do the combat system justice.  Some of the interface is only displayed when it is relevant.  For example, the action point cost of movement, and the effectiveness of cover, only appear when you prepare to move, and when cover exists in the area you mouseover.  The combat system is relatively simple (which is reflected in the user interface), but like Chess, can be quite difficult.  The difficulty is selectable at character creation, so if you find the game too easy or hard you can adjust it.  Since almost all RPGs are combat-heavy, it's important that it not be mindless and repetitive.The music is hard to describe.  It is not ambient.  You will notice it.  I especially like the theme on the title screen.I didn't like some things about Shadowrun: Returns.It is very linear, and most decisions will not affect the ending.The gameplay in the matrix is very similar to meatspace.  It's not so much that the gameplay in the matrix is bad as it doesn't feel different enough.The game only saves on area transition.  If you have to stop playing, or die, unexpectedly, you can lose quite a bit of progress.

Posted: November 23, 2015
												This is a fine piece of a turn-based RPG. I defnitely enjoyed this great, albeit short,  game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn-based rpgs, x-com enemy unknown/within, urban-science-fantasy settings and fantasy races. A surprisingly good mixture of sci-fi stuff with near-like contemporary settings filled with elves, orcs, trolls and dwarves.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												If you're new to Shadowrun, like me, and not sure whether it's worth buying, the questions is: do you like detective fiction? Because that's exactly what SR is. That means you have to read a lot.Another thing to consider is visual simplicity. Shadowrun Returns looks good, but don't expect much on that side. It won't show you stunning cutscenes or SFX. It'll describe all that in a text box instead. Yeah, just like in 90's.So if these things don't scare you, give it a try and maybe in half an hour or so you'll be completely immersed.

Posted: January 8, 2015
												An easy buy if you enjoy xcom style gameplay and fantasy cyberpunk.I really enjoyed this game. ~10hrs of gameplay... well maybe half story and half dialogue. Played as an Adept(melee tank) on very hard but didn't find the game difficult. Looking forward to checking out the steam workshop for some extra campaigns and eventually moving onto the sequel.Paid less than $2 for it Winter Sale 2014.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Shadowrun has always been a great universe. It is a real shame that it doesn't get as much attention as tradition D&D universe. So this game is much needed break from you're typical RPG. The storyline in the main campaign is pretty good but not super orginal or great. It  did kept my attention enough that I played it for over 8 on the first day I got it. It has some flaws though that may take away from the enjoy of the game. First it is a very linear game, you don't get much chance to roam around. Even more sad then that is you never really use some the advanced skills like Decking at all really. The second issue is it lack of a save anywhere feature. Even though I played the whole in nearly one sitting it was a difficult to play it through only  been able to set checkpoints. This limits the replay value because most of us, myself included normally cannot play a game without being dragged back into the real world at random times. Doing some parts of the game more then once because of fairly spaced out checkpoints wasn't so bad. It did however give the game a limited time to play or to replay without having a large amount to play it. The promise of new updates on the way and the steam workshop makeup for some of the flaws so I would recemmmend this for any RPG fan looking for a new take on the typical RPG.

Posted: March 14, 2016
												A pleasant surprise. I picked up Shadowrun Returns a few years ago,  just coming off an XCOM-high and jumped the instant I heard "XCOM-style combat". Found plenty to stay for. The neat, if linear, story, highly customizable playstyles, and some very unique character designs/portraits.I do have a few gripes, one of which is the inability to rotate the camera, which made combat a bit of a hassel. This is understandable, though, given the hand-drawn backgrounds. Other wise, not bad. Get it cheap, finish it in a afternoon.

Posted: October 21, 2014
												If Dragon Age and Deus Ex had a top down baby, it would be Shadowrun Returns.The concept, setting, story and music are great (though a few hours hours in you'll get annoyed with the repeated battle music), but the UI and controls are clunky, and the gameplay repetitive. Were it not for the story I would have given it up long ago.There are also some bugs, such as not being able to select a character to move during the battle. Alt + F4 and reload is the only solution I know of.Still worth a play through.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												Awesome game, and Dragonfall corrects most of the problems that the base game had. Dead Man's Switch campaign was a little flat, and lacked much in the way of 'side quests' or choices on how to make the story (and thus, your character's story) develop. Dragonfall offers the option to have a 'good' guy or a 'bad guy' type character, depending on the mission options you take and the manner in which you solve the missions.Dragonfall also fixes a few mechanical shortflls in the base game, including adding in a 'save anywhere' option. It does seem that the game lags a bit more after Dragonfall is installed, but I would imagine that there will be fixes forthcoming for this issue. Harebrained Schemes has really nailed it with Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall.Can't wait for the next installment!

Posted: March 3, 2014
												A "Must Have" Indie game; arguably the best cyberpunk videogame of the decade.    Shadowrun Returns & Dragonfall are excellent tributes to William Gibson's Sprawl.  Reminiscent of timeless classics such as Deus Ex, and Planescape: Torment.Included is a powerful game editor that we fans use to modify, edit and even create entirely separate cyberpunk stories of our own.  The Workshop is full of potential and already has an active community, many of which are avid readers and writers devoted to tell their story.Shadowrun Returns is an ambitious project funded through Kickstarter and HBS has delivered.  The atmosphere, writing, and music are extremely high artistic quality, and shows fans that HBS has "The Heart," and talent to make immersive campaigns and anthologies.Buy Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall now!

Posted: March 4, 2014
												The base campaign is astoundingly well-composed, the characters fleshed out and interacting with one another to create an immersive tale. Where this game TRULY shines, however, is the campaign creator. A fully-customizable world, you can build any story you can imagine, bringing to bear every piece of this wonderful engine.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												For years now I've considered old-school isometric genres to be 'my' genre. That is to say, the one that strictly caters to my sensibilities as a player. I discovered them well after their golden age, and since this wave of kickstarted CRPGs began I've been eagerly awaiting their results.As the first one out of the gate from this batch, Shadowrun Returns does not disappoint. If you're like me and you've been aching for a deep and immersive roleplaying experience and actual agency when it comes to solving problems, this game is a steal at $20. Excellent writing, beautiful environments, and a fantastic soundtrack all tied together with engaging combat and character progression.The campaign will take you about 15 hours to run through, and there's sadly little in the way of extended diversions, and the game is rather linear in how it progresses. There's not much of a sense of an 'open world' that one would expect from this genre, but even still the world itself is one of the most well-realized and vibrant ones I've seen in a long time.They've got another campaign on the way, and you're going to see plenty of gameplay content coming out of the steam workshop, so I can guarantee you'll have your money's worth in actual meaty game.If you like RPGs at all you owe it to yourself to grab this game and play through it. You'll be really glad you did.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												Finished Shadowrun returns last Monday.From my blog: http://www.dyle.org/blog/?p=233Played fully on Linux with Steam (native, no Windows Emulation).You play a character in the Shadowrun universe which is on the hunt to bring down a friend’s murderer. Time is around 2057 but due to the Awakening, the world is filled with science fiction high tech and fantasy elements alike. You have genetic modification, cyberplants and hacking warfare along with elves, orcs, dwarfes and trolls hurling magic bolts. A rich and fascinating universe.… you have to work trough yourself. The game can be summed up by the phrase “too less”. At first there is too less background for the setting, the story. You just start off creating a character, like an orc, with cybernetic implants. Yep, no explanation to this. If you want to find out more about the Shadowrun world you have to look elsewhere but not the game.Then there is too less RPG. Seldom you find something useful to pick up and equip. Also stats and skills are presented in a very sober way in a plain matrix. No introduction, no nothing. All at once, on page. Also you likely will spend points on attributes and skills you don’t need in future. Sorry, there is no turning back.Then there is too less adventure. The story is nice, but you got not real decisions to make. The storyline is very linear. There are some side-quests, but guess: too less.Then there is too less of a challenge. At the first two thirds of the game. I pimped my elf with quickness and assault rifles and the game was no real match at “normal” level. Strategic fighting is nice and … easy. Yeah, the games picks up some pace in the last third and starts to get harder. This is were the fun really sets in. But up to then it is playing a nice story …And someone always has the idea of something missing. Something’s missing at the RPG, at the adventure, at the combat game, at the grafics, animations.E.g. Harlequin is one of the coolest elves I’ve come along in playing games, but when he wields his sword he is animated as if someone had stiffed a broomstick right along his “back”. The in-game representation is missing the charisma and style this elf has in dialogues.Finally the save game mechanics are just bonkers. Actually you just can save at the start of a level, better: the game (hopefully) autosaves at this stage. Making a wrong decision at the end of a level requires to replay to whole level again.The pro: once you’ve delved into the universe the plot is great to play and the dialogs are really nice written, the combat is fun after all. It remains a nice game. Hopefully they fix this bad savegame mechanics and give more universe background information in the DLCs and patches to come.

Posted: June 22, 2015
Pros:+ Solid storyline+ Various builds that change how you play+ Rewarding, challenging combat+ Clever puzzles+ Bug-free+ The game ends on exactly the right noteCons:- Game is a bit short; campaign lasts roughly 20 hours if you do everything- Relatively low replay value- Straightforward campaign; for the most part, you stay on a single track through the main campaign, with only a couple chances for sidequests- Charisma/Etiquettes*- Specializing is required.  Jack of All Trades type characters don't do well.Overall: Shadowrun Returns is fun.  You get to hire a crew and go do odd jobs as a mercenary in a futuristic dystopia.  The tone and music fits, the game gives you just enough money to get by and forces you to spend wisely, and the storyline is fast paced and fun.  The game is short, and there's not many chances for optional sidequests, but in spite of that the overall experience is still great.  If you're a fan of tactical isometric roleplaying games, this is a solid choice.Bottom Line: A wild ride from start to finish, with fun characters, rewarding combat, and enjoyable gameplay.  A little short and straightforward, but well done in spite of this.  Worth the price.* The charisma system in game works by giving you various "etiquettes" which will open up conversation options if you know them.  Some etiquettes are extremely useful, others are entirely pointless.  Consult a guide when choosing which etiquettes to learn.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												A cool RPG looking back to the good old days of legendary isometric games like Fallout 1 & 2 - but Shadowrun Returns suffer from modern stupification in aspects of linearity and complexity. Another game that would go from 7/10 to 9/10 by dropping all the mobile device/console porting crap and instead focusing on making a solid complex game for players that use a keyboard and mouse input... The interface is quite clunky but does it's job kind of ok, but simple things like the lack of a proper inventory management on quests and weird vendor buy/sell dialogue makes me MAD!The main story module "Dead mans switch" is extremely linear and side quests are few. As an RPG heavily focused on combat it still has a solid story and memorable characters, all dialogue being text based makes for a huge variety in dialogue options that is sadly not always used to create a more complex story. Things like the stat based etiquette system works nicely but could really be more developed and used often. The artwork is beautiful with a hand drawn style and there are lots and lots of small details everywhere.Best thing in the game is the epic awesome soundtrack - easily one of the very best in the gaming world and on the same high level as HL2 + episodes OST. From dark ambient synthetic themes to adrenaline pumping beats with grinding guitars when in combat to blip-blop digital jazz when hacking into the Matrix it is for me the main component for immerion in this game. The track "Double Cross" is freakkin awesome!The game has a heavy focus on combat but it does IMO not match up to the tactical sandbox complexity in Fallout Tactics, despite things like magic, cyberware and a broad array of special attacks. Combat still is good and fun, sometimes very challenging on higher difficulty, and it is refreshing with a return to turn based combat that rewards planning ahead and managing your APs instead of just button-mashing QTE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Highly recommended, if you get the deluxe version with the OST ;)

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is an adaptation of the classic cyberpunk tabletop pen and paper RPG. Set in an alternative history future where magic has returned to the world, elves, dwarves, trolls, and orks live side by side with humans in dense urban cities, and corporations are a law unto themselves; the game centers around the segment of humanity who makes their living in the shadows, the runners. Hacker, mercenary, detective, sorcerer, where there is a job that needs doing, there will be someone willing to get paid to do it.The game itself is a single player, turn-based strategy RPG, utilizing 3/4 isometric perspective with 3D character models set against sprite based backgrounds. The sprite backgrounds are static and well done, while the character designs are somewhat poorly textured with resolution below that which the majority of modern systems could easily handle; belying the limited budget the company had to work with. Gameplay takes the form of point and click interaction with the world map and carries over directly into combat, utilizing the same environments. Combat is somewhat klunky, as there are problems with the interaction of the courser and corners of the movement field.The game itself is, however, merely a platform. It is in reality intended for players to build and share their own Shadowrun campaigns, and the full game editor comes included with the base game as well as a professionally developed campaign. Thanks to Steam Works, player campaigns are free, though professionally developed campaigns will be sold as DLC as they become available. Sadly there is no multiplayer option what-so-ever, crippling one of the intregral elements of the pen-and-paper game.Overall, the game's campaign will run you around 12 hours, and is a good buy if you can get it on sale, for any enthusiast of turn-based strategy RPGs.

												I absolutely love this game. Although it lacks in the free roaming aspect that many RPG’s do well in the story is extremely immersive and the characters are interesting and at times frustrating. The old-school isometric view lends itself well to Shadowrun and the lighting when in urban areas sets a great tone for the dark cyber punk world the game is set in.  The character creation isn’t quite deep enough in regards to ascetics but more than makes up for this in the skill tree and I found myself fiddling with the skills for ages whilst envisioning what kind of cyber punk badass I was going to be. The combat is turn based which I found very refreshing, as I am a massive fan of turn based strategy games, and I found the whole process of finding cover and blasting the enemy very entertaining. To sum up if you’re not a fan of deep story driven games with lots of text and long spells between the action then this game isn’t for you, although I would recommend anyone to embark on this story……you won’t be sorry.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												A great game, lovingly recreated to resemble the old super nintendo game I used to love.  The turn based gameplay works really well and the karma system for levelling up gives limited scope so decisions must be made carefully, rather than having a fully levelled up character before too long.  Dead Mans Switch felt linear and the responses felt as though they didn't really change the game outcome much, however the expansion, Dragonfall, addresses many issues including the ability to save anywhere.  Dragonfall is a much more honed Shadowrun campaign in my opinion and deserves an applause for the production team who clearly thought hard about the game story and characters.  A triumph.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												Overall, I would give this game a 9/10. Everything is fantastic, and I cannot wait to play Dragonfall someday and also play player-created campaigns. I am also inspired to pick up the paper and pen version of Shadowrun, as well as Shadowrun Online. It's just that Dead Man's Switch became quite disappointing. Just take it out, or give the players more freedom, and everything here would be stellar.*****Now for ***SPOILERS*** Kind of.*****I have not played Dragonfall, so this review is of the main campaign, Dead Man's Switch. I really enjoy pretty much every aspect of this game--the environment, combat, characters, atmosphere, etc.--except for the main story. Despite getting very interested in the storyline after the first few lines were presented to me, almost all of my excitement was lost when the Ripper was revealed. I was having fun treating DMS as a murder mystery; I was carefully examining everything and trying to figure out who the Ripper could be--I even had some evidence to support who I thought could be the Ripper--but the game pretty much points a huge sign at the real suspect from the moment they are introduced, and this is overwhelmingly disappointing. The other side of the story after the reveal doesn't even make much sense.

												Shadowrun Returns is a tactical strategy rpg which functions similar to the X-Com or UFO series games, set in the Shadowrun universe. Pros: *Nice Artstyle*Simple yet effective combat and skill system, allows you to more or less build your "class" by picking which stats and skills you want to learn.*Lands the Shadowrun Universe pretty wellCons:*Very short playthrough (core game, not the Shadowrun: Dragonfall expansion)*This game is very easy on "normal". I recommend to anyone that has played the genre before to play on the hardest difficulties.*Could use more weapons/armor/configuration. I kept feeling like there should be another drop or weapon coming soon... and it never does.Overall: 7/10Fun game, looks nice, but it's very short and could use more content and story. I am about 5-6 hours in (2 did not get recorded by Steam), and I would say according to the chapter list on most websites I'm about 75% through the game. I am looking forward to trying the expansion however, and I will update my review when I get the chance. Many reviews for the expansion title seem to point out that it's a bit more complete and a touch longer than the core campaign.I would purchase this game again, since I bought it on sale... but I don't think I would pay full price for it. This is a good pickup if you catch it on sale, and if so I would grab the expansion to go with it, otherwise the game may feel a bit incomplete.

Posted: November 23, 2015
												Shadowrun returns was a kickstarter project that gained traction rather fast, although like most kickstarters this was due to nostalgia. This game stands on its own extremely well.Shadowrun returns is a cyberpunk fantasy tactical rpg, which in retrospective sounds absurd but its an idea that works really well and is amplified by the impressive dungeons and dragons art style.Typical for an RPG you level up with points gained from battles but what you put your points into in this case either help you or hinder you.Upgrades are apart of the experience and have a tradeoff mechanic, sacrificing one thing to gain something else, but comes into play later in the game.During my time with the game the battles were more interesting than the story and in an rpg story should be just as important as the rest of the game.The game stands on its own legs and is a good experience for someone who enjoys strategic rpg games and/or cyberpunk settingsRating: 8.5/10

Posted: August 29, 2015
												A tale of two halves.The first half is a basic-yet-intriguing cyberpunk XCOM-lite game. The second is a tedious, monotonous, dragged-out affair that completely spoils everything and made me very glad it was only $2.50 when I picked it up.PROS-Crisp art style that lends itself fairly well to the setting-Some interesting characters (kind of)-The music is decent the first time around-Neat outfits-It's less than ten hours....CONS-Environments/levels are 99% static and lifeless-The dialogue/script is wildly inconsistent in terms of style, going from grandiose to vernacular at will. It's like two or three different guys were writing without consulting the design document. Then at the end they were just like "♥♥♥♥ it, too hard to redo all this work"-After a couple hours, the music grates-Combat is far too simple to be enjoyable for long-Lack of cool loot/drops-Exceedingly linear-Most characters are neat at first but then it becomes obvious there's no depth-The narrative takes a wild shift in the second half, and it's not for the betterment of the game-The second half is only more difficult because gobs of enemies are thrown at you, rather than anything clever or original-Puzzles can all be solved by holding down Alt to see what few things are interactive-Terrible ending that made me uninstall immediately after closing the game-Along with the tonal shifts, most of the scant humor isn't funny, and the cyberpunk/Shadowrun terms were used in a tryharding manner rather than making sense or adding atmosphere-Lots of typos and generally-lazy writing-Decking is uselessly dullOverall it's a game that starts out strong and finishes way after boredom sets in. The combat is stale with little-to-no tactical depth, and level design is so narrow-sighted and basic that I can't help but think these guys are out of their league. And this is from someone who views cyberpunk as the best genre in all of media.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Like every game, this isn't for everyone. The default campaign is short (took me slightly north of 10 hours without skipping sidequests), it has a check point system instead of save anywhere (getting changed in Berlin DLC, unsure if being ptached in to cover default game too), lack of lootable corpses, and no voice acting. If none of that bothers you, it's worth a look. The story isn't bad, and there's a lot of dialog.My main complaints are as an RPG, it's kind of lacking content. The campaign is very linear, not a lot of tactical depth to combat, no ability to customize anything except a handful of consumables on party members, nearly all hired runners lack any personality, and reactivity is pretty sparse (i.e. special dialog for race/gender is rare). However, where this game will really shine is future content. It shipped with an ugly but powerful editor that allows modders to fix certain things (more open world questing and lootable bodies for starters). The Berlin DLC is also planned to be more open ended.Overall, a shallow but solid default campaign. The best of this game will come to the surface in the coming months.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Back in my SNES days, Shadowrun was by far my favourite game.  These days, that's the only game that really sticks in my mind when I think back to playing that console.  Over the years I have tracked where the game was going.  Horrified that Microsoft bought the rights, but thought maybe they'll do something good with it.  Nope.  2007, I saw it was just another first-person shooter, not tied to the Shadowrun universe, I sadly concluded there was no chance of ever seeing another Shadowrun game like the one on SNES.  Guess I'll have to install a SNES emulator and play the original (never got around to it).Then I was cruising around Google Play last week, when Shadowrun Returns showed up on my recommended list.  OHHHH.... darn.  No tablet.  Yet.  But tis on Steam, and it works on Linux.  REJOICE!  I tried it for a few hours and so far it's looking great.  I played both the Dead Man's Switch campaign provided by Harebrained Schemes, and a story someone is putting together to replicate the SNES version.Thanks Microsoft for giving the game's rights back to Jordan Weisman!  Thanks Jordan and HBS for bringing back the world of Shadowrun to our screens!  Thanks  Kickstarter for the campaign to fund HBS' development.  Thanks all who provided funding!  Had I known the campaign existed last year, I would've contributed for sure.

The ambients are wonderful, the conversations are well-thought, and you do feel you're in some crazy society, all the way through. The gameplay is extremely simple, but you've got a miriad of choices along the way. Most of ( if not all ) of the puzzles have several different ways to be solved, depending on how you build your character, or your gaming style.You can hack stuff, use your charms and talk your way, shoot it, sneak it, however you want.From a troll bouncer that's as polite and philosophical as ever, to a psychotic ugly elf, you're gonna get surprised by this game. Very very nice.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												I've played this game for ten hours before I eventually got too frustrated and uninstalled.What I thought when I first encountered it was a misstep, (the lack of any save/load game feature), turned into a death knell -- you WILL reach moments in the game, where despite your best planning you are left in the worst condition you could be and are unable to continue.In a typical RPG, you would restore to an autosave or a quicksave or otherwise from somewhere earlier on and roll the dice again, presumably to try and get a better result from a combat sequence -- you'd be free to because a regular game recognises the mutability of each instance of combat and provides you that opportunity. That is NOT the case in this game: if you get to the penultimate area of a mission with no health, dead team members, or no supplies, you must either run through the situation over and over from their awkwardly placed checkpoints, or start the entire mission over again from BEFORE you initiated it. This includes talking to all the NPCs, watching unskippable cinematics, recruting new team members, purchasing supplies, levelling up, and travelling to the mission area. Depending on how much preparation you require, you may spend more time in preliminary prepping than actually playing the game, going over the same (admittedly clever and consistent) dialogue, losing its significance each time.This surely seems like an issue that one shouldn't harp on, but consider how elemental even a rudimentary save system is to any RPG you've ever played, and then remove it. How many opportunities are there to say that it was a universally good choice? In this game, the absence is so notable that it almost renders the game worthless.As for the positives, the game is set in the legendary Shadowrun universe, fully realised in video game form! The writing is quite often witty and on point. There is a potential for infinite content with the open authoring tools.It's worth buying if you think you can deal with the big drawback, but it is a big one.

Posted: April 25, 2014
												If you're a Shadowrun fan, or at least have some experience with the old SNES and/or Genesis games (the 2006 Xbox one doesn't count), this is worth picking up. Shadowrun Returns plays like XCOM with more RPG elements and without the punishing difficulty that is a hallmark of that series. The story is full of references and inside jokes that will render fans of the series nostalgic, but even if you're new to the series, important concepts and characters are explained at least adequately enough for the story to make sense. My one complaint is that the story, which is fairly short, is extremely linear and offers virtually no sidequesting. However, this game is meant to be just one "campaign" in the Shadowrun setting, and the real replay value lies in the editor, which allows players to create their own adventures and share them with the world. Despite its linearity and lack of meaningful choices for the player to make, I say buying it is justified by its low price tag. I hope this game helps give the Shadowrun setting more publicity, because it's definitely unique and worth investigating.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a surprisingly addictive isometric cyberpunk RPG. The combat has enough tactical depth to keep you on your toes, but the real strength to this game is the story. The dialogue between characters is both interesting and meaningful, often making use of slang specific to the Shadowrun universe which aids immersion. The game does feel quite linear at times and conversational options are often inconsequential, but it doesn't detract from the experience thanks to engaging storyline. I'm genuinely surprised at the quality of the game, especially when consideration is given to the asking price. I think anyone looking for a modern take on old-school RPG'ing would be wise to try Shadowrun.Note: ignore the playtime, my shadowrunning was done offline.

Posted: July 15, 2014
												I've never played the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, those aren't my bag. I did love the Shadowrun game on SNES that I played as a kid. This game brings a good blend of nostaglia for that previous title in a similar, but updated look, but it definitely also takes advantage of lessons learned in gaming in the intervening years. Combat in both the real world and while dekking is intuitive and easy to grasp. There are a number of skill tree options to monkey with, but not so many as to require a spreadsheet. Overall I found the game to be a satisfying experience, not terribly difficult, but that's not what I was looking for here anyway. Good times, definitely worth picking up if you enjoyed the old SNES game or the trailer to this one appeals to you.

Posted: July 31, 2014
												The Dead Man's Switch(DMS) campaign is forgettable and is only notable for having an annoying enemy that can only be killed with a cumbersome mechanic. There are a handful of interesting interactions during DMS but overall its honestly not worth playing through and can be easily skipped.Dragonfall(DF), on the other hand, is awesome and is filled with characters and scenarios that are as imaginative, well written,  and worth exploring as some of the best RPGs that I have ever played. DF additionally contains a much better structure than DMS, by that I mean rather than having a linear quest with hardly any side branches that you undertake with some flavorless NPCs, DF tasks you with a central goal and allows you to lead a team of fairly unique characters along a questline that has scores of opportunity to explore more of the world of Shadowrun. I enjoyed the vast majority of my time with DF, save for the hacking bits (called decking in this universe), and some later game fights with some annoyingly powerful enemies. Altough, I wholeheartedly recommend DF, Its a shame that you have to buy both to play DF but since thats the case I would advise that you buy the campaigns at a reduced cost and skip DMS.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												I didn't play the original Shadowrun back in the early nineties, so the game gets no retro love in this review. Shadowrun returns is a average cyberpunk and magic theme RPG. The main defect in the game is the vacuity of the gameworld comprised of the different interconnected areas. The game basically gives you only plot items to interact and the city locations are small. True to the "pocket world" RPG approach the plot is your average RPG pipeline stuff. Shadowrun Returns also lacks the intricate background stories for NPCs that most RPGs have, but this aspect of team interaction is added in the Dragonfall DLC. Dragonfall also does everything a little bit better, passing of as a relatively good RPG. It takes maybe 15-18 hours to complete Dragonfall if you're a completionist and about 20h for the main game. Since there's lots of combat, which is not that great, the game in my opinion is somwhat lacking in replay value. Though the end game of Dragonfall does play differently depending on few key choices, you're not inclined to mow through the same combat laden missions again.

												There are two camps that come to my mind. Those that enjoy being 'told' a story and those that enjoy 'telling' the story. If you are one who resides mostly in the camp of the former, then I tell you this:"Wait"There is absolutly no urgency in your purchase of this game, not yet anyway. The Shadowrun community needs to bolster its numbers with creative individuals, and get into crafting trinkets and stories. This game is an excellent tool to tell stories, and with the back-drop of cyber-punk in a world of magic, dragons, and elves one has many resources to craft tales of epic adventures.Now to those of the second camp, get your butts in here! We need more content, and the only way to ensure this is for you to help us in creating it. In due time, this will grow to be something absolutly amazing. Till then, if you do choose to purchase this now, 'Dead man switch' will be the first thing you will get to play through. It is a good introduction to the posibilities you as a story teller will be able to create.

Posted: June 4, 2015
												Shadowrun Returns is an excellent, engrossing, and enjoyable tactical RPG. It does come highly recommended; sort of.When the game originally released, it came with the default campaign known as "Dead Man's Switch". It's enjoyable, with some memorable characters, but there were complaints about it being too linear with too much focus on straight gunplay. Now obviously, that is still available. There's also tons of mods for custom campaigns. There was a DLC for this game, called "Dragonfall", which was superior to the base game in almost every way. Now in order to get that, you need to purchase "Shadowrun: Dragonfall - Director's Cut". Buying this title here will not grant you access to Dragonfall anymore, sadly. I personally recommend both titles, but at this point it would be best to wait for this title to go on sale, and pick up the seperate Dragonfall game ASAP.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												Cyberlike, tatical strategy, turn-based rpg. A lot of great things about this game however, there are a lot of flaws as well. The graphics are nice. The artwork is fantastic. The story is interesting. Shadowruns is a great series!Not to mention, the game editor produced some amazing community content.I especially love that it's compatible with my tablet pc. You don't need a keyboard to play. As a result, I spent my long subway rides progressing with the story which was a great way to pass time. However... this game is extremely linear. There are dialogue choices, but most of the time.. They don't matter. Most, if not all, dialogues end the same.Most importantly, the gameplay is extremely linear. There's not much exploration and the paths are clearly laid out for you. Adding to that, there are very very little side quests to actually do. There are just optional objectives that give you extra karma or help a little with the main quest. A little bit about the combat: Because it's turn-based, it takes a while for each battle. There's no way to speed up the process so battles often take longer than you'd expect. Adding on top of that, You can only save out of combat - Be prepared to finish or don't start it at all. Tldr;+ Interesting story+ Can be fun, depending on your own preferences+ Great time-passer+ Amazing artwork+ Great community content- Linear gameplay & plot- Linear dialogue - Slow combatDespite it all, Shadowrun Returns is a great place to introduce yourself and start the video game series. The sequels are a huge improvement as well. I recommend that you play it!

Posted: August 13, 2013
												Great game for fans of old school RPG at a great price. If you've read Neuromancer; and loved it, if you've spent countless hours playing Baldur's Gate or older Fallout titles; and couldn't tear yourself away from them, this is a game for you.And once you're done with original campaign, quality user generated content awaits you on Steam Workshop and 3rd party sites like Shadowrun Nexus. Modders are so ambitious that they are recreating whole Shadowrun sourcebooks. So, come on, join us in the shadows, chummer.Shadowrun Dragonfall: I know they are marketing this as merely DLC, but DLC this is not. It is a full blown, old fashioned expansion pack. Dragonfall packs a bigger campaign, set in the anarchy ridden Berlin of 2054, otherwise known as the Flux State.HBS has listened to fans and addressed all the major issues from the original game. Saving your game anywhere? Check! More interesting companions with actual personalities and backstory? Yes, sir! Side missions? Of course! This time around you are not led by the hand. You get a hub, certain Berlin neighborhood, where you can choose your missions, even reject them if Mr. Johnson offering it isn't on the level. You can chat with the (meta)humans living there. Solve their problems. Learn of their past, and they all have some very shady skeletons in the closet. Let's face it, only people running from something come to the F-State...and corporations. But the latter are a different story altogether. Runs themselves have been improved considerably. There are multiple solutions to every problem and some tough choices to be made in practically every one. Enemy encounters have been improved. Combat is more enjoyable, overall. Non-combat skills feature more prominently. Skills and etiquette checks are very frequent. You can go in guns, fists, blades and magic blazing. But you can also do things covertly. It's all up to you.Writing in this game is great. Story takes hold of you, is full of twist and turns, and won't let you go 'till the end. By that time, you'll crave more. Speaking of length, you'll get at least twenty hours out of the game. Even more, if you play on harder difficulties, want to speak to everyone and see everything.Dragonfall is the definitive reason to pick up the original game. If you're into old school RPGs, cyberpunk, and value a good story, you won't be disappointed with this game.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Well i grew up playing the SNES game Shadow Runners and It was a title that I was quite fond of. I saw this game on steam one day and I thought taking a chance on a purchase was a no brainer...I'm glad I did.While it is not an official sequal to the SNES classic the story does continue on in the same shadowrun world. The story is a little cliche' you play a shadow runner avenging the death of your friend. I don't want to give away too much of the plot as the campaign is quite small and unfortunately linear however the story and gameplay do create an enjoyable experience. There are many different character classes. Some specialise in close or ranged combat. Others specialise in magic and summoning. There is also a decker class that specializes in breaking into computers and invading cyberspace. You get a choice of how you would like to play the game based on Karma (attribute points) to apply to your skills. Party Combat itself is fun although not difficult just requires basic tactical common sense.Overall I have really enjoyed the experience and recommend this game 100% when its on sale. Thanks to the steam workshop there is some replayability however the main story is only worth one playthrough. I hear the other Shadowrun games on steam are even better so I am excited to try!

Posted: July 8, 2014
Pros The Cyberpunk-meets-Fantasy-Magic set in the real-world near-future aesthetic is great. The way the stats are balanced leaves the class-race combos open, and encourages exploration of different options/layouts. I just wish there was a way to respecc. Maybe there is later in the game. I love the tactical, turn-based combat.Cons The single angle of the camera gets a little annoying in combat; e.g. if you've got an ally standing directly beneath/infront of an enemy, you can accidentally target your ally because their hitbox overlaps the enemy's. If I could rotate the camera to a different angle, that'd solve my biggest gripe with the game The first campaign (Dead Man's Switch) is interesting, but rather slow-paced. Haven't tried the expansion campgain or any of the user generated content yet.All in all, it's a fun tactical, turn-based, text-driven RPG. The character creation options are pretty robust -- not so much in terms of appearances, but in terms of class selection and creation. It's easy to start out with one of the game's premade archetypes and expand out into other disciplines as you get the feel for the game, or to just stick with a single discipline. I don't know how well either works comparatively because I haven't played long enough. The story of the first campaign moves a little slow; they do a good job of tying the tutorial stuff into the story without breaking immersion, but that's kind of what slows it down.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												At the time of this writing, Hairbrained Studios have only released "Dead Man's Switch" and "Dragonfall", with the latter a significantly stronger module than the former. Both are heavily combat-based, and while careful positioning and action choices can tilt battles in your favor, the RNG can make sure that even if you do everything right, your team can still be wiped in a couple rounds due to keyboard-smashing bad luck (in this respect, the combat is very similar to X-COM: Enemy Unknown). But if you're getting an RPG like this, you're hopefully getting it knowing that luck is part of the game.It's all very good fun, particularly on harder difficulties. Agonizing over how to build your character, whom to take on a mission, and how to position them each round should please old-school turn-based RPG purists. The story arcs and character depth are not really fantastic, but the game is built on going out and completing runs (usually by shooting/stabbing/blowing things up, with only occassional decking responsibilities).Definite recommend, particularly if you've played the pencil-and-paper version.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												Shadowrun: Returns and its Expansion/DLC Shadowrun: Dragonfall is a turn-based tactical RPG game created by a studio called Harebrained Schemes out of Seattle, WA. The base game Shadowrun: Returns was released on Steam on July 25th, 2013, and the DLC Shadowrun: Dragonfall was released on February 27th, 2014.For those not familiar with the Shadowrun universe, it is based on a cyber-punk futuristic planet Earth. It is the 2050’s. The world is run by enormous, greedy corporations who will stop at nothing to acquire power. The twist is that a few decades earlier (around our current modern-day) magic returned to our world. With it came elves, dwarves, trolls, ogres, and other magical creatures.Shadowrunners are for-hire mercenaries who will do just about any job as long as there is money to be made. Whether it is stealing secrets from a corporate rival, working as security to protect those secrets, or taking out individuals that stand in their way of power, they are hired by big corporations to do their “dirty work”. They work in the seedy underbelly of this corporate society and live and survive in the shadows.I discovered Shadowrun when I was browsing around Steam looking for something new to play. Dragonfall was pretty highly recommended, and after reading up a bit on it I thought it sounded like something I would enjoy. I started it up and decided to start from the beginning and play through the original campaign. I was immediately sucked in to the story. I just had to keep playing, if for no reason other than to find out how the story turned out!The story for each of the campaigns is probably the best feature of the game. I don’t think I’ve been this captivated by a video game’s story since Final Fantasy VII! Even though there are no video cut scenes and no voice overs, the story is told VERY well.The story is progressed by speaking with various NPCs in the game world. When you speak to them you are given a number of choices as to how you want to respond in the conversation. There are a few places in the game where the dialogue options you choose will change the sequence of events to complete the mission. There isn’t a LOT of these places, but they are there. Also some dialogue options may not be available to you because of certain conditions. For example, if your Strength stat is high you may be able to bully that gang leader into giving you the key you need to progress. But, if you lack strength and are more intelligent, you may have to use brains over brawn to get what you need. There is also a feature called “Etiquette”. The game describes etiquette as “knowing how to behave in various social situations”. In-game this means you will get certain dialogue options based on what etiquette you choose when you create your character. In the example above, if my character has the “Gang” etiquette I may have a dialogue option when talking to the gang leader that will open up different options for completing the mission.Character progression is pretty straight-forward. When you create your character there are a few class archetypes that you can choose from. This gives you a basic set of skills to start from. As you progress you will acquire more skill points that you can spend on any skill you want. If you want to spend your skill points to be a shotgun-wielding mage you can, or if you want to specialize in being an uber “Decker” (Shadowrun’s version of a computer hacker) you can do that too. While skill points come pretty easy, it’s still a good idea to specialize in one or two areas. The campaign isn’t long enough for you to get enough skill points to max out everything.The skills were all pretty well explained right in game. All of your teammates and other Shadowrunners that you can hire all have their own set of skills and abilities. So if you are a shotgun-wielding mage you can hire a teammate that has the hacking skills you need for a mission. I kind of like this system. It lets you build your character however you like and then you can complement your skills with those of the shadowrunners you run with.From the very beginning I felt like the game environment and the atmosphere were very well done. I felt like I was running around in the movie Blade Runner! Everything was futuristic, yet familiar. The characters I interacted with and their portraits definitely captured the cyberpunk feel. Each character you encounter has their own personality and they are very unique. I thought the music was great too, even if there wasn’t a lot of variety. I thought it fit well with the theme of the game.The tactical combat style is what attracted me to the game in the first place. I found the combat to be a lot of fun, and in some places it was VERY challenging. For most missions you have your player character and three other Shadowrunners to make up your team.When you are walking around the map everything is in real time. But, as soon as combat starts, it switches to turn-based tactical mode. Every member of your team has a set number of “Action Points” (AP) that you can spend each turn. Firing your weapon or using a special ability may cost an AP point. Moving to a different location with better cover may cost another. Casting that healing spell or reloading your rifle will cost another. This is where the tactical part comes in. You have to decide what you want each member of your team to do each round. Do you want to focus fire and finish off one enemy at a time, or do you spread out and burn them all down at once? You also have to be careful that you don’t leave yourself pinned down somewhere without enough AP to use that medkit to keep you alive in the fight. Once you spend all your AP for that turn, the computer will play the turn of your enemies. Once they are done it is your turn to spend your AP again. Add in that each weapon type has a different range and friendly-fire can be hazardous to your teammates, it makes combat VERY interesting.The Good, The Bad, and the UglyAs a whole I very much enjoyed Shadworun: Returns and Shadowrun: Dragonfall. The story lines for BOTH campaigns are among the best I’ve ever seen in a video game. The first campaign is a BIT slow to start but it’s only so at the beginning. Combat is a lot of fun and can be pretty challenging at times. There were a few missions I had to play through a couple of different times with different strategies before I was victorious.I really enjoyed the skill system as well. It was easy to understand and easy to use. I didn’t feel like I needed to go online and read hundreds of forum posts to learn what the best build for my character would be. I could just pick a couple of skills I wanted to learn that were fun for me and go with it and be successful.The only bad worth mentioning is the length of the campaigns. My total play time on Steam is 48 hours, and that was running all the way through both campaigns. I’m sure I’m a lot slower that a lot of other people. However, considering the inexpensive price of the game and the fact that there is a lot of player generated content on the Steam Workshop, there is a lot of replayability here. Hopefully they will also be releasing more DLC in the future.About the only “ugly” I can say about the game is a couple of buggy missions I encountered. In one mission there was an event that didn’t trigger properly and I was unable to continue because a door would not unlock. I had to replay that mission one or two times before it finally triggered properly and I could advance.Also, some earlier reviews criticized Shadowrun: Returns’ save system. At release you could only save at certain checkpoints. This is no longer the case. I’m not sure if it was with the release of Dragonfall or if it was before that, but they changed the game so you can now save anywhere.See my original review at http://www.mistervertigo.net

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Simply a-freaking-mazing.Shadowrun Returns is my first venture into this universe, and after a ten hour campaign, I'm completely obsessed. If you are also new, but a little wary about dropping the money for this title, allow me to explain a little about the game...SR is an isometric-style Rpg, set in a future-fantasy universe, where elves and dwarves wield shotguns and cast spells. Starting up the default campaign, Dead Man Switch, you create a character. Race, class and appearance are all up to you. Then, the developer, Harebrained Schemes drops you into a well-written and thoughtfully crafted story, presented in a text-based format - no voice acting here, and I think it's better for it, but that's personal preference. Dialog options are different depending on how you build your character and elicit different responses from NPCs, with charisma allowing you to sweet-talk, and etiquettes let you rub elbows with the many groups that populate Seattle.You play a Shadowrunner, a type of mercenary, doing the dirty-work of multi-billion dollar corporations and aristocrats for cash. Gameplay is very reminiscent of the recent Xcom: Enemy Unknown. If you didn't like that, chances are you won't like this. Every turn, each combatant is given a certain number of moves, from moving to shooting and using items. It's very tactical and you could wind up dead if you don't think before you click. Several jobs you undertake have you bringing other Runners on to watch your back and take a cut of the pay, so you're almost never alone.I found no hick-ups in the gameplay during my play-through. The specials and items are balanced well, meaning death is often the fault of the player's ill preparation. The game is fair, which is about all a gamer could ask for. Also available are game editors, allowing anyone to write their own stories and scenarios for others to enjoy. I haven't been able to try any out because there currently seems to be a bug that causes the ugc to be downloaded to the wrong files, making them difficult to locate.Shadowrun Returns is a gem that I'm glad was funded. It's not for everyone, but if it sounds like it's up your alley, I urge you to pick it up.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game for those who enjoy old-school RPG's. Dragonfall DLC is a must have.The games strengths are in good writing, rich world history and all in all beautiful artwork.The world is beautifully detailed whether you're in the streets of Redmond Barrens, a luxurious corporate headquarter or busy market hub in Germany. I might not be the biggest fan of the "cartoony" style the designers went ahead with but all in all it works. The portrait artwork is also beautifully done.Dialogue and text is descriptive and good all through the games, lack of voice is the proper way to do an rpg when you have good writers.While there are many things in the game that could have been done better, far better even, I cannot think of any major  flaws or issues in design. Base game delivers an okay story and gameplay although it's lacking in many ways I still managed to get some 12 hours of gameplay from it and did not feel bad about getting the game but I did feel like it could have been done better and certainly it could have been bigger.Dragonfall DLC is a whole different story however. In fact, I would say that Dragonfall is -the- reason to buy Shadowrun Returns. Dragonfall provides you with a more classic Shadowrun feel, the storyline is excellent, the permanent companions have personalities and plenty of dialogue in and out of missions and even the local npc's are always worth talking to. Dragonfall features more of the actual Shadowrun gigs, the game is full of choices to make, plot twists to uncover and provides far richer experience for all types of characters as all types of skills have more uses.The Dragonfall DLC provided me with additional 18-20 hours of gameplay, far more than the base game does.Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall dlc's only major problem is that it leaves me wanting for more. So much more.. I want a bigger game with more content!Harebrained Schemes has a great basis set up, hopefully they will continue in the path of Dragonfall as it is obviously doing so many things right.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												While the main campain of this game is rather weak the world of Shadowrun is enthralling. Given that users create more content for this game it's a sure buy on sale. 8/10

Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never played Shadowrun when it was on the NES or whatever else it was on. I joined the world with Shadowrun Returns and I have to say its a good place to start. It opens up a lot of doors, and even some windows, to a whole new world of science and magic. The controls feel clunky sometimes, but its by no means game breaking. Its turn table based combat, good guys go first more often then not, and then the bad guys. You get to make your own character from various races and classes. You don't have to stick to class you pick at creation though. You can be a mage with some intense decking skills, or a rigger who knows some summoning. They don't force you to stick to a class. Just be careful, as the game often hints 'A Jack of all trades is a master of none.'You play as a Shadowrunner, a gun for hire in the streets. You've fallen on some hard times and seem to be thinking more about your future then your past, till you get a call from a old contact. A guy you used to run with, Sam. He's been killed recently and set up a 'dead mans switch' in his brain to send you a message when he finally kicks the bucket. Well, someone kicked his bucket for him and you need to travel to Seattle and find out who did it. There are some serious twists and turns as you dig deeper into this world, trying to uncover who did it.Dragonfall is leap and bounds ahead of Dead mans Switch. The graphics feel tighter, but there is no real change. Some of the sounds and combat has been tweaked a bit and the save anywhere anytime button is a lifesaver. The supporting characters feel a lot more real, and can be interacted with anytime. They have backgrounds and lives, and aren't afarid to give you a piece of their minds if they think your doing something wrong.In the newest 'dlc' you get a whole new campgain, set up for a new character but thanks to some dedicated players you can import your character over to this save file to run the DLC. Your out on a run with long time friend Monica and her crew in Berlin. Its a simple job, a smash and grab type. However things aren't always as they seem... Monica ends up dead and you and the crew end up fleeing for your lives. With Monica dead there is a seat to be filled in the community where she lived, and her crew wants revenge. Will you be the vengeful angel and the savior all in one package?

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun. I picked up the Pen and Paper RPG when I was younger. Sadly it took years before finding a group to play it. Luckly around my University years I found a decent group of people and we are gaming since than. I am an hardcore fan so probably my Review could be a bit biased. Frist of all I strongly suggest to read a bit before gaming. Just the "Primer" which is a small guide\introduction to the World of Shadowrun available from the site Shadowrun Universe (official site for all things related to Shadowrun). Once you have the Primer you can have a good idea of what to expect from the Setting. I know that at a frist glance it looks strange maybe even too much but trust me it is awesome. The more you will dig the better it will get, specially if you start to read the various RPG manuals and novels. If you liked the setting buy this game. The basic Campaign included in Shadowrun Returns is a classic. If you never rped or played Shadowrun (I am mostly referring to SNES and GENESIS Games) this is a wonderfull start. The narration is set in 2050s which is a very cool period for Shadowrun (keep in mind that in the current RP Setting the time is around 2075) and it is based on some of the hottest plots of that period. The game is a basic Turn Based Combat with RP elements in the form of dialogues where the various options depends on which skill you have. Back when it was just published the Game lacked few things like save anywhere option. Luckly this was fixed up in the 1st DLC Dragonfall. Dragonfall is even better than the basic game. The Devs listened to us Players and fixed few things and I dare to say even took inspiration from some of UGC - User generated Content (More of this later). Dragonfall can look a bit boring at the start with the logic of "Do a Run, get back and run again" (Run is a work, a mission in Shadowrun) but the Narration, the Plot goes always up till its end. In Dragonfall I was not impressed by the first Runs but nearby the end I could not stop to see how this Story was going to end. The only negative side of both Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall is that you can not manage your NPCs. You can select who can help you in a Run but you do not have any kind of control on their Skills and how they improve. Probably this will be fixed in future DLCs. If the basic game and the DLC are not enough there are UGCs. Shadowrun Community is very active and Devs select from time to time some UCG to play just to show up how much it is good. There are a lot of good Artist out there who are working on big UCG like remakes of SNES and Genesis Shadowrun Games. I strongly suggest to take a loot at "Shadowrun Unlimited". Posted: April 3, 2014
												ahhhhhh, sitting back with a glass of 15 year glenlivet and a pipe in your man chair. It's hard to find a more refreshing and manlier past time....oh wait, what is this? Cyberpunk infused with a refreshing take on fantasy? In an Isometric rpg using hand crafted maps with a unique art style? I have a game to play, enough of this manly lounging about!tl;dr;  Overall 7/10. Worth the cash if your gaming plate is empty and, you want a fun rpg with decent story telling and stunning, unique, art direction and  visuals to sit back and relax with.-hardcore rpgs fans will find the Dev's campaigns lacking rpg-ness in areas-those who want the best parts of the campign will have to pay $30 for the toolset and dragonfall -it missed its calling -> it needs networking/co-op support so it can be used as a pnp campaign tool for shadowrunners. In my opinion, with these expansions added on this tool would be hands down the best way to run a pnp shadowrun campaign with friends.Shadowrun plays as a mix between old school isometric rpgs such as baldurs gate and uses a combat system similar to the new Xcom by Firaxis. Unfortunatey though the first campagin is...lacking. While a fun play through and introduction to the universe, it is necessary to buy the dragonfall campaign to truly see what this framework is capable of. However, hardcore Isometric rpg fans will find this game lacking. Side quests are few and far between, you have no control over how your npc companions (depending upon the campaign by harebrained) level up, and a general lack of freedom in what should be a more open world experience. However, the game is primarily designed for being a tool that players use to build their own campaigns. Sadly though, this shouldn't have to be a substitute for harebrain's lack of campaign building talent. The game also needs co-op, just hear me out. This is turn based game, based upon a pen a paper rpg, with focus on building a single character for a player with full stats/"classes", with tools to build your own campaigns and maps. While entertaining to experience in single player, and as cool as the build your own rpg framework is, it missed its calling. This is a tool that could be expanded to actually run a pen and paper campaigns! There are things like roll20.net but lets be honest, the visual tools and dice support are lacking for odd ball rpgs like Shadowrun (huge lack of cyberpunk visuals like tiles/characters/creatures and a lot of custom equation building required to get it running properly). Adding networking/co-op would allow a savvy dm to build their own maps/campaigns and run a pnp rpg with visual support and a set rule framework for combat! (seriously, the art direction is gorgeous and no need to worry about that "one player" cheating their stats or rule loop holes).Overall, for the price ($30 if you buy all the dev built campaigns) it's worth the money. The 2 campaign  stories are fun, the lenghts of the stories are good, the changes in Dragonfall are proof that harebrained is listening to the community to improve upon their stories, tool upgrades, and improving rpg elements in their own work. There are a few bugs/optimizations that need to be sorted out but, I also need to upgrade my pc (really badly) so I'd like to hear how those with beefier rigs hold up. (I'm pretty sure the issues I ran into were due to the HD graphics straining my rig at high resolutions).

Posted: May 9, 2014
												This game, this game is one of the few titles I can name that truly inspires my mind to delve depths unimaginable the setting is superb, the lore rich and thick and let's not forget the beautiful controls and gameplay all in all I would say this title is one of my absolute favorites, but let's talk about why.First off the setting is one of the, if not the most beautifully crafted settings to grace the games industry the world feels alive and full of character and emotion as though it is dripping pure atmosphere and spawning true intrigue this is because it is built off of an amazing title already being part of the deep and wonderful world of Shadowrun making it one of the best modern iterations of a classic game series I have ever had the pleasure to step into.Now let's saunter on over to the lore of the game, which is built upon the original Pen and Paper title and the superb yet confusing NES and Genesis title, not to spoil anything too major but the entire world has been changed massively by an event called the awakening and yea, you know what just go read up on everything else.The gameplay is another area I want to cover as the game plays like an Turn Based Roleplaying Game, now the game comes with one preinstalled mission which is actually quite huge but there are a lot of player made missions on sites like NexusMods and even on the workshop itself add on the beautiful levelling system which stops you becoming extremely over powered early and you have fantastic gameplay.But I don't think the game is one hundred percent perfect, the preinstalled story called Dead Mans Switch, unfortunately feels undercooked and doesn't pull off the gritty superb story I expected in short your friend is killed and he hires you post death to find and kill the drek that killed him, I'm not gonna spoil anything but I thought the end villain was weak and uninteresting when they could've done something great with an established character from the beginning.I also shouldn't forget the DLC Dragonfall which in and of itself adds much more to the world and is it's own excellent piece of content adding new characters and more awesome story development.to test my new scoring system I give this 4 stars or a That's Grand LadLook forward to more reviews that hopefully don't sound too pretentious or crap

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Almost a perfect title.First off, the focus on the editor and the "module" approach to the campaign made me think of neverwinter nights (the first one). The fact that the game focused on being highly expandable and customizable made me more forgiving of the campaign's shortcomings.That being said, the game's pretty good, but still lacking. Some of it in terms of interface, some in terms of design (gameplay). Please note, I played on normal difficulty. The storyline is quaint, the visuals are detailed, and flow overall is smooth and enjoyable.1) With all the awesome artwork, the protagonist visuals were extremely boring, whatever look I had in mind for my hero was nowhere to be found in the portrait collection. I just gave up in the end and went with a whatever-approach.2) The chapter oriented campaign moves the story along nicely, but the linearity(sp?) of the game was disappointing, if you didn't manage your resources well, it's gone. This includes karma (xp).3) Moving around when there's no (immediate) combat in combat mode is a chore.4) Too many illusionary dialogue choices. Great, but acknowledging it was also an acknowledgement of it's extremely linear gameplay design (like combat, progression, resource allocation and game balance).Ultimately, I think if they fixed a few things, this title would have a been a true A+, and fans would be clamoring for a sequel like crazy. Unfortunately, in it's current state, it's a great experiment to the throwback that is the shadowrun RPG, but that's all.Maybe some mods would've helped, but the online presence for the game wasn't really there like other games neither. Hopefully they'll come out with some improvements in due time, if not a sequel.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												Well, where do I begin? I'll start by saying the developers really did the Shadowrun name a lot of justice with this release. Basically a party-based tactical RPG set in the cyberpunk world of Shadowrun. It really nails that futuristic, dystopian vibe I look for in this type of story. The gameplay is very enjoyable and you'll have a lot of fun leveling up your character in the main campaign. The options for character development and customization are pretty solid.My only complaint is - the main campaign is too short. Sure, you can get Dragonfall (the expansion) for another $15, and that is much bigger than the original campaign... but the stock capaign just sort of disappointed me. I also felt like it was a bit too linear. I was expecting a LOT more side-missions and stuff like that to help me develop my character before the endgame. I wouldn't let that deter you from buying the game, but I would set aside a little extra money for that expansion - first.Some would argue that the Workshop has player-made campaigns in case you get bored with the one that comes with the game, but I find it tedious sifting through mountains of crap to find a decent player-made campaign. Most of them suffer from the "Oh here's part 1....part 2.... part 3... And you have to download them all seperately.. oh but im not done with part 4, and I quit working on it cause I got bored.." It's just annoying. Same thing as most any game that comes with a toolkit... most of the player developed content is half-arsed.Anyway, I don't want the review to sound too negative because I actually did really enjoy the 20+ hours I've spent with Shadowrun Returns, and I'd recommend it to my friends - As long as they can afford to buy Dragonfall with it.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a game that could have been so much more. I love the setting and I think that for the most part they did a great job creating the world. However while it looks great it often feels like a set rather than a living city. Every place you go plays out more or less the same. Click the 2 or 3 people with talk symbols over their head, look for the 1 or 2 items that you can click on the map somewhere, fight a few guys, leave area. I like the world, I want to be able to go around and explore it and have a reason to do so. Even if it is just flavor text like "You see a grimy computer terminal, you can tell it has been well used" for example. I want to be able to go around and look at everything and just explore. The world graphics are great for the most part. There are a few things that really take me out of it like the quick loop of papers blowing in the wind over and over. The birds that fly off when you walk by are great though. My biggest gripe with the graphics is that the characters rarely look anything like their super awesome avatar pictures. I see a big orc character and when I walk up to him his avatar picture is of a skinny orc. The avatar picture I made for my guy is very thin but his character model is chunky with a way different head. Just pulls me out of the story. I like the story and I like the characters. It was well written and kept me interested. Even the loading screen text telling me about the place I was heading was great. I do wish that there was less travel here travel there though. I just get interested in an area and nope off to the next place. Maybe if rather than quick traveling everywhere there were inbetween areas with optional side stuff to do then all the traveling around would feel more cohesive. I have not played the official DLC mission yet so maybe they fixed some of my problems with it. Despite the problems, I do recommend the game if for nothing else other than the story and great setting. I really hope we get something more expansive in this universe someday though.
