Posted: May 10, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game I find hard to give excessive praise, but it's a game that I also find hard to dislike. When it comes down to it, it's a completely solid game, even if it's shallow. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it and feel fully satisfied with the experience, and I didn't have any trouble playing all the way through. There are certainly some notable flaws, however.Let's start with the story, since this game relies heavily on it's writing to motivate the player. The writing and characterization is good, I felt very absorbed in the universe, but the story itself is fairly lacking. It's a shame as well, it starts out great. You got a murder mystery with a lot of interesting faces dying to be talked to, with a few twists and turns here and there. The problem is that it just doesn't developed. It feels extremely rushed. The characters are lovable and relatable to the very end, but I started skipping through dialogue that dealt with the actual plot about 2/3rds through the game. It escalates in a comical direction, with an extremely weak and one-dimensional villian. It's extremely predictable, and just plain boring. The last stretch is so typical and lackluster that I had little to no investment in the actual plight, I just wanted to see if the characters would drop some more interesting backstory about themselves. It gave me closure, but it's not memorable at all. It's just too bad, the beginning was really good, but the plot started going so fast in such a linear direction that it forgot to flesh itself out, leaving some questions unanswered and plot points underdeveloped. It got the job done, but I was hoping for more.Where the game really shines are the characters and their own personal issues. Almost all the staple characters have their own personal motives and vendettas, and I was interested in all their stories. I enjoyed going back to base and talking to every single one of them that were willing to open their mouths. The game does a fantastic job of setting up this belonging feeling, that you're part of this organization of runners. Although, as I stated before, as the game escalates it leaves behind this deep characterization in order to fawn over its own hilariously absurd and out-of-place world-threatening dilemma.The combat is serviceable. It's ultimately shallow and linear, there isn't a lot of variation or depth, and there are some balance issues. But it's still fun, you get to characterize some characters simply by their fighting styles. It's too easy as well, but not game-ruiningly so. It's fun, if you really like X-COM-like turn based combat, you'll probably enjoy it if you can stand it being a tad shallow.The game is overall fun, I would recommend it. It doesn't really have any offending flaws, it just doesn't quite reach the large potential it could've. It's not particularly memorable, but it's enjoyable. I would wait for a sale, but when the price is suitable to you, I'd say to go for it just to get immersed in the world.

Posted: October 21, 2014
												The game is not perfect. There are some real problems with it, but, despite that, I'd still recommend it to anyone who's thinking of giving it a chance. Gameplay is linear and there are some inherent flaws in the design, for instance the tendency of attacks to roll Missed despite your actual stats. If I did a count, I'm fairly sure the number of times the characters missed surpass the times they actually land a hit. It got ridiculous to the point that I'd get misses 3 times in a row at point blank range. This makes for very frustrating play especially at the endgame portion. There's also an impression of unbalanced design considering that certain builds came off more useful than others. Party members builds seem to have no impact either outside of battles and a certain plot mission. I could have a decker in my party but not be able to do any side decking other than what was neccesary to move the game forward, it made party build up rather pointless and lackluster. On the upside, it's rather well-written and the characters in-game are rather engaging and interesting. I'm not too familiar with the Shadowrun tabletop but I am a fan of the setting. You can see much effort has gone into the game and the end result is rather polished. The game is, overall, a good effort from an indie developer and while not great, is a decent experience and has lots of potential for the future.

Posted: September 28, 2013
The GoodFor me the biggest best part about this game is that it's Shadowrun, and I love Shadowrun.  And I mean this is actual, proper SR too, not like some of the dribble that's carried the SR name in the past.  It's made by some of the folks who created SR in the first place, and it definitely shows by how deeply entwined with the actual lore it is.  If you like - or, like me, love - SR, you owe it to yourself to get this game.But that's not all!  The writing is top notch, with great characters and a great story with lots of neat twists and turns.  The art is beautiful, making the game look like a painting come to life.  And the turn-based tactical combat - while not exactly original - is very well-executed and fun to play.Further, it's set up so you can make your own campaigns, which is pretty dang cool in my book.The BadThough I understood pretty much everything that was going on in the story, understanding almost every reference and technical term that came flying my way, I'm not entirely certain it would be nearly as accessible for anyone who doesn't already know the SR rulebooks forwards and backwards or is at least somewhat familiar with the setting.  This may be a foundless fear, but I figure I should mention it just in case.Character stats were greatly simplified from the original systems, and even compared to at least one of the previous SR video games, which I do understand to a degree.  But I feel they may have simplified a little bit too much, and would have welcomed a little more depth.  That may be just me being a rules lawyer, tho'.OverallIf my comments above don't speak plainly enough for themselves, I don't really have much bad to say about this game, but I fully realize that that might simply be my own pro-Shadowrun bias.  The game does have its faults, and I do wish it had a bit more depth than it does, but overall I feel that its pros far outweigh its cons, so I feel very confident in recommending it to folks.  And if you can, play the SNES and Genesis games first!

Posted: July 15, 2014
												I've never played the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, those aren't my bag. I did love the Shadowrun game on SNES that I played as a kid. This game brings a good blend of nostaglia for that previous title in a similar, but updated look, but it definitely also takes advantage of lessons learned in gaming in the intervening years. Combat in both the real world and while dekking is intuitive and easy to grasp. There are a number of skill tree options to monkey with, but not so many as to require a spreadsheet. Posted: July 31, 2014
												The Dead Man's Switch(DMS) campaign is forgettable and is only notable for having an annoying enemy that can only be killed with a cumbersome mechanic. There are a handful of interesting interactions during DMS but overall its honestly not worth playing through and can be easily skipped.Dragonfall(DF), on the other hand, is awesome and is filled with characters and scenarios that are as imaginative, well written,  and worth exploring as some of the best RPGs that I have ever played. DF additionally contains a much better structure than DMS, by that I mean rather than having a linear quest with hardly any side branches that you undertake with some flavorless NPCs, DF tasks you with a central goal and allows you to lead a team of fairly unique characters along a questline that has scores of opportunity to explore more of the world of Shadowrun. I enjoyed the vast majority of my time with DF, save for the hacking bits (called decking in this universe), and some later game fights with some annoyingly powerful enemies. Altough, I wholeheartedly recommend DF, Its a shame that you have to buy both to play DF but since thats the case I would advise that you buy the campaigns at a reduced cost and skip DMS.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												A fine game, however...There are many differences between a video game RPG and a tabletop RPG run by a GM. A video game RPG we expect certain conventions: random battles to raise XP, walking around a fixed location until we're ready to proceed with the story, and freedom to explore the entire world to a certain point.In a tabletop RPG, it's almost the opposite: random battles are tedious and most battles are relevant to the plot in some way, you're expected to keep to a timetable to follow the plot, and you probably won't revisit areas you've already visited except for a 'safe house' or two.What we have here is a video game RPG that acts like, plays like, and runs like a tabletop RPG! There are no random battles, and world exploration is very limited. Side quests are (generally) done immediately when you get them or not at all. There are no obvious good/bad dialogue choices that alter an unseen scale that judges your 'morality'. What we instead have is a very intriguing, atmosphere-driven game with a tightly-focused plot and tactical combat which feels very tabletop-ish.I enjoy Shadowrun, but I've also played the tabletop RPG and enjoy the setting. A person who buys this expecting something like a Bioware rpg or Skyrim is going to be very disappointed. But if you're willing to give it a chance, the atmosphere and writing will immerse you easily.And there's a game editor. So you can probably make your own game, if you think you could do better.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ah Shadowrun, I'll start off by saying this: If you're into the Shadowrun universe and games like UFO: XCOM, then chances are that you'll really like Shadowrun returns.That said, I do have some issues with the game. First and foremost, the music gets grading and tiresome fast. I've played the game for 9 hours and I had to turn the music off, they were clearly aiming for a dark electronic ambience and they do achieve it, but there are simply not enough tunes and a few of them simply sound too much alike.A second point that I feel must be made, is the fact that the game has cut a lot of corners when making the jump from pen & paper to video game. Shadowrun has always aimed for high realism, but this requires a lot of rules and a lot of depth. I understand that they had to cut a lot of these rules because otherwise nobody would've been able to play the game without 2 hours of tutorial, if not more.Third point, there are some issues when trying to select certain points to move to in the grid, so I suggest activating the double-click feature, which ends the miss clicks.Fourth point, the save system blows balls. The game will auto-save whenever you enter a new scene, but you are unable to manually save, this means that if you fail, you have to start all over from the very beginning of the scene, this can be especially tiresome if the encounter is 30 minutes long or you just leveled up before you died.Fifth point is mostly mechanical, but I still feel  it should be mentioned. There's an issue with scripted events that can ♥♥♥♥ you over; I'll try to explain it: When you move a character through a door and towards cover, the character will stop because and a little dialogue will play. Afterwards your character will be stuck where the dialogue started and if you're out of actions for said character, this can lead to them recieving a lead sandwich. Couple this with the fact that you're unnable to resurrect your main character if his HP hits zero and you can get rather frustrated. This wouldn't be half bad, but when you can resurrect side characters after they hit zero HP it just seems rather silly.And finally always remember:Watch your back. Shoot straight. Conserve ammo. And never, ever, cut a deal with a dragon.

You can approach situations through many different ways. You will enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Cyberpunk is a genre as much built on the atmosphere as it is on the technology. Everyone has that formative memory of the giant advertisements and smog-belching smokestacks in Blade Runner, Some games make the mistake of keeping the slums out of the cyberpunk, but Shadowrun Returns has the formula down just right: "high tech, low life." The game is a fun return to an earlier era for me, given my experience with the tabletop game - but the experience is fluid and accurate, reminding me of so many times spent around a table being suspicious about your Fixer or the latest contact you made.The gameplay can be somewhat halting and awkward at times - a concession to make in order to accommodate the system itself, of course - but it doesn't diminish the enjoyment of this authentic cyberpunk game. Combat is strategic, if somewhat sparse on detail, and emphasises the differences in roles within the party itself. The decking is sadly quite anaemic compared to the tabletop world, a blue-gridlines re-creation of the combat systems, with Agents standing in for Spirits, and spells replaced with Decker attacks. Nonetheless, it rounds out the flavour of the game well.If you're looking for an engaging Cyberpunk story, with a dash of magic and plenty of political intrigue and conspiracy, I highly recommend Shadowrun Returns.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												It's been a while since I last played a classic, turn-based RPG - and when I say a while, I mean the likes of Forgotten Isles. So picking up this game was quite refreshing for me since most titles nowadays are all high energy ball-busting action. It would also be right to say that I don't have past references to any other Shadowrun titles, so my impressions here are purely stand-alone.Putting it simply - I'm quite impressed. Let me get to some of the simple points that make this title a gem:Writing: The narrative is well written albeit some "street" language that sometimes sticks out badly. The sights and sounds (as though these were not enough) of apocalyptic Seattle is well supported by transition build ups and some witty dialogue.Role-playing Mechanics: The game mechanics builds its own simple character customization. You only really get to build your main protagonist via a simple characteristics points system. You simply have to progress through the story to earn your points and design a character from a set number of characteristics. The game builds on several archetypes but does not restrict a player into any cookie-cutter format. (Check out the Nephilim Network to get some quirky combination inspirations.)Setting: Explore an apocalyptic Seattle teeming with classic RPG lore races, armed to the teeth with Guns, Cybernetics and Magic. Timelessness is often a great appeal to any story, and this title just has the right mix.Art and Music: While being somewhat leaning towards cartoon-like, the world of Shadowrun Returns is beautifully crafted. The city sprawls are rich in detail. On the one hand you will be running around streets blaring with neon signs and shop fronts. But on another, you get to traverse dark alleys, dimly lit halls of medical facilities and cult complexes to uncover the mystery that drives the campaign. This is supported by pulses of techno music transitioning into eerie fantasy sequences. Of course the game is not without its faults. While dialogue and the story telling are well written, character focus seems to be lacking since most often than not you will be running around the sprawl with game-generated Shadow Runners. True, there are some key NPCs that you get to interact with but the times can be very short and too far in between for such a short campaign. Inventory system may need a bit of a re-work but nothing too major to murder the experience. I've read some concerns about saving games but I've hardly found it an issue - so maybe they have fixed this one already. My only suggestion really right now is you might want to try starting a game at a much higher difficulty level. I'm currently running with a Decker at the moment in Normal setting, and it seems like a cake walk - what more if you go for the more heavy hitting classes? By no means is the game perfect - it has a few rough edges but it definitely delivers the merchandise well. If you feel like slowing down a bit, go out of the usual, this read & click title might do the thing for you.

Which is going to be my final review for this game.  Shadow Run: Returns... Smart.

												Shadowrun. I picked up the Pen and Paper RPG when I was younger. Sadly it took years before finding a group to play it. Luckly around my University years I found a decent group of people and we are gaming since than. I am an hardcore fan so probably my Review could be a bit biased. Frist of all I strongly suggest to read a bit before gaming. Just the "Primer" which is a small guide\introduction to the World of Shadowrun available from the site Shadowrun Universe (official site for all things related to Shadowrun). Once you have the Primer you can have a good idea of what to expect from the Setting. I know that at a frist glance it looks strange maybe even too much but trust me it is awesome. The more you will dig the better it will get, specially if you start to read the various RPG manuals and novels. If you liked the setting buy this game. The basic Campaign included in Shadowrun Returns is a classic. If you never rped or played Shadowrun (I am mostly referring to SNES and GENESIS Games) this is a wonderfull start. The narration is set in 2050s which is a very cool period for Shadowrun (keep in mind that in the current RP Setting the time is around 2075) and it is based on some of the hottest plots of that period. The game is a basic Turn Based Combat with RP elements in the form of dialogues where the various options depends on which skill you have. Back when it was just published the Game lacked few things like save anywhere option. Luckly this was fixed up in the 1st DLC Dragonfall. Dragonfall is even better than the basic game. The Devs listened to us Players and fixed few things and I dare to say even took inspiration from some of UGC - User generated Content (More of this later). Dragonfall can look a bit boring at the start with the logic of "Do a Run, get back and run again" (Run is a work, a mission in Shadowrun) but the Narration, the Plot goes always up till its end. In Dragonfall I was not impressed by the first Runs but nearby the end I could not stop to see how this Story was going to end. The only negative side of both Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall is that you can not manage your NPCs. You can select who can help you in a Run but you do not have any kind of control on their Skills and how they improve. Probably this will be fixed in future DLCs. If the basic game and the DLC are not enough there are UGCs. Shadowrun Community is very active and Devs select from time to time some UCG to play just to show up how much it is good. There are a lot of good Artist out there who are working on big UCG like remakes of SNES and Genesis Shadowrun Games. I strongly suggest to take a loot at "Shadowrun Unlimited". I hope all of this makes sense. In any case, if you start to play and dig into the Shadows of Shadowrun remember: "Shoot straight, conserve your ammo and never make a deal with a Dragon".

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Ive been fan of the Shadowrun ever since i first played on the Genesis and Snes and was glad to see a new iteration of it come out. The game still follows all of it rules and has a great look and story that fits the Shadowrun world great.While I still do recommend the game to fans of the Shadowrun world, it does have some really bad bugs / glitches still and wouldnt recommend it unless you love the shadowrun series.Fans of the first two fallout games might find some interest in this title as well since the combat sytem is set up very similar,although a  buggy (almost feels incomplete) version of it.Just an example of a few combat bugs to give people an idea of what thier getting into.A bug for shamans where when you summon a spirit which will cause the combat system to break and not be able to use or select any of characters during youre turn and basicly forcing you to forfeit the rest of your turn which will most likely cause a death of one of your runners.Another bug is where and enemy attacking you will shoot you through walls while you not only cannot shoot because of line sight issue and wont be able to even see the enemy untill you run around the wall.A bug where when you try to heal your drone out of combat it will say immune not heal your drone and use a repair kit.So I would say a good game for the price if your a fan of the series but if not I would probaly skip over this one.

Totally surprised me in a good way and extended the gameplay by a couple of hours. Looking forward to replaying as a different spec character to see if there are any other twists that I missed. Posted: May 11, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns lives somewhere between a point-and-click adventure and a tactical RPG like XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but the lack of voice acting and completely linear plotline makes everything seem unfinished. However, once you accept the forced march through story, it's actually pretty well-written and the combat is fun. Just expect everything to be a dime short of a dollar--this game has all the hallmarks of a project that ran out of money too soon. However, since this game is modular and easily modded (http://www.nexusmods.com/shadowrunreturns), it may improve over time.The first story module that comes with the game, Dead Man's Switch, is not quite as interesting as the first DLC module: Dragonfall.TL;DR: If you enjoy turn-based, three-quarter RPGs such as Fallout 2 and Baldur's Gate 2, you may enjoy this one, especially if it's in the $5-10 range.

What I can tell you is that whatever is in the game, works nicely in my opinion.Warning - it's not "3D" in the sense that you can't rotate camera around. It really plays like the old games mentioned above - 1 fixed perspective only. What you can do is zoom in and out, that's it. The main campaign is pretty interesting, and a minor plot twist (ok I didn't see it coming), but the best thing about this is that there is an EDITOR included! That means users are free to create and share (or "mod") this game. I am sure, in time, the mods will rival that of Skyrim :)

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Shadowrun for me is filled with fond memories of tabletop gaming, and lazy weekends with people too clever by half for their own good. Thankfullly, that core is there, and the story they bundle with it is solid. The problem however, lies with the overall brevity of the content given. There are remarkable storytellers out there who have written, and continue to write stories in the setting, [Do browse the UGC for the game!] but the package as a whole for the average gamer may be a little underwhelming. Mechanically, the pieces are functional, and the experience in terms of actual gameplay is solid enough, but the pace of action and the lack of diversity in its approach may not seem the divine ambrosia to all. X-Com would be a fair parallel to make for the way the gameplay unfolds in action sequences. Character development allows for specilization, and divesification both, but can feel stiflingly slow compared to the glut of typical loot-and-shoot games. For players who like the idea of being able to poke a few buttons thoughtlessly, toss another point into "strength" and move on to the next fight, the system may prove unsatisfying. For players who constantly look at old saves and think "What if I tried it with _____ build?" the depth of variety allowed is a welcome change of pace.Graphically, there is a sense of "days gone by", I personally found myself filled with nostalgia for the classics. The atmosphere is there, in all its dirty, decayed charm, and the experience as a whole is such that no single part of the presentation is a jarring disconnect from the rest. At its core, it holds true to the experiences I remember as a tabletop gamer. I enjoyed and continue to enjoy it and do not regret the purchase.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												A fine game, however...There are many differences between a video game RPG and a tabletop RPG run by a GM. A video game RPG we expect certain conventions: random battles to raise XP, walking around a fixed location until we're ready to proceed with the story, and freedom to explore the entire world to a certain point.In a tabletop RPG, it's almost the opposite: random battles are tedious and most battles are relevant to the plot in some way, you're expected to keep to a timetable to follow the plot, and you probably won't revisit areas you've already visited except for a 'safe house' or two.What we have here is a video game RPG that acts like, plays like, and runs like a tabletop RPG! There are no random battles, and world exploration is very limited. Side quests are (generally) done immediately when you get them or not at all. There are no obvious good/bad dialogue choices that alter an unseen scale that judges your 'morality'. What we instead have is a very intriguing, atmosphere-driven game with a tightly-focused plot and tactical combat which feels very tabletop-ish.I enjoy Shadowrun, but I've also played the tabletop RPG and enjoy the setting. A person who buys this expecting something like a Bioware rpg or Skyrim is going to be very disappointed. But if you're willing to give it a chance, the atmosphere and writing will immerse you easily.And there's a game editor. So you can probably make your own game, if you think you could do better.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ah Shadowrun, I'll start off by saying this: If you're into the Shadowrun universe and games like UFO: XCOM, then chances are that you'll really like Shadowrun returns.That said, I do have some issues with the game. First and foremost, the music gets grading and tiresome fast. I've played the game for 9 hours and I had to turn the music off, they were clearly aiming for a dark electronic ambience and they do achieve it, but there are simply not enough tunes and a few of them simply sound too much alike.A second point that I feel must be made, is the fact that the game has cut a lot of corners when making the jump from pen & paper to video game. Shadowrun has always aimed for high realism, but this requires a lot of rules and a lot of depth. I understand that they had to cut a lot of these rules because otherwise nobody would've been able to play the game without 2 hours of tutorial, if not more.Third point, there are some issues when trying to select certain points to move to in the grid, so I suggest activating the double-click feature, which ends the miss clicks.Fourth point, the save system blows balls. The game will auto-save whenever you enter a new scene, but you are unable to manually save, this means that if you fail, you have to start all over from the very beginning of the scene, this can be especially tiresome if the encounter is 30 minutes long or you just leveled up before you died.Fifth point is mostly mechanical, but I still feel  it should be mentioned. There's an issue with scripted events that can ♥♥♥♥ you over; I'll try to explain it: When you move a character through a door and towards cover, the character will stop because and a little dialogue will play. Afterwards your character will be stuck where the dialogue started and if you're out of actions for said character, this can lead to them recieving a lead sandwich. Couple this with the fact that you're unnable to resurrect your main character if his HP hits zero and you can get rather frustrated. This wouldn't be half bad, but when you can resurrect side characters after they hit zero HP it just seems rather silly.And finally always remember:Watch your back. Shoot straight. Conserve ammo. And never, ever, cut a deal with a dragon.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												First, an explaination: When you buy SHADOWRUN RETURNS, you get one campaign - "Deadman's Trigger." It's a solid introduction to the gameplay and story world. There's one additional campaign for sale from the studio - "Dragonfall," which also adds some new items and gameplay functionality. Additionally, the game comes with a campaign editor, allowing you to create your own or download campaigns from others on Steam Workshop.In terms of gameplay, SR is basically a glorified point-and-click adventure, with XCOM-style turn-based combat added in. The combat is just solid enough to feel worthwhile, but otherwise this is the kind of game that lives or dies on the quality of the writing. Thankfully, both campaigns present some of the best character development and story writing I've seen in a videogame. Is it high-literature? No, but it's incredibly solid pulp-fiction and well worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Cyberpunk is a genre as much built on the atmosphere as it is on the technology. Everyone has that formative memory of the giant advertisements and smog-belching smokestacks in Blade Runner, Some games make the mistake of keeping the slums out of the cyberpunk, but Shadowrun Returns has the formula down just right: "high tech, low life." The game is a fun return to an earlier era for me, given my experience with the tabletop game - but the experience is fluid and accurate, reminding me of so many times spent around a table being suspicious about your Fixer or the latest contact you made.The gameplay can be somewhat halting and awkward at times - a concession to make in order to accommodate the system itself, of course - but it doesn't diminish the enjoyment of this authentic cyberpunk game. Combat is strategic, if somewhat sparse on detail, and emphasises the differences in roles within the party itself. The decking is sadly quite anaemic compared to the tabletop world, a blue-gridlines re-creation of the combat systems, with Agents standing in for Spirits, and spells replaced with Decker attacks. Nonetheless, it rounds out the flavour of the game well.If you're looking for an engaging Cyberpunk story, with a dash of magic and plenty of political intrigue and conspiracy, I highly recommend Shadowrun Returns.

Posted: May 4, 2014
												If you liked the table top game, or any table top game... then buy this game.  The graphics are...ok... the gameplay is good... but the story is fantastic.  It felt simultaneously home grown and professionally constructed. I felt like I was at a table game, participating in one of the mostl finely constructed stories I had ever played.  It starts small, with a seemingly inocuous event and ends huge.  The story is a work of art.  And speaking of works of art...  The mod tool is one as well.  Included is a single tool with which to build your own stories. It's powerful, easy (enough) to use, the tutorial videos are great, and it includes tons of assets. All in all it's really smart.  Which is going to be my final review for this game.  Shadow Run: Returns... Smart.

Posted: April 30, 2014
												I must admit that I purchased this game with a bit of trepidation.  Shadowrun on the SNES was one of my favorite gaming experiences of my youth.  It was so unique compared to the gaming experiences I had up to that point.  I caught the game on sale and after playing I am absolutely floored by how great this game is.  The storyline had me reeled in.  The combat was a blast, just like back on my old SNES.  Even with 6 character archetypes to choose from, there is still an immense amount of customization that allows you to find your own playstyle.  Hats off to the dev team for a well polished, enjoyable experience with plenty of new features that still pulls off a nice tip of the hat to the old SNES classic.  This game is a must play.

												Awesome artstyle. Awesome theme. Awesome IP. Gameplay leaves a little to be desired. Posted: May 6, 2014
												The classic 80s-90s vision of the cyberpunk future of the Shadowrun world is done serious justice by this game.  The art style and game mechanics and story all do a great job of pulling you into it even though there is no voice acting (prepare for a lot of reading).The turn based combat is slow paced but satisfying.  The character skill and equipment system is pretty robust.  So, there's definately room for replay variety but it would probably be boring to play through more than a couple times.  If you're a veteran of turn based combat games, I would suggest playing on a high difficulty.  I played the default normal setting and for the most part, combat was way too easy.All in all a pretty lesurely game and a bit nostalgic.  Keeping in mind how SR is setup more as a gaming platfom with systems in place for users to create their own stories and content, the lack of niceties like voice acting, variety of music and so on is forgivable.  This was definately worth the $4.99 I paid for it on Steam sale.

The characters are great, the story is interesting, the decisions are difficult, and although the "epilogue" is a little weak, the overall ending was solid. Posted: June 24, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is so damn likable that it's easy to overlook how mediocre it can be. The user interface is cumbersome and frequently doesn't let you do what you'd expect it would. It's janky in the way that you remember crusty old PC games used to be, except it's not charming by today's standards. The default campaign: Dead Man's Switch is unflinchingly linear and the game has some odd hitching issues. But it's ****ing cyberpunk! Despite the fact that the story goes off the rails in a rather magnificent way, Shadowrun Returns stays true to the Gibson-esque tone that you want from a cyberpunk RPG and more to the point, a sequel to the original Shadowrun. The writing is what you want from a Shadowrun game. The combat is ersatz-XCOM Enemy Unknown. I'd have a hard time calling Shadowrun Returns great, but if you're as starved as I am for its specific brand of dystopia, it's a decent fix.

Posted: May 10, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game I find hard to give excessive praise, but it's a game that I also find hard to dislike. When it comes down to it, it's a completely solid game, even if it's shallow. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it and feel fully satisfied with the experience, and I didn't have any trouble playing all the way through. There are certainly some notable flaws, however.Let's start with the story, since this game relies heavily on it's writing to motivate the player. The writing and characterization is good, I felt very absorbed in the universe, but the story itself is fairly lacking. It's a shame as well, it starts out great. You got a murder mystery with a lot of interesting faces dying to be talked to, with a few twists and turns here and there. The problem is that it just doesn't developed. It feels extremely rushed. The characters are lovable and relatable to the very end, but I started skipping through dialogue that dealt with the actual plot about 2/3rds through the game. It escalates in a comical direction, with an extremely weak and one-dimensional villian. It's extremely predictable, and just plain boring. The last stretch is so typical and lackluster that I had little to no investment in the actual plight, I just wanted to see if the characters would drop some more interesting backstory about themselves. It gave me closure, but it's not memorable at all. It's just too bad, the beginning was really good, but the plot started going so fast in such a linear direction that it forgot to flesh itself out, leaving some questions unanswered and plot points underdeveloped. It got the job done, but I was hoping for more.Where the game really shines are the characters and their own personal issues. Almost all the staple characters have their own personal motives and vendettas, and I was interested in all their stories. I enjoyed going back to base and talking to every single one of them that were willing to open their mouths. The game does a fantastic job of setting up this belonging feeling, that you're part of this organization of runners. Although, as I stated before, as the game escalates it leaves behind this deep characterization in order to fawn over its own hilariously absurd and out-of-place world-threatening dilemma.The combat is serviceable. It's ultimately shallow and linear, there isn't a lot of variation or depth, and there are some balance issues. But it's still fun, you get to characterize some characters simply by their fighting styles. It's too easy as well, but not game-ruiningly so. It's fun, if you really like X-COM-like turn based combat, you'll probably enjoy it if you can stand it being a tad shallow.The game is overall fun, I would recommend it. It doesn't really have any offending flaws, it just doesn't quite reach the large potential it could've. It's not particularly memorable, but it's enjoyable. I would wait for a sale, but when the price is suitable to you, I'd say to go for it just to get immersed in the world.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												I'm done with "Dead Man's Switch" and a few missions into "Dragonfall."tl,dr: Don't buy the game unless you buy Dragonfall with it.The combat is a bit simple, though turning up the difficulty helps immensely to provide a more engaging, complicated experience. It certainly doesn't feel like the fluidity one finds in a real tabletop game session, but then, to expect that from a computer game is usually folly.The heart, and meat, of the game is, rather, in its dialogue and world. For clarity, don't expect voice acting and animated cutscenes. It's more in the mein of the aging RPGs like Baldur's Gate, but even less frilly. Characters are rendered convincingly, and with their own authorial voices. The writing never worse than "pretty good."But where Dead Man's Switch (the base campaign) never gets far above pretty good, and maintains a dreary linearity at all times, Dragonfall excels. Dragonfall's characters and story are much more believably written, the world more flavorful, and the story less full of deus ex machina windfalls.Where Dead Man's Switch feels like a saturday morning cartoon, Dragonfall is more like a well-written, high-budget film. I might watch both, but you can be sure I'd much rather watch the latter.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Hoy Chummers.Shadowrun Returns takes you through a solid introduction to the cyberpunk world of shadowrun where classic fantasy, (sword and sorcery) meets cyber enhanced super soldiers.  When I first saw that this game was going to be done I was afraid another company was going to screw it up the way Microsoft did when they failed making another game trying to use the Shadowrun name.    Thankfully this is not the case.  The first story deadman switch is a good solid introduction to the world of being a gun for hire.  While the story is largly liniar the additional content added by players adds vast replayability to the original quest and provides a huge amount of additional content. Dragonfall adds several more hours and more options for play as well.  Another thing that has been nice is that many of the bugs that are/were in this have been fixed.  So many products are released to die where this game has been continually updated to ensure problems when found are solved.  For RPG fans or those who remember playing one of the many table top cyberpunk games,  this is a great game worth every penny.

Posted: July 8, 2014
Pros The Cyberpunk-meets-Fantasy-Magic set in the real-world near-future aesthetic is great. The way the stats are balanced leaves the class-race combos open, and encourages exploration of different options/layouts. I just wish there was a way to respecc. Maybe there is later in the game. I love the tactical, turn-based combat.Cons The single angle of the camera gets a little annoying in combat; e.g. if you've got an ally standing directly beneath/infront of an enemy, you can accidentally target your ally because their hitbox overlaps the enemy's. If I could rotate the camera to a different angle, that'd solve my biggest gripe with the game The first campaign (Dead Man's Switch) is interesting, but rather slow-paced. Haven't tried the expansion campgain or any of the user generated content yet.All in all, it's a fun tactical, turn-based, text-driven RPG. The character creation options are pretty robust -- not so much in terms of appearances, but in terms of class selection and creation. It's easy to start out with one of the game's premade archetypes and expand out into other disciplines as you get the feel for the game, or to just stick with a single discipline. I don't know how well either works comparatively because I haven't played long enough. The story of the first campaign moves a little slow; they do a good job of tying the tutorial stuff into the story without breaking immersion, but that's kind of what slows it down.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												I am a big fan of table top RPGs but I was never into Shadowrun. I think Shadowrun returns is an excellent game in that it not only made me interested in trying Shadowrun the table top setting, but it was also an isometric view RPG when there have been so few. Games like Baulder's gate kick♥♥♥♥♥but so few are made. Shadowrun Returns not only delivered but offered a great price and the option for unlimited new content. I would recommend that the world become more open ended and that dialogue choices have more impact on the gameplay. Without those the game feels like a rail-road with no real consequences and that harms emersion. The good outweighs the bad and if this is just a start I can't wait to see what happens next. I will be paying attention to these guys for a while :)

Posted: May 25, 2014
												If you're a fan of noir-style stories with twists and turns, tactical turn-based combat, or a fan of the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, this is probably a solid game for you. Played through "Dead Man's Switch" in about 10 hours. Good balance of exploration, dialogue, and combat. There were some things missing, though; the act of hiring teammates was cool, but you never interacted with them, which kind of sucked (some parts in the game led me to believe that it was originally there, but was cut). I also felt like my dialogue choices meant nothing to the outcome of the game, which pretty much goes against how tabletop RPGs work. Also, I think the Dragonfall DLC should be free, but I suppose I'm against paid DLC in general. Should you pay full price for this game? Yeah, I guess so. I'd give it a solid 8/10.

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Shadowrun for me is filled with fond memories of tabletop gaming, and lazy weekends with people too clever by half for their own good. Thankfullly, that core is there, and the story they bundle with it is solid. The problem however, lies with the overall brevity of the content given. There are remarkable storytellers out there who have written, and continue to write stories in the setting, [Do browse the UGC for the game!] but the package as a whole for the average gamer may be a little underwhelming. Mechanically, the pieces are functional, and the experience in terms of actual gameplay is solid enough, but the pace of action and the lack of diversity in its approach may not seem the divine ambrosia to all. X-Com would be a fair parallel to make for the way the gameplay unfolds in action sequences. Character development allows for specilization, and divesification both, but can feel stiflingly slow compared to the glut of typical loot-and-shoot games. For players who like the idea of being able to poke a few buttons thoughtlessly, toss another point into "strength" and move on to the next fight, the system may prove unsatisfying. For players who constantly look at old saves and think "What if I tried it with _____ build?" the depth of variety allowed is a welcome change of pace.Graphically, there is a sense of "days gone by", I personally found myself filled with nostalgia for the classics. The atmosphere is there, in all its dirty, decayed charm, and the experience as a whole is such that no single part of the presentation is a jarring disconnect from the rest. At its core, it holds true to the experiences I remember as a tabletop gamer. I enjoyed and continue to enjoy it and do not regret the purchase.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun. I picked up the Pen and Paper RPG when I was younger. Sadly it took years before finding a group to play it. Luckly around my University years I found a decent group of people and we are gaming since than. I am an hardcore fan so probably my Review could be a bit biased. Frist of all I strongly suggest to read a bit before gaming. Just the "Primer" which is a small guide\introduction to the World of Shadowrun available from the site Shadowrun Universe (official site for all things related to Shadowrun). Once you have the Primer you can have a good idea of what to expect from the Setting. I know that at a frist glance it looks strange maybe even too much but trust me it is awesome. The more you will dig the better it will get, specially if you start to read the various RPG manuals and novels. If you liked the setting buy this game. The basic Campaign included in Shadowrun Returns is a classic. If you never rped or played Shadowrun (I am mostly referring to SNES and GENESIS Games) this is a wonderfull start. The narration is set in 2050s which is a very cool period for Shadowrun (keep in mind that in the current RP Setting the time is around 2075) and it is based on some of the hottest plots of that period. The game is a basic Turn Based Combat with RP elements in the form of dialogues where the various options depends on which skill you have. Back when it was just published the Game lacked few things like save anywhere option. Luckly this was fixed up in the 1st DLC Dragonfall. Dragonfall is even better than the basic game. The Devs listened to us Players and fixed few things and I dare to say even took inspiration from some of UGC - User generated Content (More of this later). Dragonfall can look a bit boring at the start with the logic of "Do a Run, get back and run again" (Run is a work, a mission in Shadowrun) but the Narration, the Plot goes always up till its end. In Dragonfall I was not impressed by the first Runs but nearby the end I could not stop to see how this Story was going to end. The only negative side of both Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall is that you can not manage your NPCs. You can select who can help you in a Run but you do not have any kind of control on their Skills and how they improve. Probably this will be fixed in future DLCs. If the basic game and the DLC are not enough there are UGCs. Shadowrun Community is very active and Devs select from time to time some UCG to play just to show up how much it is good. There are a lot of good Artist out there who are working on big UCG like remakes of SNES and Genesis Shadowrun Games. I strongly suggest to take a loot at "Shadowrun Unlimited". I hope all of this makes sense. In any case, if you start to play and dig into the Shadows of Shadowrun remember: "Shoot straight, conserve your ammo and never make a deal with a Dragon".

Posted: March 30, 2014
												If you're a fan of the old-school turn-based games, you'll enjoy this one.  If you're a fan of coorporate run futuristic dystopias, you'll enjoy this game.  If you're a fan of the table-top game that this is based on, you'll enjoy this game.The strongest point of this game is it's story.  The writing is fantastic and the world is immersive.  Walking into this world knowing almost nothing about it, the game gives you plenty of story to build off of.  Each of the characters feel like people and even the slang used in the game that's unique to the world is easy to understand, even for someone who has never came into contact with it before.The artwork for the game is superb.  The game combines 3-D and 2-D elements in the form of painted portraits for most NPCs and the 3-D element of game play.  The world itself isn't very interactable, but it isn't necessary.The game play can get very static very fast, especially with combat.  Once you figure out that the AI is going to react certain ways and the trick to not getting your face blown off, it can get dull quickly.  It's absolutely worth finishing the game, however, as the story is fantastic.If you're a fan of Baulder's Gate, this game will remind you of it in its play style.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Some 18 years removed from the cult following success of the arcade style, cartridge era rpg shadowrun games.  This title puts a new face on a Gen-X classic.  Not to say it is a remake, although it does incorporate some of the characters i.e. Jake and a few others.  This (Dead mans switch) is a brand new story set a few years after the events we played out back in the mid-1990's.  The graphics may not be state of the art and the over all game play is somewhat cell phone app lvl.  However it is LOADS of fun.  Highly addictive and the replay value is surprisingly high although I personally feel that they could have spent a bit more time on programming the sub-missions instead of over-dramatizing the whole wanna-be detective angle which is already well implied.  To sum up.  This is Shadowrun the way it was MEANT to be as a video game.  Not great.  Nor is it trying to be anything more than advertised.  If you want to run the shadows instead of just reading about it in yet another dusty but well written novel.  Then here is your interactive 'BTL' of choice.  True nuff!Jim Lost4daze1 @Yahoo.com

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Shadowrun returns is a much-anticipated return to from for the often-maligned Shadowrun videogame series.  After the absurdly bad adaption as a first-person shooter under Microsoft's ageis, this game returns to the series' roots as a delightfully atmospheric adventure game.  Tactical turn-based squad combat is blended deliciously with punchy storytelling in the vibrant if dark and gritty 6th World.Really, I can't recommend this game any more highly.  Everything from the music, to the art, to the writing was nigh perfect.  As someone with over two decades of experience with the setting, getting to see stories well told in it was heartening, especially when familiar characters get to cameo.A solid purchase, with no regrets.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												Highly reccomended, especially if you remember the paper n' pencil, SNES or Genesis games.  Turn based combat, but the use of cover makes for good strategy.  AI tends to target the player, and it's one of those 'if the player goes down you lose, regardless if someone could save said player' which is a stupid bit of design that's been accepted as industry standard.WARNING:  This is NOT a hand-holder, you CAN screw your build, and grinding is NOT an option.  Cash is scarce.  You must build practically, specializing in three areas:  Offence, primary role (this may be the same thing) and Survivability.  Think Fallout 1 & 2:  You can't do everything.  Thankfully, most of the time you can hire the help to do it for you.There's a few bugs here and there, and the system could use a bit of polish.  Firearms specialists feel a bit overpowered compared to mages, but make no mistake:  magic is invaluable and you'll always want at least one magic user of some sort.  Hires in Dead Man's Switch seem to have been built before the system was tested.Note that you won't likely to be able to recreate any characters from the paper and pencil game; the system just isn't the same.  Street Sam's can't have Wired Reflexes AND Dermal Plating for example, and the Wired Reflexes don't give extra AP passively like they did in previous editions.  Drain is replaced with cooldown (although casting from hitpoints remains an option).Once you get the hang of the system however, it's well worth it.  Strong builds are rewarding, and certain builds allow soloing runs on Normal, but you'll never get so powerful you can afford to get cocky.Fans of the console adaptions will be pleased, as there's plenty of shout-outs.  Highly replayable as well, due to the number of ways to solve situations depending on your build.ADDITIONAL EDIT:  I cannot recommend the Dragonfall DLC highly enough!  It includes several improvments in game design and having experience from the first game shows.  While Dead Man's Switch is definitely a love letter to the SNES/Genesis games, Dragonfall adds more depth to the characters and feels more like a true RPG with the ability to talk to a regular set of runners inbetween runs.  It is also a vastly more satisfying experience and well worth its price because it's basically a separate game entirely.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												Shadowrun is cyberpunk meets fantasy, all mashed together with the kitchen sink thrown in. Character classes include shamans (clerics), street samurai (fighters, melee or gun-based), mages, adepts (magical martial arts fighters), deckers (computer hackers) and riggers (who control drone robots). Player character races include humans, orcs, trolls (extra large orcs), elves and dwarves.The world includes lots of fantasy monsters from spirits and giant scorpions to great dragons, and also plenty of security personnel itching to die at your hands.Decking (computer hacking), and the way computers and the Internet work in general, doesn't make any sense at all. But this is totally consistent with the Cyberpunk genre, which was generally written by people with no real computer knowledge. Inside Cyberspace, you battle ICE (Intrusion Countermeasures) and even Black ICE (ICE that can kill you in real life).I've played through the original plot of Shadowrun Returns (Deadman's Switch) and also Dragonfall. I thought that both games had really engaging stories, and were generally well-paced, had good dialogue and interesting characters. The scenes and themes fit well with a cyberpunk "high tech, low life" motif.Dead Man's Switch was very linear, with little more than dialog choices (nice answer, neutral answer, mean answer). Playing it is a lot like reading a good book that has interactive fight scenes and some inventory management.Dragonfall was less linear, with some limited ability for the player to make world-changing choices. The important decisions are all made more toward the end of the game, though. This may annoy you, or you may like it because it gives you the chance to load your game and try a different ending with only 5 minutes more investment. Also, Dragonfall has much more lively NPCs, which makes for a game that feels a bit more social and less isolating.That having been said, it's great that the stories are good, but 90% of your time in the game will be spent in fights. Almost all of the skills that you increase with experience (which Shadowrun calls "karma") are combat skills, although they have some limited utility in conversation (especially Charisma). All the equipment is combat or quest related.In Shadowrun, the fighting is turn-based, with each character on a side getting a turn (with 2 or 3 Action Points) before the next side gets to act. The huge array of options can be overwhelming, especially at first. Fighting takes place in a large variety of locales and against a wide variety of foes. Sometimes your opponents get a surprise turn against you, which can be very annoying if your main character is squishy (has few HPs), as you see the entire enemy team attack your character (who is not under cover) before you get to act. I was once killed outright this way without even having a chance to react. Fortunately, I had an item that automatically resuscitated me.The fighting in Shadowrun Returns can get pretty repetitive fairly quickly, though. Once I figured out the ideal strategy (see next paragraph), it was just a question of repeating the same operations every fight. The same strategy works every fight. The only variation is a bit of difference in tactical positioning depending on how the enemy is approaching you and the layout of cover. Take cover, buff your main damage dealers, and kill your opponents. If your opponents bunch up use grenades and area effect spells against them. Rince and repeat.SPOILER WARNING the best strategy is to take a mage and buy spells that do area effect damage or reduce AP. In a 1v1 duel you can easily steal all of your opponent's AP and just damage them every turn without ever being hurt. Other viable options include a rifle/shotgun specialist or a high-Intelligence decker/rigger. The melee characters are particularly underpowered. Use shamans as support to boost your main damage dealers with AP, HP and accuracy. SPOILER WARNING ENDThe game is a bit buggy. I frequently have trouble with character equipment, where items will switch in or out of my backpack spontaneously, or I'll see different items when in combat or out of combat. I've had rare situations where I click on a HUD button and my character moves on the map instead--wasting a turn. I encountered no critical bugs that crashed the game or prevented story completion, however.There are some usability issues. There doesn't seem to be any way to manage drone equipment. It can be awkward to manage objects found in the world, since only the character accessing the container can pick up the item, and outside of combat you only have control over your main character. The game often requires extra unecessary clicks, like when using abilities that can only be used on yourself, you're still forced to click on your sprite to self-select.Overall, I consider this game worth buying and playing, especially if you're a fan of computer role-playing games.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns runs very well on Linux, does not crash suddenly, graphics render well, I've had no problems running it.I wouldn't call the writing in this game "spectacular”, but certainly you can tell they cared about the story and the dialogues. Although your choices in dialogues don't really alter the game very much, and sometimes not even the NPC's response, the game text is not a default, vague writing just to fill in dialogues. There is a common universe and plot going around and it's not a common sci-fi cliche. There is some depth to the story and that is noticeable, but it is not very developed: the writing and dialogues don't alter the outcome of the game very much.If you are crazy about graphics, I wouldn't exactly recommended, but if you like graphics as in Bastion, you might be satisfied. Textures are mostly still, and you move through a fixed-camera map which you can pan with the mouse. Graphics are pretty, they don't look outdated at all, but they are not intended to be realistic.In this default campaign, trying to let as little spoilers as possible, you will try to discover something. This process is full of dialogues and there is a story behind it, but when it boils down to it, you are just following what the game directs you to do. You don't actually understand what you are getting from dialogues and put the pieces together: the pieces are put together for you. If you are looking for a game that makes you think, probably not the best choice. This is an action game.Shadowrun Returns provides you with a fair amount of character customization as you gain "karma", the game's word for experience. Doing many things, from picking things from the ground to killing enemies, will earn you karma. You can spend that to increase your stats and earn skills in the process. The race you pick is crucial to this, and that's good: races are not a mere aesthetic choice, rather, they set the limit for how much you will be able to invest in a certain stat.Overall, if you like turn-based combat, don't care too much for cartoonish graphics and likes reading the dialogues and understanding the story, give it a try during sales, as it's the case right now. I wouldn't buy it for the original price tag, but the game is nice and very enjoyable, certainly worth my time.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a classic RPG combined with modern gameplay elements but it's focus clearly lies on storytelling and immersion. It aims to create a believable world based around the popular Shadowrun pen&paper ruleset and in that it succeeds. It took me around 16h to complete the main campaign most of which was reading dialogues similar in structure to that of games like Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment. On pure gameplay and mechanics it lacks however although you will love the combat system if you liked X-Com: Enemy Unknown.But if you really want a good game buy this and get the DLC "Dragonfall". It beats the maingame astronomically. While the maingame focuses purely on the main character Dragonfall introduces persistent team members for the first time that develop relationships between them and yourself over time. They even managed to create a richer and more dense story around the awakening of the Dragons with lots of plot twists and filled with morale decisions where there is simply no clear right or wrong. And when you are finished with both campaignsthere is always the workshop to come back to where you'll find a huge number of player created adventures. Shadowrun Returns has the potential to keep you engaged for several years as, so far, the devs are constantly working on new content for the game but even more so the community. Currently a number of the best modders for the game are working together on a massive scale campaign. So even if the next piece of DLC is not that great, there is still something to be looking forward to.In short words this game is best described as a mixture of Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment, X-Com and Fallout. That all combined with it's active modding community easily makes Shadowrun Returns the best "C"RPG of this time.It's on sale until the May 5th, so grab it. It's a steal.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												This expansion for Shadowrun Returns (by Hare-Brained Schemes) evokes the old-school grand scope of classic Bioware RPGs.  More than just an expansion campaign, Dragonfall improves on the original engine in many ways, and responds directly to many complaints about the original.  Even better, it translates those improvements (like a new save system) to the original campaign as well, so folks new to the series entirely can enjoy the improved engine from the start.  The result is an improved product all around, and a memorable and enjoyable RPG set in one of the most fun alternate universes ever created.  An excellent set of custom creation tools add to the potential life of the game, as the mod community may well produce some masterpieces of their own, down the line.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												If you're a fan of the old-school turn-based games, you'll enjoy this one.  If you're a fan of coorporate run futuristic dystopias, you'll enjoy this game.  If you're a fan of the table-top game that this is based on, you'll enjoy this game.The strongest point of this game is it's story.  The writing is fantastic and the world is immersive.  Walking into this world knowing almost nothing about it, the game gives you plenty of story to build off of.  Each of the characters feel like people and even the slang used in the game that's unique to the world is easy to understand, even for someone who has never came into contact with it before.The artwork for the game is superb.  The game combines 3-D and 2-D elements in the form of painted portraits for most NPCs and the 3-D element of game play.  The world itself isn't very interactable, but it isn't necessary.The game play can get very static very fast, especially with combat.  Once you figure out that the AI is going to react certain ways and the trick to not getting your face blown off, it can get dull quickly.  It's absolutely worth finishing the game, however, as the story is fantastic.If you're a fan of Baulder's Gate, this game will remind you of it in its play style.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never played the original Shadowrun (SNES and Sega Genesis, apparently), but after playing Shadowrun Returns, I'm going to find it.Shadowrun Returns is one of the few games in the "RPG" category that is, in fact, a Role-Playing Game. Unlike Dungeon Siege, Diablo, BioWare Game or Final Fantasy, Shadowrun actually requires you to interact with NPCs and the manner of those interactions actually impacts the game. Imagine that. So many games claim that NPC interactions affect outcomes, but this is the first game I've played in a while (not including the Elder Scrolls/Fallout 3 sub-genre) in which that's actually true.Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign) has a little bit of important dialogue, but Dragonfall (the first DLC campaign) is LOADED with character development and NPCs that actually behave differently depending on how you treat them.But the beauty of Shadowrun Returns isn't the official campaigns. It's the editor, and the integration with Steam Workshop. I've not actually used the editor yet, but judging from the vast range of quality in the user-created content, it must be pretty easy to use. On the one hand, that means a LOT of just pure garbage content. On the other hand, it means that learning how to use the editor isn't a stumbling block for somebody who's got a great story to tell.So while the original campaign is really quite good (I mean really, really good. It's one of the few campaigns of any game that I'm perfectly happy replaying several times in a row), Dragonfall really showcases what the game's engine is capable of.If you've ever played the old Fallout games (Fallout, Fallout 2, Fallout Tactics), this is a lot like those. If you haven't played those, think of it as turn-based, squad-based Diablo, with almost no emphasis on gear. There is an equipment treadmill, but it's not very involved. More along the lines of Mass Effect 2.There are three or four pistols (for example), and you buy the most expensive one you can afford. So while there IS a reason to make more money and get the better stuff, it's not the need that it is in other games (Diablo, for example). Sorry to keep making the comparison to Diablo, but that's the other game I've been playing most recently.Shadowrun Returns is also one of the few games I've played that knows how to use a touchscreen. Most games work "well enough," but SR has a touchscreen mode that makes it function beautifully. And by "beautifully," I mean that the PC version plays just as well on my Dell touchscreen as the Android version plays on my Samsung Note 2.I don't know if anyone but me cares about that, but with the increasing prevalence of Windows 8, I figure it's worth mentioning.I know I'm making a big deal about Dragonfall, and I mean to. It's an excellent campaign, and is actually (in my opinion) worth the price of a full expansion pack, as opposed to the increasingly-common 2-dollar DLC. But I suppose I should really talk more about Dead Man's Switch. It's an engaging mystery with great characters. It doesn't have the meaningful dialogues and character developmnet of Dragonfall, but I was immediately taken with both Dresden and Kluwe. They're not "important" characters, but the fact that placeholder roles are filled with well-fleshed and well-written characters is just indicative of the attention to detail paid by the devs. It's a well-polished introduction to the world of Shadowrun.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Okay, I finally have to write a little something after playing the Dragonfall DLC.First off, to quickly go over Shadowrun Returns:  Let me preface this by saying I am a kickstarter backer.  Back when SRR popped up on Kickstarter, I immediately jumped on board.  I'd been craving the old-school SR like the ones on Genesis and SNES which I played when I was hardly into my teens, and everything in the KS pitch sold me that this would bring it back to those days.  When SRR finally released and I played through it, I came out satisfied.  It has a solid and deep story, good combat (which has since been balanced and improved), fairly simple puzzles, and yes..it had some flaws like no manual saves (again, resolved since then), but it didn't really bug me that much.  Most of all, they made choice matter.And then along comes Shadowrun: Dragonfall.   Dragonfall absolutely oozes greatness.  There's insane depth of characters and the world, down to the smallest details, even in conversations with side characters like Simmy Kim and reading the Shadowland BBS.  It's a very rare thing where a game captures me so well that I sit and read every single piece of text I come across (and there's so much to read in this series).  I especially appreciated the design in this DLC of having the quest hub, but more importantly, there were so many more rich side quests throughout the campaign than in the base game.  They also upped the design on the puzzle elements a bit which I appreciated (the original campaign's were generally way too straightforward).  But enough of a wall of text, let's break things down:Story: Phenomenal.  Aside from the depth of lore in this world, the story of this campaign alone was so great.  Just when you     think you've got things figured out, something throws you for a loop.  You face lots of decisions that test your morals, many of which mostly seem to test just how close to "the line" you're willing to step, or if it's even a question for you.Characters: Great.  This time around, you've got a dedicated crew.  Sure, you could hire runners to go along with you, but the crew is where it's at.  They've got deep stories and I loved every bit of exploring them.  The SRR Dead Man Switch campaign had people occasionally joining you, like Coyote, but those companions pale in comparison to the attention given to the crew of Dragonfall.  I cared about my crew.  Hell, I felt bad that I always had to leave one member behind on my runs having only room for a team of 4.  I felt like I was neglecting them most of the game and that they were going to confront me about it at some point.Combat: Solid.  I played on hard difficulty, and essentially did the same rifle-focused street samurai build I did in SRR.  I found it much more balanced, and there were several missions with some real tension as the fights raged on.  The Matrix served a good purpose as well; it felt much more key to this campaign than the first.Graphics: Beautiful.  They already established this with SRR, they just painted a whole new world for Dragonfall's Berlin setting, and it's gorgeous.So that's it in a nutshell.Final verdict: Worth buying?  Abso-freakin-lutely.  This is an rpg not to be missed.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I bought this game during the summer sale a few days ago and paid $3.74 for it. It's easily worth 10 bucks to me. Having just finished my first play through on normal difficulty as an Elf Decker of the base game (Dead Man's Switch), I figured I'd share my thoughts on it: Very solid shadowrun feel to it in many respectsThe cityscape looked how i envisioned it would.  The Matrix, magic, cyberware, and other things were there as well. It was missing the shadowrunning feel to it though honestly.  Instead of it being a single Johnson or a series of Johnsons giving you missions, it focused on a single mission which kept getting more complex as it went along until it was concluded... which leads to one of the things I was not impressed with (mentioned below).Solid combat systemIt's a Turn based Action Point system alternating between you/your team and enemies going.  This is a deviation from the combat system of the Shadowrun Tabletop, but was still solid and required some strategy.Solid story lineI played 6 straight hours my first time sitting down with it and the only reason I stopped is because I realized I had fallen asleep in my chair for 4 hours and had to get up to go to work.  It wasn't a thrill a minute action story, but it was a good solid line that progressed evenly and kept me interested ehough to see what happened next. It didn't feel like it was too long, but didn't feel like it was quite long enough. Maybe 1 more scene to the game would have been perfect for length.Awesome envisioning of the MatrixThe implementation of the matrix was close to how I'd envisioned it from the 3rd and 4th edition Shadowrun game books. It was fast and sleek looking, although I wish there were more of it and a little more customization capability of your Avatar in it. (It would have been nice to have the genesis version with random systems and a Johnson that could give side quests?... which would also fix one of my  previously alluded to complaints about the game.)My cons:Maps are very limited/restrictedThe maps were small and basically there was nowhere to go outside of your target destination. You entered and moved from insertion point to objective building. Everything else was blocked off.money generation felt like it is limitedOutside of the main story line which basically rewarded you for clicking on/finding everything or metered infusions of money as the story line progressed... there was no way to earn money to upgrade your gear.  Through most of the game it felt like I was being forced to pick having a team to run with and mediocre gear and little to no cyberware upgrades or get the cyberware and best gear to go it alone.Missing the Johnsons and the basic premise of the shadowrun gameThe fact that there were no Johnsons to take runs from in the game was frustrating as it is a big part of being a shadowrunner.  Although when you look at the storyline of the game, it is more of a single run  instead of living the full life of a shadowrunner so maybe the lack of Johnsons and side runs isn’t actually missing from the game, but it would have helped to make some money to buy better tech.Overall, I’d say the game is a gem for anyone who likes the shadowrun universe but would fall flat for anyone that’s just a gamer.

												An essential game for all fans of cyberpunk, sci-fi and fantasy, cRPGs or PnP, and turn-based gaming. Posted: June 17, 2014
												Shadowrun is a long running series, starting in 1993 as a Nintendo action adventure game, it literally blew minds with its diverse story telling. It had everything; connecting your brain to the internet, street mages, mafia trolls, crazy ex-girlfriends. the game was later adapted into a paperback rpg that has had a relatively strong run. ( its in its 5th edition.)Shadowrun Returns; Deadmans switch and its superior, Dragonfall, takes place in 2070, about 10- 20 years after the events of original. Deadmens switch is an adventure through the city of Seattle, fighting through deadly cultist plots and drek crazy doctors you manage to avenge your old partner’s death. While dragonfall is and intricate story about investigating a mysterious force in berlin while your attempt to battle forces that would appose the flux state. I belive the game play is quite sharp for a turn based game, delivering multple layers of complexty with its various custom class archtypes (rigger, adept, shaman, samurai, mage, decker, ect) you can play a muscle mage, or a shooty hacker, or any combination there of. next there's the multiple layers of customization, from bio mods to specll selection you have a large library to chose from. I've thoroughly enojoyed my adventures in the dark, an impatienly await the coming additions.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												I've played this game for ten hours before I eventually got too frustrated and uninstalled.What I thought when I first encountered it was a misstep, (the lack of any save/load game feature), turned into a death knell -- you WILL reach moments in the game, where despite your best planning you are left in the worst condition you could be and are unable to continue.In a typical RPG, you would restore to an autosave or a quicksave or otherwise from somewhere earlier on and roll the dice again, presumably to try and get a better result from a combat sequence -- you'd be free to because a regular game recognises the mutability of each instance of combat and provides you that opportunity. That is NOT the case in this game: if you get to the penultimate area of a mission with no health, dead team members, or no supplies, you must either run through the situation over and over from their awkwardly placed checkpoints, or start the entire mission over again from BEFORE you initiated it. This includes talking to all the NPCs, watching unskippable cinematics, recruting new team members, purchasing supplies, levelling up, and travelling to the mission area. Depending on how much preparation you require, you may spend more time in preliminary prepping than actually playing the game, going over the same (admittedly clever and consistent) dialogue, losing its significance each time.This surely seems like an issue that one shouldn't harp on, but consider how elemental even a rudimentary save system is to any RPG you've ever played, and then remove it. How many opportunities are there to say that it was a universally good choice? In this game, the absence is so notable that it almost renders the game worthless.As for the positives, the game is set in the legendary Shadowrun universe, fully realised in video game form! The writing is quite often witty and on point. There is a potential for infinite content with the open authoring tools.It's worth buying if you think you can deal with the big drawback, but it is a big one.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Back in my SNES days, Shadowrun was by far my favourite game.  These days, that's the only game that really sticks in my mind when I think back to playing that console.  Over the years I have tracked where the game was going.  Horrified that Microsoft bought the rights, but thought maybe they'll do something good with it.  Nope.  2007, I saw it was just another first-person shooter, not tied to the Shadowrun universe, I sadly concluded there was no chance of ever seeing another Shadowrun game like the one on SNES.  Guess I'll have to install a SNES emulator and play the original (never got around to it).Then I was cruising around Google Play last week, when Shadowrun Returns showed up on my recommended list.  OHHHH.... darn.  No tablet.  Yet.  But tis on Steam, and it works on Linux.  REJOICE!  I tried it for a few hours and so far it's looking great.  I played both the Dead Man's Switch campaign provided by Harebrained Schemes, and a story someone is putting together to replicate the SNES version.Thanks Microsoft for giving the game's rights back to Jordan Weisman!  Thanks Jordan and HBS for bringing back the world of Shadowrun to our screens!  Thanks  Kickstarter for the campaign to fund HBS' development.  Thanks all who provided funding!  Had I known the campaign existed last year, I would've contributed for sure.
