Posted: March 15, 2014
												The original shadowrun for Sega was one of my favorate games of all time, and certainly my favorate cyberpunk game.  The amount of detail in world creation, plotline, and character development made the original game playable multiple times.Over a decade later, I was thrilled to see a sequel.  I found that the writing and plotlines were as original and immersive as the previous original.  Some things had changed, the graphics were slightly more detailed, the combat system different, and the world much smaller and more linear.  But the essence of the game, the style, and much more was enough to make the game a great experience.I was slightly disappointed at the small size of the game compared to the original, but have since discovered there will be additional content added.  Shadowrun Returns is certainly a great start, and I look forward to new content.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns offers an enjoyable walk through a cyberpunk story, which grows larger than is really sensible.  This is a linear tale, presented in the form of the original Baulder's Gate games.  Players of games in this style may be left wanting from the gameplay.  Although the player has control over team mates in combat the player has no control over their skill point allocation and may only manage their own player in this way.  Further, there is not much variety to speak of in the combat.  I'm also warned by friends to not bother chosing to play a Decker (hacker class) one's self, as there is little opprotunity for the player to make use of this class's specialities.  Likewise, there are some conversational bonues in the Charisma attribute that can ignored altogether (I think I only saw "Academic" as a possible response category once).  I'd recommend this one for anyone itching for a Shadowrun experience, but with reservations.  I am hoping that Shadowrun: Dragonfall offers more depth in the gameplay.  I also just remembered that this was a Kickstarter project.  Great work from that perspective.  Here's hoping future installments keep up with the excellent story-telling and also satisfy more in the gameplay.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns runs very well on Linux, does not crash suddenly, graphics render well, I've had no problems running it.I wouldn't call the writing in this game "spectacular”, but certainly you can tell they cared about the story and the dialogues. Although your choices in dialogues don't really alter the game very much, and sometimes not even the NPC's response, the game text is not a default, vague writing just to fill in dialogues. There is a common universe and plot going around and it's not a common sci-fi cliche. There is some depth to the story and that is noticeable, but it is not very developed: the writing and dialogues don't alter the outcome of the game very much.If you are crazy about graphics, I wouldn't exactly recommended, but if you like graphics as in Bastion, you might be satisfied. Textures are mostly still, and you move through a fixed-camera map which you can pan with the mouse. Graphics are pretty, they don't look outdated at all, but they are not intended to be realistic.In this default campaign, trying to let as little spoilers as possible, you will try to discover something. This process is full of dialogues and there is a story behind it, but when it boils down to it, you are just following what the game directs you to do. You don't actually understand what you are getting from dialogues and put the pieces together: the pieces are put together for you. If you are looking for a game that makes you think, probably not the best choice. This is an action game.Shadowrun Returns provides you with a fair amount of character customization as you gain "karma", the game's word for experience. Doing many things, from picking things from the ground to killing enemies, will earn you karma. You can spend that to increase your stats and earn skills in the process. The race you pick is crucial to this, and that's good: races are not a mere aesthetic choice, rather, they set the limit for how much you will be able to invest in a certain stat.Overall, if you like turn-based combat, don't care too much for cartoonish graphics and likes reading the dialogues and understanding the story, give it a try during sales, as it's the case right now. I wouldn't buy it for the original price tag, but the game is nice and very enjoyable, certainly worth my time.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I recommend this only if it's on sale. Dragonfall I found more enjoyable than the base campaign, but it's still linear and short; given that user content comprises most of the gametime this release has to offer, I also only recommend it if it's on sale.When you purchase this, you are purchasing a clumsy game engine with a short, linear example campaign. I only narrowly gave this thumbs up, because of the fact that most of the game's potential comes from user-generated content, which is made by people who will not not be seeing any of the money you pay. The engine itself is clumsy because it takes a lot of fiddling to make it immersive; doors cannot be closed again once open, by default; you have to set each one up to do so, etc. Places that look navigable are sometimes not. There is a lack of cover in places where there sems like there should be.In short the product feels rushed, and most of the potential comes from people that are willing to work (for free)/adapt the tools released, rather than from the developers. Worth it if under 5$.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												Bottom line: If you like turn based combat and this game is on sale for 5-10$, go for it.Fun Factor: 70-73/100Game Time:  Around 30-45 hours.  I left the game on a few different nights, so chalk up 16-30 hours of Steam's "recorded play time" being from that.Mediocre turn based strategy that really didn't bring anything new to the genre.  The setting for the game is neat, it takes place in Seattle/Berlin and there has been a resurgence of magic use, different sub types of humans(Orcs, Elves, etc.), all blended with future technologies.  The stories are fun but mostly but are mostly predictable, leaving you with no real sense of wonder.  The dialog tried it's best, but it probably reads as poorly as this review, hah.  The combat isn't anything to get too excited about either, as it's basically dice rolling for accuracy of success and damage. Even at the highest difficulty setting, I didn't find myself all that challenged, which may be a blessing to those who just want to breeze through the game.  The inability to customize characters outside your main character is pretty lame and rather off putting at times.  I wanted to customize my own Shadowrunner hit squad...  I do recommend checking it out, but it certainly isn't one you need to get to right away.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is set in a fantastic, cyberpunk, distopian earth, where mega-coorporations are running the show, drug dealers roam the streets, and mercenary adventurers, called "shadowrunners" take on dangerous work for the highest bidder. On top of everything else, magic has returned to the world, which puts a novel spin on the whole cyberpunk setup.This game has a brilliant atmosphere, captivating from the start, pulling you into the dirty streets of a blade-runner-ish seattle, and putting you into the skin of a shadow runner. Shadowrun returns features a great story, with lots of twists and reminds me of the Torment due to its emphasis on dialogue, rather than battles. On the downside it's very linear, with only a couple of occasional options for side-quests. But this is not necessarily that bad, because it focuses on the plot and tells the story without infinite distractions and pointless errants.Highly recomended for RPG fans who are not aversed to exploring a futuristic, cyberpunk world, very similar to the worlds of Gibson's "the neuromancer", or Stephenson's "snowcrash" but still very unique in its own right.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a great game.Think Lord of the Rings meets the Matrix for the setting : orks, elves, trolls, dwarves and regular humans dwell in the shadow of mega-corps, facing the many perils of a cyber-punk low-life. They fight, charm or oustsmart their way around the many dangers of this world with guns, cybertech and magic. The general setting is vibrant and offers a great potential for many stories.The official first campaign is good, but the excellency comes from the User Generated Contents, some of which are better than the original game. Shadowrun's online community offers a lot of different storylines that make this game virtually immortal : play as an elf shaman, a troll bruiser, a dwarven mage, an ork street samurai or a human cyber pirate (or any combination of them, or a character of your own design), assemble your team of runners and advance through the myriad of high-quality mods. Each character has its advantages and drawbacks, so a balanced team is often the best option, though sometimes brute force, magic or technological capacity can make the difference.On the gameplay, it is rather intuitive : 50% RPG, 50% turn-by-turn tactical fighting (à la X-Com) with varyinng proportions depending on the mod.Some "classes" are better suited to some roles than others but the progression system allows you to create your own build : do you want your shaman to have proficiency in firearms ?  Do you prefer him to be a pure spellcaster and go mage/shaman ? Do you want him to be extra-tough ? Do prefer to concentrate on invocations and shamanic support spells ? Do you want to sacrifice some of your spellcasting capabilities in favour of cyberware ? All builds are possible and all of them work, with various advantages and drawbacks !The different races help for the feel of the game but have ultimately little impact gameplay-wise apart at the very begining or at the very end of a campaign. Choosing to be a tough troll or a gracefull elf will give you some minor changes in starting stats and a different ultimate potential, but for most of the game the different races don't really matter.Overall, this great game is made awesome thanks to the online community (most of which is here on Steam).

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Its hard for me to put into words just how great this game is, I honestly can't sing enough of its praises to be truthful. The entire game is rich and full of atmosphere, really setting the mood for the setting it is placed in. The game had me firmly in its grasp the entire time I played it and not once did it let me go, never breaking character or form in a way that jarred me out of the experience.The game's character creation is really straight forward and easy to understand and especially flexible, so if you find yourself dislikeing the path you set yourself on but happen to like another class as long as you do so early enough you can more or less cross class and still be rather effective!The game is turn based so if that's your stick hop right on in! It's challenging, but not in the punishing way.  I've never had something in the game bad happen to me that was anything less than poor performance on my part. It's never made me feel like I've been cheated out of a win or into a death. Only that I made a stupid move and ended up dead or lossing the battle becuase I failed a requirement.Every character I ran into was full of life and unique in their own right, I've never met someone in the game I've even actively disliked! Well, save some of the villians and that was only in the sense of. "Jeez, what a♥♥♥♥♥♥" Rather than the usual, "Ugh what a cliched loser." The only real complaint I have in the area is that you dont really get to associate much with the some of the npcs. By that I mean become real tight friends with them. Ie: Lets say I stroll along and help out vendor A or give him something he wants. While it's acknowledged that I've done right for him verbally, they dont really give you any discounts or anything. Heck other than really asking them about their past and getting to be chummy with them you don't really get to interact with them much outside of that, save with the exception of like: Coyote. None of the npcs really give you any discounts and the like. Though if your playing the game right you wont really need the money to be honest. Though I suppose in the end its only really a minor set back if even one at all, considering that they were very three-d and interactive characters. It was a significant step up from all the two-d card board characters that you get for npcs a lot lately. I could actually feel and even would go so far as to say, loved going back to talk to them on a regular basis.Another thing I loved was the fact that I had all sorts of ways to solve any problem I ran into, each class had its own unique way to solve or deal with things that they ran into. Especially out of combat and I rarely ran into a problem that I couldn't solve in muliple ways myself. I'm going to stop here because I'm more or less fan girl rambling at this point, but seriously if you've got the spare cash to shell out for this game. Do it, it is well worth the price, I've frankly had significantly less fun on sixty dollar games. For fourteen ninty nine this game is a total steal. I can't believe I how lucky I got on the flash sale back with this, I almost feel half  guilty for getting it as low as I did.But long story short, the game is great, damn great if you wanna get down to it. I only hope that they pump out more dlc for this. All the content I've played so far is a massive explosion of awesome. Any of you guys still on the edge for trying it just give in. Trust me its worth that price and that much more if you can afford it.

Posted: September 7, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns may not attract everyone, especially younger more modern players, but those who remember the hayday of classic PC Rpgs like Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Icewind Dale, etc. will fall in love with this title. It may not be as advanced as the previously mentioned games but it is one of the closest experiences one can get to a true table top pen and paper experience like Pathfinder, D&D and real Shadowrun that one can get. It feels mostly like you are playing through a novel. Dialogue and responses to said dialogue is all read. There are no voice overs. Leveling up your character is a blast with alot of options for play style.Though Shadowrun Returns is not the most advanced or elaborate RPG out there it is still an insanely fun experience, especially for pen and paper fans or classic PC rpg fans. Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game totally rocks!!  It's a little old, and if you're looking for graphics and cosmetics, go elsewhere, cause those are things you won't find here.  But it has everything else.  Lots of interactivity, like you just don't find:  a lot of the decisions you make for how you say things are just your own flair, don't make a difference, but decisions you make in game impact things early on and forward.  Some of these decisions, naturally, Shadowrun being a logical universe, require you to be able to do it-- so if you don't have the skill in question high enough, it's not an option-- but not to worry, there are more than two ways to skin a cat sometimes, and there's pretty much always going to be more than one.  Sometimes, that involves creativity- like buying coffee if you figure out a solution for a street junkie who wants more money than you (may) have, even if you talk him down in price (though you might have enough) but is too out of it to be able to get down to the cafe for himself, so, insert errand, you pay less than you would have doing it straightforwardly-- though it's the future, and real coffee is still pretty pricey (for coffee).  You get money multiple ways for different things, including of course selling loot-- but so far in my playing the game there's more of an emphasis on selling mission items, specifically software you stole, and by completing jobs and/or tasks.  Tasks:  this is also how you level up.  In this game, trust me from the start, you *really* want to explore the world around you.  There are people to interact with you, and as often as not, the things they want from you can give you a karma point.  You don't know what will give you karma points, but it's not hard enough to figure out looking around and seeing things you can help people with helps.  Karma would seem an odd name for the resource for levelling, but it's actually not, because you can do things like get a junkie help-- which you hear more about later if you do.  Again, you can pick how you go about getting her to get help, too:   do you play it higher-than-thou, at least that's how I see it, do you talk logic to her, do you scare her-- you might have to do two of those at least, actually, but I only played through once.  Just on the earlier point.   But back to karma.  You get karma for beating mission objectives, which again do not just come up without chatting, looking into things and such, clicking on things to figure out what's going on in the world around you-- if interactivity does not appeal to you, this is not the game for you; it is not simply fighting.  If it does, it's more complicated than I make it sound in experience, because there are so many different things to interact with... it would be hard to categorize.  *Ahem!*  You explore, you complete tasks, you get karma....... and you level up!!  Leveling up takes up a lot of karma, and there's a whole lot to level up, so you have to pick and choose, but a lot of it you're just going to forget about anyway, because your character isn't specialized in hacking- oh you included that?  S/he is a super crappy fighter then, at least as far as I've gotten, but okay, that's what you get when you want to hack computers instead of being a gunslinger.  I kinda didn't like the extensive use of spell-like systems in this game to start with, but now that I've gotten more used to it, I just want to go all out when I have the credits and buy like everything and use it all.   The spell-systems are different, though they don't all get called that (there are three of them) and they're not as out of place as you may be thinking.  If you read about the game, bear in mind, there are guns and computers and hackers, but there are also trolls and ogres and dragons.  Just sayin'.   Oh.... the dragons are bad*** and you literally don't mess with them.  Taking down a dragon takes an army, not a small unit, generally speaking, and in this futuristic society the dragons wiped out large bodies of people before getting taken out... not all of them have been.   All of this is in the lifetime-recent past of the living, some of it having started *it's true* since after the game came out, presumably, but at any rate also before 2014, which is when I'm writing this.  Man, I've spent a fortune it seems on MMOs that I got sick of.... this game cost me under $5 while on sale and I can't get enough of it so far.  I'll get tired of it, too, but I'm definitely looking for another game for nothing again when I get tired of it... graphics aren't bad for being old and cheap budget, and I like reading the text better than listening, but oh, there is a lot of reading, did I say that?  lol... you have to read the conversations, no voice acting... it's all low-budget... just straight-up good creativity is what makes it such an awesome game.  Modding community too, though I haven't tried their work yet, no reason-- still playing through my first campaign.   So I highly recommend this game.... it should run on your computer if it's not a fossil, though I could be wrong, and I apologize if so.... this is the first review I've written for Steam, and the game definitely deserved some "credits."  Universe is scifi, if you missed that part, looks a lot cheesier than it is.  Lots of effects and ways to acheive them, grenades for instance that do different things, robots that do different things-- you have seriously limitied inventory, but you've got a killer size stash, so the limit is on missions (you can keep as much as you like, there's nothing there specifiying an inventory limit on your stash.)To tell the truth, there are still things I haven't figured out how to do in game yet, or if there's a way to do them (I'm pretty sure I level my own team too, but I don't know how-- or even how to switch out their gear) but there's a help me section I've been having way too much of a blast to wade through lmao.... I don't have the credits right now to buy Igger a new gun anyway lol.  You have time after every mission involving fighting to wander around town and do more missives that are just interaction and figuring stuff out (nothing requiring a high IQ, don't worry-- just be curious, that'll get you more than far enough), during which time you can stock up on supplies, sell stuff, tip a dancer, that kind of thing... have a cup of soykaf!  Woo-hoo! lololol.... World:  Well-drawn.  It's like reading a good book, really.  There's stuff happening, nothing boring, lots, and I mean lots, of drama, nevermind you're a cold-hearted professional cutthroat, you care about sentiment because everybody does in reality and so therefore do you.  You may be bad***, and your team too, but you all care.... I'm only a little way in but I play this game for interacting with a world in more ways than one, with real results (albeit it's a game xD), and not so much so for adrenaline rushes or combat.  Gear is great-- not just armor and weapons, but lots of other stuff too.  You can replace limbs with robotic parts, use different-purpose grenades (including shrapnel xD), use medkits and trauma kits (the latter bring you back to life from a near-death encounter, but you don't have much inventory-- just 7 slots-- so it's not like this makes everything peachy.).. lots else Anyway, the characters are all different, it's not like your team consists of the same 5 people, per se, though your party expands in time- they all have personalities, and they don't all feel exactly the same toward you, and while most of them follow your leadership as far as I've gotten, there are differences that come up-- after something adverse, one of them wants to share alcohol with you (which gives you a choice-- do I drink in this game?  there are more than just two answers).  Naturally there are limits to how much impact you have on storlyine six times in a single conversation, don't get me wrong-- but usually, if I think about it, so's life.  -noroom

Posted: March 3, 2014
												I never played the table top or the MMO shooter no one else seems to have played either, but Shadowrun Returns hits all the important bits for a western RPG: flexible charecter progression, a plot that raises the stakes as you progress, comrades of drinking age, and a fun enviroment that doesn't need hundreds of codex entries to explain what the hell all is going on. Its good tactical fun for a reasonable price: beating the game won't make you sad to leave the charecters, but it will feel like you came from somewhere and did something. If that's not you cup of tea, go find a game where the protagonist has three love intrests he doesn't even notice in between beating up spiders and panther bear robots in his quest to slay god. I'm sure that is much better time spent...

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Even if you're not totally familiar with the universe, if you're looking for a great tactical RPG to knock out in a few days? This is perfect. The whole thing is like having one big tasty snack that leaves you wanting more. But that's sort of the downside. It may not give you enough to entirely satisfy you. Which is better than feeling like it's one trudge, but you still wish for more. The user created levels and junk you can download are okay, but don't really match up to the same quality as the main campaign. That's just my opinion though. And it may not be quite that replayable, or at least not as much as you'd want it to be. Say you decide to be a Street Samurai. This means you probably wont be decking any computers. And while you'll come across a few situations where it'll help, all it really does is save you some time. Same for speech options. They're rare, and don't really offer any change in the conversation.But in the end, I'd still reccomend it. It still has a great short story to tell and a rich atmosphere. I'd say plan on buying the DLC rather than relying on the user created content to get your additional fix, though. At least until some of the more major projects are legitimately finished.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is not in itself a game. It is a platform that supports the creation and play of Adventures, both developer and community created. "Dead Man's Switch" is the initial campaign that you get at purchase and is a well constructed adventure. It has almost all the things you might expect to see and hear in a shadow run adventure. The combat is a xcom esque entertaining and at times very challenging. The characters are interested and likeable. The leveling system is more or less an intuitive waterfall setup. Attributes unlock skills, and skills unlock specializations i.e. Quickness[1] -> marksmen[1] -> rifles[1]. Though the game could do better on conveyance in general. Most important though is the adventure is fun and the game mechanics are solid.I do have minor grips with some of the unanswered mechanics issues and other game play short comings. But before that I can safely say that if you are a fan of shadowrun or have ever enjoyed playing the paper and pen or older SENS games you will enjoy this one.** My final recommendation: If you like Shadowrun you will like Shadowrun Returns - Dead Man's Switch **Now If you are interested in an runners ranting here are some of my misgivings about the game.-Characters should be persisten between adventures. Starting a new character every adventure is a little disheartening. (This being between Dead Man's Switch and dragonfall)-Send to stash: sending things to your stash doesn't seem to send said items to your stash.-Hit Chance: a legendary marksmen shouldn't consistently miss from half a room away just because the target is behind a half cover desk.-The lack of stealth is a real bummer, coupled with that is the lack of ability to use your etiquettes to aid in undercover stealth sections.-The absence of a local net on runs to disarm alarms, disrupt communication, shut off lights, lock doors, est. Mostly the disarming alarms before they go off bit.-Magic is also very spartan in comparison to the physical combat skills and interactions. You can summon spirits at predetermined locations-Having to run into an enemy or ambush to trigger combat mode is very disconcerting. The ability to freely toggle combat mode would have been greatly appreciated. -Riggers: Not being able to pilot drones outside of combat is a bit of a disservice to the rigger characters. As setup is a key part to the rigger play style.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Wow, the Dragonfall campaign really changed my opinion on this game. I didn't really enjoy Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign), it felt forced, linear, barren and dull. All that coupled with the game's inherent limitations and plenty of bugs, left a bad taste in my mouth. I do enjoy tactical combat and "old-school" RPGs, but I was about to give up on Shadowrun Returns.Then came Dragonfall. Still pretty much linear (though you notice it less this time around), still riddled with bugs (take old bugs out, put new bugs in, the development process kinda goes that way) and still with more or less the same annoying game limitations... yet it manages to outshine all these drawbacks with a helluva good story, enjoyable NPCs and character interaction, ambiguous moral choices that you can actually care about, challenging and entertaining combat and several new ways to do old things, including new tech and spells, plenty of skill checks (which also meant that no matter how good you got, you were never going to get the full information on everything, which is a good thing in my opinion). It's a huge leap up from Dead Man's Switch and has redeemed Shadowrun Returns in my eyes. Highly Recommended.I hope SR continues to give us content comparable in quality to Dragonfall, so that we can all put that Dead Man's Switch nonsense behind us. l found out bitterly what this game couldn't do when I played through Dead Man's Switch. But I just now found out what this game CAN do after I played through Dragonfall. And that is: BE ENTERTAINING!

Posted: July 15, 2014
												I finally got around to playing this game. Picture the gameplay of XCOM: Enemies Unknown mixed with a book roleplaying game. AKA Shadowrun. I've roleplayed a lot, although never Shadowrun. But it feels like a nice little adventure. I'd say the game lasts about 12-15 hours. It gets a little slow paced though, it's very text heavy. If it was voice acted I think that would add a lot to it, but I don't fault it for that. When you do get into combat, it plays almost exactly like XCOM. You get action points, 2 to begin with and you can either move or do an action like fight with those points during your turn. It's all turn based strategy on a grid. Overall I didn't find the combat to be very difficult, you hire a team before each mission to go with you but I played a Street Samurai and I was basically bread for combat.That leads me to the character creation, I picked a Street Samurai as I mentioned, but you can pick from quite a variety of characters to begin with and tweak them as you play with Karma points. Like leveling up in the book RPG's. These various character choices lead to different dialogue choices and even options on the battlefield. So there is definitely variety and replayability here.Speaking on replayability, this game also opens itself up to player stories and mods. You can download and create your own or others stories/adventures. So the game really has no end. It is certainly worth full price, but even better if you get it on sale. I would definitely recommend this game to any Cyberpunk style enthusiasts. If you liked XCOM you will like this combat system. Only gripe is all the reading. It makes me sleepy, but I pressed on and finished the main campaign and really enjoyed it.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Its hard for me to put into words just how great this game is, I honestly can't sing enough of its praises to be truthful. The entire game is rich and full of atmosphere, really setting the mood for the setting it is placed in. The game had me firmly in its grasp the entire time I played it and not once did it let me go, never breaking character or form in a way that jarred me out of the experience.The game's character creation is really straight forward and easy to understand and especially flexible, so if you find yourself dislikeing the path you set yourself on but happen to like another class as long as you do so early enough you can more or less cross class and still be rather effective!The game is turn based so if that's your stick hop right on in! It's challenging, but not in the punishing way.  I've never had something in the game bad happen to me that was anything less than poor performance on my part. It's never made me feel like I've been cheated out of a win or into a death. Only that I made a stupid move and ended up dead or lossing the battle becuase I failed a requirement.Every character I ran into was full of life and unique in their own right, I've never met someone in the game I've even actively disliked! Well, save some of the villians and that was only in the sense of. "Jeez, what a♥♥♥♥♥♥" Rather than the usual, "Ugh what a cliched loser." The only real complaint I have in the area is that you dont really get to associate much with the some of the npcs. By that I mean become real tight friends with them. Ie: Lets say I stroll along and help out vendor A or give him something he wants. While it's acknowledged that I've done right for him verbally, they dont really give you any discounts or anything. Heck other than really asking them about their past and getting to be chummy with them you don't really get to interact with them much outside of that, save with the exception of like: Coyote. None of the npcs really give you any discounts and the like. Though if your playing the game right you wont really need the money to be honest. Though I suppose in the end its only really a minor set back if even one at all, considering that they were very three-d and interactive characters. It was a significant step up from all the two-d card board characters that you get for npcs a lot lately. I could actually feel and even would go so far as to say, loved going back to talk to them on a regular basis.Another thing I loved was the fact that I had all sorts of ways to solve any problem I ran into, each class had its own unique way to solve or deal with things that they ran into. Especially out of combat and I rarely ran into a problem that I couldn't solve in muliple ways myself. I'm going to stop here because I'm more or less fan girl rambling at this point, but seriously if you've got the spare cash to shell out for this game. Do it, it is well worth the price, I've frankly had significantly less fun on sixty dollar games. For fourteen ninty nine this game is a total steal. I can't believe I how lucky I got on the flash sale back with this, I almost feel half  guilty for getting it as low as I did.But long story short, the game is great, damn great if you wanna get down to it. I only hope that they pump out more dlc for this. All the content I've played so far is a massive explosion of awesome. Any of you guys still on the edge for trying it just give in. Trust me its worth that price and that much more if you can afford it.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												If you've ever played 2nd Edition Shadowrun this is a huge nostalgia trip - if you haven't it's still damn fun.The majority of the game plays out like an old-school text-based RPG like Fallout (no voice actors required) and will have you investigating the death of an old friend through a variety of standard 2050s Seattle backdrops.Combat, when it happens, is very similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Each character has a set number of action points that they can use each turn to move, shoot, cast spells, control drones, etc. Normal difficulty shouldn't pose much of a threat (I think I've been killed twice) so once you have the mechanics of it down I'd suggest playing through on Hard or better.Slight spoiler for the main story: make sure you put some points into Shotguns.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I recommend this only if it's on sale. Dragonfall I found more enjoyable than the base campaign, but it's still linear and short; given that user content comprises most of the gametime this release has to offer, I also only recommend it if it's on sale.When you purchase this, you are purchasing a clumsy game engine with a short, linear example campaign. I only narrowly gave this thumbs up, because of the fact that most of the game's potential comes from user-generated content, which is made by people who will not not be seeing any of the money you pay. The engine itself is clumsy because it takes a lot of fiddling to make it immersive; doors cannot be closed again once open, by default; you have to set each one up to do so, etc. Places that look navigable are sometimes not. There is a lack of cover in places where there sems like there should be.In short the product feels rushed, and most of the potential comes from people that are willing to work (for free)/adapt the tools released, rather than from the developers. Worth it if under 5$.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												Bottom line: If you like turn based combat and this game is on sale for 5-10$, go for it.Fun Factor: 70-73/100Game Time:  Around 30-45 hours.  I left the game on a few different nights, so chalk up 16-30 hours of Steam's "recorded play time" being from that.Mediocre turn based strategy that really didn't bring anything new to the genre.  The setting for the game is neat, it takes place in Seattle/Berlin and there has been a resurgence of magic use, different sub types of humans(Orcs, Elves, etc.), all blended with future technologies.  The stories are fun but mostly but are mostly predictable, leaving you with no real sense of wonder.  The dialog tried it's best, but it probably reads as poorly as this review, hah.  The combat isn't anything to get too excited about either, as it's basically dice rolling for accuracy of success and damage. Even at the highest difficulty setting, I didn't find myself all that challenged, which may be a blessing to those who just want to breeze through the game.  The inability to customize characters outside your main character is pretty lame and rather off putting at times.  I wanted to customize my own Shadowrunner hit squad...  I do recommend checking it out, but it certainly isn't one you need to get to right away.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												This has been an interesting experience! Isometric RPGs have been rapidly winning my heart back even since ME 3 and this one was a fresh change from the normal recipe.The skill system is nicely portrayed, gameplay is fun and with a lot of choices and the story brilliant enough to keep you invested ( don't expect crazy or unexpected plot twists here ) My two major cons here are the general linearity of the game , which doesn't allow much on the exploration department and the lack of plentiful side quests (which probably goes side by side with my first complain) This game CRIES for side questing and the characters it introduces are SO WELL portrayed that it's arguably a crime that there is no further development with them or some involving quests to further enjoy them in action (Coyote's quest for example should have been done for more characters!) There is your occasional side quest , but they are SOOO few that it makes you feel sad moving on to the next chapter like this. Finally i was REALLY bummed by the length of the main campaign .. I mean okay i understand that you guys were betting on the UGC (user generated content) to maximize replayability but really that short ??? You could have made an at least +20 hours on the Dead man's switch . Oh well..Pros:+ Beautiful Skill system+ Fun Gameplay+ Enjoyable storyCons:- Too Linear (for an RPG)- Very few side quests - Main campaign TOO BLOODY SHORT!All in all did i fully enjoy this game? Yes Could i have enjoyed it EVEN more ? DEFINITELY YES Do i recommend it? well yes if you are an RPG fan you will enjoy this for what it offers. But maybe try and get it on a Sale as i did

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I just finished "Dead Man's Switch" of Shadowrun Returns and I really enjoyed it. Just a heads up before my review, the main reason I purchased this game is because I used to play the table top version of Shadowrun back in highschool. Just the product's name brings back great memories and my review (and enjoyment of the game) of course is partially biased due to this background. Here is a quick review for those interested in the title:What is "Dead Man's Switch"?Think of Shadowrun Returns as the client, and DMS as the story you plug into it. There is also a DLC that I've purchased but not started yet that is another story for Shadowrun Returns. I'm hoping they will continue to support this product! Game Mechanics:Smooth, easy to learn, and well done. The game plays like the first Fallouts or the Baldur's Gate series as an overhead tactical turn-based gameplay. With that said you do not need any prior experience with this type of game to enjoy Shadowrun Returns. The menu, UI, and rpg elements are all straight forward. The only thing that bothered me about the combat UI was reloading my rifle, however I'm sure there was a hotkey I could've used. Story vs. Action:The biggest compliant I saw on my own research of this game prior to purchase was the amount of dialog. The team that created this game obviously aimed to reproduce a table-top setting that focused primarily on storytelling, not combat. There are plently of short engagements throughout this product and I felt the combat was very satisifying. However, if you are the type that clicks quickly though dialog in other games you won't be impressed with this title. The best part of this game is the story and for those don't care about that and just want an action / adventure title should look elsewhere. If you have any direct questions please comment below! I just wanted to hit those two points since they I felt they were not communicated well in other reviews.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												This ain't your nephew's Dragon Age 2 or Witcher. Instead of going for needless voice-overs and cheesy cutscenes, this game aims purely for great dialogue - in written form. For the uninformed, dialogue in written form is a tradition which had been going on for many, many centuries.What you're getting here is an Old School western RPG, very reminiscent of the first two Fallout games. It shares two of their biggest strengths - great writing and interesting setting. The biggest detriment is that the gameplay here follows an extremely linear plot. That wouldn't be so bad, if the game also didn't feel so short. It's absolutely adequate for the price you're paying, but you can't help but feel like there's something missing when you arrive at the end. However, that may just be, again, because of the very, very good writing.Despite the fact that barely any dialogue choices and actions has a greater impact on the story, this game inspires one to play through it again with different characters and mindsets - just to read all the NPCs' reactions to all the dialogue choices. I can't stress that point enough. Some people notice the difference between 'okay' writing and great writing, and some think of AAA titles as high art.DRAGONFALL DLC:Dragonfall, in two words: Pretty amazing. For me, what really makes Dragonfall stand out in comparison with the original campaign, is the difference in plot structure.For one thing, the game is much less linear. There are several missions to do in the middle section of the game; these can be done in any order you want, and it's entirely possible to skip one (maybe even two) of those missions.Another major improvement is the fact that companions stick with you and are there to talk to after every mission. There are more than enough of these permanent companions hanging around that you never have the need fore hired companions. The original campaign had a great variety of interesting characters who would accompany you for a mission or two; here, they stick around and have new dialogue after every major mission. There's character development, and in the end, there's even closure.Which brings me to the ending. Bluntly put, it's really, really good - enough to be a major point in this review. While the original campaign left you no choice in the end and the feeling of closure was kinda missing, Dragonfall delivers both in the end, and it does so very, very excellently, too. You are not only given a very meaningful choice which has the potency to shape the future of the setting, but the consequences of that choice are also portrayed adequately. After the end of the game, you are given one more chance to talk to every NPC of the main hub, every one of your companions and even new NPCs, depending on your choice. There's closure for every character and your choice is possibly being questioned in some of the best dialogue of the game. But, lastly, the best thing about this DLC is that it delivers more of the old. Shadowrun shines when you get to interact with strong characters and are given absolutely free reign - the first Harlequin dialogue from the original campaign comes to mind - and there is much of that, here.

												Shadowrun Returns original campaign:This is a very nice Shadowrun based game, with a good story and gameplay. However, it is a short game and as soon as you learn how to optimize the character skills (and the enemies AI failures...) it is an easy game, even in the very hard mode. 												Even if you're not totally familiar with the universe, if you're looking for a great tactical RPG to knock out in a few days? This is perfect. Posted: July 24, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is not in itself a game. It is a platform that supports the creation and play of Adventures, both developer and community created. "Dead Man's Switch" is the initial campaign that you get at purchase and is a well constructed adventure. It has almost all the things you might expect to see and hear in a shadow run adventure. The combat is a xcom esque entertaining and at times very challenging. The characters are interested and likeable. The leveling system is more or less an intuitive waterfall setup. Attributes unlock skills, and skills unlock specializations i.e. Quickness[1] -> marksmen[1] -> rifles[1]. Though the game could do better on conveyance in general. Most important though is the adventure is fun and the game mechanics are solid.I do have minor grips with some of the unanswered mechanics issues and other game play short comings. But before that I can safely say that if you are a fan of shadowrun or have ever enjoyed playing the paper and pen or older SENS games you will enjoy this one.** My final recommendation: If you like Shadowrun you will like Shadowrun Returns - Dead Man's Switch **Now If you are interested in an runners ranting here are some of my misgivings about the game.-Characters should be persisten between adventures. Starting a new character every adventure is a little disheartening. (This being between Dead Man's Switch and dragonfall)-Send to stash: sending things to your stash doesn't seem to send said items to your stash.-Hit Chance: a legendary marksmen shouldn't consistently miss from half a room away just because the target is behind a half cover desk.-The lack of stealth is a real bummer, coupled with that is the lack of ability to use your etiquettes to aid in undercover stealth sections.-The absence of a local net on runs to disarm alarms, disrupt communication, shut off lights, lock doors, est. 												I recommend this only if it's on sale. Dragonfall I found more enjoyable than the base campaign, but it's still linear and short; given that user content comprises most of the gametime this release has to offer, I also only recommend it if it's on sale.When you purchase this, you are purchasing a clumsy game engine with a short, linear example campaign. I only narrowly gave this thumbs up, because of the fact that most of the game's potential comes from user-generated content, which is made by people who will not not be seeing any of the money you pay. The engine itself is clumsy because it takes a lot of fiddling to make it immersive; doors cannot be closed again once open, by default; you have to set each one up to do so, etc. Places that look navigable are sometimes not. There is a lack of cover in places where there sems like there should be.In short the product feels rushed, and most of the potential comes from people that are willing to work (for free)/adapt the tools released, rather than from the developers. Worth it if under 5$.

												Overall, I would give this game a 9/10. Everything is fantastic, and I cannot wait to play Dragonfall someday and also play player-created campaigns. I really enjoy pretty much every aspect of this game--the environment, combat, characters, atmosphere, etc.--except for the main story. Despite getting very interested in the storyline after the first few lines were presented to me, almost all of my excitement was lost when the Ripper was revealed. I was having fun treating DMS as a murder mystery; I was carefully examining everything and trying to figure out who the Ripper could be--I even had some evidence to support who I thought could be the Ripper--but the game pretty much points a huge sign at the real suspect from the moment they are introduced, and this is overwhelmingly disappointing. Posted: November 7, 2015
												Cyberlike, tatical strategy, turn-based rpg. A lot of great things about this game however, there are a lot of flaws as well. The graphics are nice. The artwork is fantastic. The story is interesting. Shadowruns is a great series!Not to mention, the game editor produced some amazing community content.I especially love that it's compatible with my tablet pc. You don't need a keyboard to play. As a result, I spent my long subway rides progressing with the story which was a great way to pass time. However... this game is extremely linear. There are dialogue choices, but most of the time.. They don't matter. Most, if not all, dialogues end the same.Most importantly, the gameplay is extremely linear. There's not much exploration and the paths are clearly laid out for you. Adding to that, there are very very little side quests to actually do. There are just optional objectives that give you extra karma or help a little with the main quest. A little bit about the combat: Because it's turn-based, it takes a while for each battle. There's no way to speed up the process so battles often take longer than you'd expect. Adding on top of that, You can only save out of combat - Be prepared to finish or don't start it at all. Tldr;+ Interesting story+ Can be fun, depending on your own preferences+ Great time-passer+ Amazing artwork+ Great community content- Linear gameplay & plot- Linear dialogue - Slow combatDespite it all, Shadowrun Returns is a great place to introduce yourself and start the video game series. The sequels are a huge improvement as well. I recommend that you play it!

												This expansion for Shadowrun Returns (by Hare-Brained Schemes) evokes the old-school grand scope of classic Bioware RPGs.  More than just an expansion campaign, Dragonfall improves on the original engine in many ways, and responds directly to many complaints about the original. Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never played the original Shadowrun (SNES and Sega Genesis, apparently), but after playing Shadowrun Returns, I'm going to find it.Shadowrun Returns is one of the few games in the "RPG" category that is, in fact, a Role-Playing Game. Unlike Dungeon Siege, Diablo, BioWare Game or Final Fantasy, Shadowrun actually requires you to interact with NPCs and the manner of those interactions actually impacts the game. Imagine that. So many games claim that NPC interactions affect outcomes, but this is the first game I've played in a while (not including the Elder Scrolls/Fallout 3 sub-genre) in which that's actually true.Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign) has a little bit of important dialogue, but Dragonfall (the first DLC campaign) is LOADED with character development and NPCs that actually behave differently depending on how you treat them.But the beauty of Shadowrun Returns isn't the official campaigns. It's the editor, and the integration with Steam Workshop. I've not actually used the editor yet, but judging from the vast range of quality in the user-created content, it must be pretty easy to use. On the one hand, that means a LOT of just pure garbage content. On the other hand, it means that learning how to use the editor isn't a stumbling block for somebody who's got a great story to tell.So while the original campaign is really quite good (I mean really, really good. It's one of the few campaigns of any game that I'm perfectly happy replaying several times in a row), Dragonfall really showcases what the game's engine is capable of.If you've ever played the old Fallout games (Fallout, Fallout 2, Fallout Tactics), this is a lot like those. If you haven't played those, think of it as turn-based, squad-based Diablo, with almost no emphasis on gear. There is an equipment treadmill, but it's not very involved. More along the lines of Mass Effect 2.There are three or four pistols (for example), and you buy the most expensive one you can afford. So while there IS a reason to make more money and get the better stuff, it's not the need that it is in other games (Diablo, for example). Sorry to keep making the comparison to Diablo, but that's the other game I've been playing most recently.Shadowrun Returns is also one of the few games I've played that knows how to use a touchscreen. Most games work "well enough," but SR has a touchscreen mode that makes it function beautifully. And by "beautifully," I mean that the PC version plays just as well on my Dell touchscreen as the Android version plays on my Samsung Note 2.I don't know if anyone but me cares about that, but with the increasing prevalence of Windows 8, I figure it's worth mentioning.I know I'm making a big deal about Dragonfall, and I mean to. It's an excellent campaign, and is actually (in my opinion) worth the price of a full expansion pack, as opposed to the increasingly-common 2-dollar DLC. But I suppose I should really talk more about Dead Man's Switch. It's an engaging mystery with great characters. It doesn't have the meaningful dialogues and character developmnet of Dragonfall, but I was immediately taken with both Dresden and Kluwe. They're not "important" characters, but the fact that placeholder roles are filled with well-fleshed and well-written characters is just indicative of the attention to detail paid by the devs. It's a well-polished introduction to the world of Shadowrun.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Okay, I finally have to write a little something after playing the Dragonfall DLC.First off, to quickly go over Shadowrun Returns:  Let me preface this by saying I am a kickstarter backer.  Back when SRR popped up on Kickstarter, I immediately jumped on board.  I'd been craving the old-school SR like the ones on Genesis and SNES which I played when I was hardly into my teens, and everything in the KS pitch sold me that this would bring it back to those days.  When SRR finally released and I played through it, I came out satisfied.  It has a solid and deep story, good combat (which has since been balanced and improved), fairly simple puzzles, and yes..it had some flaws like no manual saves (again, resolved since then), but it didn't really bug me that much.  Most of all, they made choice matter.And then along comes Shadowrun: Dragonfall.   Dragonfall absolutely oozes greatness.  There's insane depth of characters and the world, down to the smallest details, even in conversations with side characters like Simmy Kim and reading the Shadowland BBS.  It's a very rare thing where a game captures me so well that I sit and read every single piece of text I come across (and there's so much to read in this series).  I especially appreciated the design in this DLC of having the quest hub, but more importantly, there were so many more rich side quests throughout the campaign than in the base game.  They also upped the design on the puzzle elements a bit which I appreciated (the original campaign's were generally way too straightforward).  But enough of a wall of text, let's break things down:Story: Phenomenal.  Aside from the depth of lore in this world, the story of this campaign alone was so great.  Just when you     think you've got things figured out, something throws you for a loop.  You face lots of decisions that test your morals, many of which mostly seem to test just how close to "the line" you're willing to step, or if it's even a question for you.Characters: Great.  This time around, you've got a dedicated crew.  Sure, you could hire runners to go along with you, but the crew is where it's at.  They've got deep stories and I loved every bit of exploring them.  The SRR Dead Man Switch campaign had people occasionally joining you, like Coyote, but those companions pale in comparison to the attention given to the crew of Dragonfall.  I cared about my crew.  Hell, I felt bad that I always had to leave one member behind on my runs having only room for a team of 4.  I felt like I was neglecting them most of the game and that they were going to confront me about it at some point.Combat: Solid.  I played on hard difficulty, and essentially did the same rifle-focused street samurai build I did in SRR.  I found it much more balanced, and there were several missions with some real tension as the fights raged on.  The Matrix served a good purpose as well; it felt much more key to this campaign than the first.Graphics: Beautiful.  They already established this with SRR, they just painted a whole new world for Dragonfall's Berlin setting, and it's gorgeous.So that's it in a nutshell.Final verdict: Worth buying?  Abso-freakin-lutely.  This is an rpg not to be missed.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												If you're a fan of the old-school turn-based games, you'll enjoy this one.  If you're a fan of coorporate run futuristic dystopias, you'll enjoy this game.  If you're a fan of the table-top game that this is based on, you'll enjoy this game.The strongest point of this game is it's story.  The writing is fantastic and the world is immersive.  Walking into this world knowing almost nothing about it, the game gives you plenty of story to build off of.  Each of the characters feel like people and even the slang used in the game that's unique to the world is easy to understand, even for someone who has never came into contact with it before.The artwork for the game is superb.  The game combines 3-D and 2-D elements in the form of painted portraits for most NPCs and the 3-D element of game play.  The world itself isn't very interactable, but it isn't necessary.The game play can get very static very fast, especially with combat.  Once you figure out that the AI is going to react certain ways and the trick to not getting your face blown off, it can get dull quickly.  It's absolutely worth finishing the game, however, as the story is fantastic.If you're a fan of Baulder's Gate, this game will remind you of it in its play style.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Some 18 years removed from the cult following success of the arcade style, cartridge era rpg shadowrun games.  This title puts a new face on a Gen-X classic.  Not to say it is a remake, although it does incorporate some of the characters i.e. Jake and a few others.  This (Dead mans switch) is a brand new story set a few years after the events we played out back in the mid-1990's.  The graphics may not be state of the art and the over all game play is somewhat cell phone app lvl.  However it is LOADS of fun.  Highly addictive and the replay value is surprisingly high although I personally feel that they could have spent a bit more time on programming the sub-missions instead of over-dramatizing the whole wanna-be detective angle which is already well implied.  To sum up.  This is Shadowrun the way it was MEANT to be as a video game.  Not great.  Nor is it trying to be anything more than advertised. 												It was a pretty cool game. My favorite aspect was just the atmosphere. I'm into that techy almost post-apocalyptic feel. Everything was edgy and I really felt I had to rely on my wits and street knowledge. However I was really confused about the classes and karma upgrades. I felt like I needed to take some time to sit down and go through each section to understand what upgrades were good to get or worthless for my character. Another issue was probably the fact that you'd have a big advantage being a decker. A bunch of quests had only special decker options. Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game totally rocks!!  It's a little old, and if you're looking for graphics and cosmetics, go elsewhere, cause those are things you won't find here.  But it has everything else.  Lots of interactivity, like you just don't find:  a lot of the decisions you make for how you say things are just your own flair, don't make a difference, but decisions you make in game impact things early on and forward.  Some of these decisions, naturally, Shadowrun being a logical universe, require you to be able to do it-- so if you don't have the skill in question high enough, it's not an option-- but not to worry, there are more than two ways to skin a cat sometimes, and there's pretty much always going to be more than one.  Sometimes, that involves creativity- like buying coffee if you figure out a solution for a street junkie who wants more money than you (may) have, even if you talk him down in price (though you might have enough) but is too out of it to be able to get down to the cafe for himself, so, insert errand, you pay less than you would have doing it straightforwardly-- though it's the future, and real coffee is still pretty pricey (for coffee).  You get money multiple ways for different things, including of course selling loot-- but so far in my playing the game there's more of an emphasis on selling mission items, specifically software you stole, and by completing jobs and/or tasks.  Tasks:  this is also how you level up.  In this game, trust me from the start, you *really* want to explore the world around you.  There are people to interact with you, and as often as not, the things they want from you can give you a karma point.  You don't know what will give you karma points, but it's not hard enough to figure out looking around and seeing things you can help people with helps.  Karma would seem an odd name for the resource for levelling, but it's actually not, because you can do things like get a junkie help-- which you hear more about later if you do.  Again, you can pick how you go about getting her to get help, too:   do you play it higher-than-thou, at least that's how I see it, do you talk logic to her, do you scare her-- you might have to do two of those at least, actually, but I only played through once.  Just on the earlier point.   But back to karma.  You get karma for beating mission objectives, which again do not just come up without chatting, looking into things and such, clicking on things to figure out what's going on in the world around you-- if interactivity does not appeal to you, this is not the game for you; it is not simply fighting.  If it does, it's more complicated than I make it sound in experience, because there are so many different things to interact with... it would be hard to categorize.  *Ahem!*  You explore, you complete tasks, you get karma....... and you level up!!  Leveling up takes up a lot of karma, and there's a whole lot to level up, so you have to pick and choose, but a lot of it you're just going to forget about anyway, because your character isn't specialized in hacking- oh you included that?  S/he is a super crappy fighter then, at least as far as I've gotten, but okay, that's what you get when you want to hack computers instead of being a gunslinger.  I kinda didn't like the extensive use of spell-like systems in this game to start with, but now that I've gotten more used to it, I just want to go all out when I have the credits and buy like everything and use it all.   The spell-systems are different, though they don't all get called that (there are three of them) and they're not as out of place as you may be thinking.  If you read about the game, bear in mind, there are guns and computers and hackers, but there are also trolls and ogres and dragons.  Just sayin'.   Oh.... the dragons are bad*** and you literally don't mess with them.  Taking down a dragon takes an army, not a small unit, generally speaking, and in this futuristic society the dragons wiped out large bodies of people before getting taken out... not all of them have been.   All of this is in the lifetime-recent past of the living, some of it having started *it's true* since after the game came out, presumably, but at any rate also before 2014, which is when I'm writing this.  Man, I've spent a fortune it seems on MMOs that I got sick of.... this game cost me under $5 while on sale and I can't get enough of it so far.  I'll get tired of it, too, but I'm definitely looking for another game for nothing again when I get tired of it... graphics aren't bad for being old and cheap budget, and I like reading the text better than listening, but oh, there is a lot of reading, did I say that?  lol... you have to read the conversations, no voice acting... it's all low-budget... just straight-up good creativity is what makes it such an awesome game.  Modding community too, though I haven't tried their work yet, no reason-- still playing through my first campaign.   So I highly recommend this game.... it should run on your computer if it's not a fossil, though I could be wrong, and I apologize if so.... this is the first review I've written for Steam, and the game definitely deserved some "credits."  Universe is scifi, if you missed that part, looks a lot cheesier than it is.  Lots of effects and ways to acheive them, grenades for instance that do different things, robots that do different things-- you have seriously limitied inventory, but you've got a killer size stash, so the limit is on missions (you can keep as much as you like, there's nothing there specifiying an inventory limit on your stash.)To tell the truth, there are still things I haven't figured out how to do in game yet, or if there's a way to do them (I'm pretty sure I level my own team too, but I don't know how-- or even how to switch out their gear) but there's a help me section I've been having way too much of a blast to wade through lmao.... I don't have the credits right now to buy Igger a new gun anyway lol.  You have time after every mission involving fighting to wander around town and do more missives that are just interaction and figuring stuff out (nothing requiring a high IQ, don't worry-- just be curious, that'll get you more than far enough), during which time you can stock up on supplies, sell stuff, tip a dancer, that kind of thing... have a cup of soykaf!  Woo-hoo! lololol.... World:  Well-drawn.  It's like reading a good book, really.  There's stuff happening, nothing boring, lots, and I mean lots, of drama, nevermind you're a cold-hearted professional cutthroat, you care about sentiment because everybody does in reality and so therefore do you.  You may be bad***, and your team too, but you all care.... I'm only a little way in but I play this game for interacting with a world in more ways than one, with real results (albeit it's a game xD), and not so much so for adrenaline rushes or combat.  Gear is great-- not just armor and weapons, but lots of other stuff too.  You can replace limbs with robotic parts, use different-purpose grenades (including shrapnel xD), use medkits and trauma kits (the latter bring you back to life from a near-death encounter, but you don't have much inventory-- just 7 slots-- so it's not like this makes everything peachy.).. lots else Anyway, the characters are all different, it's not like your team consists of the same 5 people, per se, though your party expands in time- they all have personalities, and they don't all feel exactly the same toward you, and while most of them follow your leadership as far as I've gotten, there are differences that come up-- after something adverse, one of them wants to share alcohol with you (which gives you a choice-- do I drink in this game?  there are more than just two answers).  Naturally there are limits to how much impact you have on storlyine six times in a single conversation, don't get me wrong-- but usually, if I think about it, so's life.  -noroom

Posted: July 1, 2014
												This has been an interesting experience! Isometric RPGs have been rapidly winning my heart back even since ME 3 and this one was a fresh change from the normal recipe.The skill system is nicely portrayed, gameplay is fun and with a lot of choices and the story brilliant enough to keep you invested ( don't expect crazy or unexpected plot twists here ) My two major cons here are the general linearity of the game , which doesn't allow much on the exploration department and the lack of plentiful side quests (which probably goes side by side with my first complain) This game CRIES for side questing and the characters it introduces are SO WELL portrayed that it's arguably a crime that there is no further development with them or some involving quests to further enjoy them in action (Coyote's quest for example should have been done for more characters!) There is your occasional side quest , but they are SOOO few that it makes you feel sad moving on to the next chapter like this. Finally i was REALLY bummed by the length of the main campaign .. I mean okay i understand that you guys were betting on the UGC (user generated content) to maximize replayability but really that short ??? You could have made an at least +20 hours on the Dead man's switch . Oh well..Pros:+ Beautiful Skill system+ Fun Gameplay+ Enjoyable storyCons:- Too Linear (for an RPG)- Very few side quests - Main campaign TOO BLOODY SHORT!All in all did i fully enjoy this game? Yes Could i have enjoyed it EVEN more ? DEFINITELY YES Do i recommend it? well yes if you are an RPG fan you will enjoy this for what it offers. But maybe try and get it on a Sale as i did

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I just finished "Dead Man's Switch" of Shadowrun Returns and I really enjoyed it. Just a heads up before my review, the main reason I purchased this game is because I used to play the table top version of Shadowrun back in highschool. Just the product's name brings back great memories and my review (and enjoyment of the game) of course is partially biased due to this background. Here is a quick review for those interested in the title:What is "Dead Man's Switch"?Think of Shadowrun Returns as the client, and DMS as the story you plug into it. There is also a DLC that I've purchased but not started yet that is another story for Shadowrun Returns. I'm hoping they will continue to support this product! Game Mechanics:Smooth, easy to learn, and well done. The game plays like the first Fallouts or the Baldur's Gate series as an overhead tactical turn-based gameplay. With that said you do not need any prior experience with this type of game to enjoy Shadowrun Returns. The menu, UI, and rpg elements are all straight forward. The only thing that bothered me about the combat UI was reloading my rifle, however I'm sure there was a hotkey I could've used. Story vs. Action:The biggest compliant I saw on my own research of this game prior to purchase was the amount of dialog. The team that created this game obviously aimed to reproduce a table-top setting that focused primarily on storytelling, not combat. There are plently of short engagements throughout this product and I felt the combat was very satisifying. However, if you are the type that clicks quickly though dialog in other games you won't be impressed with this title. The best part of this game is the story and for those don't care about that and just want an action / adventure title should look elsewhere. If you have any direct questions please comment below! I just wanted to hit those two points since they I felt they were not communicated well in other reviews.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Even if you're not totally familiar with the universe, if you're looking for a great tactical RPG to knock out in a few days? This is perfect. The whole thing is like having one big tasty snack that leaves you wanting more. But that's sort of the downside. It may not give you enough to entirely satisfy you. Which is better than feeling like it's one trudge, but you still wish for more. The user created levels and junk you can download are okay, but don't really match up to the same quality as the main campaign. That's just my opinion though. And it may not be quite that replayable, or at least not as much as you'd want it to be. Say you decide to be a Street Samurai. This means you probably wont be decking any computers. And while you'll come across a few situations where it'll help, all it really does is save you some time. Same for speech options. They're rare, and don't really offer any change in the conversation.But in the end, I'd still reccomend it. It still has a great short story to tell and a rich atmosphere. I'd say plan on buying the DLC rather than relying on the user created content to get your additional fix, though. At least until some of the more major projects are legitimately finished.

Posted: September 4, 2015
Dead Man's SwitchShadowrun Returns. Indeed it has... this intriguing isometric RPG is a great combat system wrapped in a rollicking mystery that although has a few stumbling points, it is very much worth your time. Returns comes with a built-in campaign that will last you 10-12 hours if you take your time, and with plenty of mods in the community to keep it fresh. GameplayShadowrun Returns has a basic isometric movement system, just click where you want to go/interact with. It's when you get into the easy-to-learn combat system that the game really opens up. You can create your Runner to be a Sorcerer, a Drone-using mastermind, or just a guy with a shotgun that shoots people in the face. The RPG system is good, not overly complicated, and has good conversation trees that can be affected with different levels of Charisma. You can even role-play what type of things your character is knowledgable in. Overall, the gameplay of Shadowrun Returns is slick and stellar. StoryShadowrun Returns has a story that doesn't quite work on the empathy stakes... there's no reason really to care for any of the characters you meet, and some of the Runners you can hire are simply generic. If they die, it's just a *shrug* and leave them behind. However, the actual mystery behind the game and what's going on I found to be motivating enough... although it starts off slow, you want to meet the 'Ripper' until you actually stop playing the game- though after you've met him, things really start to get interesting... Graphics, Atmosphere, and SoundThe graphics of Shadowrun are servicable; sure, they won't dazzle you, but they aren't bad either. It has a nice art-style to make the world come to life, and the character portraits help give you first impressions of the characters, as well as the information that comes through text-wise.The atmosphere is great, with dank hotels and rain-drenched streets beckoning your Runner on. The characters are as fleshed out as you can get in a 'short' campaign as the Dead Man's Switch, but personally, I won't miss any of them. The music quality in this game is impeccable. If you are a fan of electronic music, you won't regret listening to the tracks that are on offer here. 'Double Cross' is my personal favorite track. The additional sounds of guns and sorcery that permeate the air whilst fighting adds to the atmosphere. ConclusionShadowrun Returns, A Dead Man's Switch, is a joy to play, and although the story has a few hiccups and the companion system leaves a lot to be desired, the game is overall a solid reccomendation. Worth your time indeed. Ready to deck into the system?

I didn't have a single character die, or even get close to death in the campaign and I don't think this is because I played particularly well. Money was very readily available, to the point where I could buy anything I wanted. Overall a good game, mainly for the story, novel setting and dialog.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												Undoubtedly beautiful, quite immersive and relatively nonlinear. The greatest drawback of this game is the p&p RPG system it's built upon. I personally find it to be one of the least attractive p&p concepts, doubly so because it invades one of my favourite genres; cyberpunk. Personal buttrage aside, it is a smooth and decently long RPG with a good albeit uninteresting combat system. Play it for a laid-back adventure with a Dreamworks aroma, best enjoyed inside a duvet with plnety of bulk confectionary. [7/10] (personal bias) [8/10] (buttrage aside).
