Posted: July 21, 2014
												Amazing writing, I really got into the characters in Dragonfall. There is a lot there if you put in the effort to talk to your team members and get their back stories. Combat has enough depth to be fun, but wasn't that challenging on hard. Definitely worth playing for the story. The game mechanics add value but are not enough by themselves.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Even if you're not totally familiar with the universe, if you're looking for a great tactical RPG to knock out in a few days? This is perfect. The whole thing is like having one big tasty snack that leaves you wanting more. But that's sort of the downside. It may not give you enough to entirely satisfy you. Which is better than feeling like it's one trudge, but you still wish for more. The user created levels and junk you can download are okay, but don't really match up to the same quality as the main campaign. That's just my opinion though. And it may not be quite that replayable, or at least not as much as you'd want it to be. Say you decide to be a Street Samurai. This means you probably wont be decking any computers. And while you'll come across a few situations where it'll help, all it really does is save you some time. Same for speech options. They're rare, and don't really offer any change in the conversation.But in the end, I'd still reccomend it. It still has a great short story to tell and a rich atmosphere. I'd say plan on buying the DLC rather than relying on the user created content to get your additional fix, though. At least until some of the more major projects are legitimately finished.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is not in itself a game. It is a platform that supports the creation and play of Adventures, both developer and community created. "Dead Man's Switch" is the initial campaign that you get at purchase and is a well constructed adventure. It has almost all the things you might expect to see and hear in a shadow run adventure. The combat is a xcom esque entertaining and at times very challenging. The characters are interested and likeable. The leveling system is more or less an intuitive waterfall setup. Attributes unlock skills, and skills unlock specializations i.e. Quickness[1] -> marksmen[1] -> rifles[1]. Though the game could do better on conveyance in general. Most important though is the adventure is fun and the game mechanics are solid.I do have minor grips with some of the unanswered mechanics issues and other game play short comings. But before that I can safely say that if you are a fan of shadowrun or have ever enjoyed playing the paper and pen or older SENS games you will enjoy this one.** My final recommendation: If you like Shadowrun you will like Shadowrun Returns - Dead Man's Switch **Now If you are interested in an runners ranting here are some of my misgivings about the game.-Characters should be persisten between adventures. Starting a new character every adventure is a little disheartening. (This being between Dead Man's Switch and dragonfall)-Send to stash: sending things to your stash doesn't seem to send said items to your stash.-Hit Chance: a legendary marksmen shouldn't consistently miss from half a room away just because the target is behind a half cover desk.-The lack of stealth is a real bummer, coupled with that is the lack of ability to use your etiquettes to aid in undercover stealth sections.-The absence of a local net on runs to disarm alarms, disrupt communication, shut off lights, lock doors, est. Mostly the disarming alarms before they go off bit.-Magic is also very spartan in comparison to the physical combat skills and interactions. You can summon spirits at predetermined locations-Having to run into an enemy or ambush to trigger combat mode is very disconcerting. The ability to freely toggle combat mode would have been greatly appreciated. -Riggers: Not being able to pilot drones outside of combat is a bit of a disservice to the rigger characters. As setup is a key part to the rigger play style.

Posted: September 17, 2014
												You! Yes, you.  You like fantasy RPGs? You like strategy games? You like Sci-Fi? Ever wanted to mash 'em together into a delicous nerd smoothie?  Then do we have a product for you.If you're an XCOM fan, the mechanics are pretty straightforward to you.  Honestly, Shadowrun Returns as simply a game is good, but not great.  The Karma system for leveling allows you to customize your character however you like with no limitations on class, though you'll want to specialize as you approach endgame.However, Shadowrun Returns -- Shadowrun as a whole -- is so much more than a game.  It's a living, breathing world; a technologically heightened and magic-infused setting for stories of any kind.  Plots might hinge on the epic and esoteric (dangerous research into blood magic by a ruthless, profit-hungry megacorp) or the throwback noir with a twist (being hired by a dead man to find his murderer).  Sure, most of the RP of this RPG happens via old-school plain text, but you know what they call plain text in most places? Books. It ain't broke, so don't fix it!Character creation remains fun to me, even after a few playthroughs.  It's pretty neat to tell your friends about your human shaman/street samurai who packs enough heat to take on a militia even before summoning his elemental spirits.  Or about your pink-haired elvish techno-wiz equally at home jacking into corporate Matrix blocks or rigging into her homemade combat drones with her very mind.  Moreover, the skills your character chooses will assist them outside of combat, unlocking alternate routes, hidden passages with loot, chances to solve a problem diplomatically (with added EXP!), and more.The campaign that ships with the game, Dead Man's Switch, is a bit short but satisfying nonetheless.  It's an excellent introduction to the Shadowrun world, and veterans of the series will even see a few familiar faces.  Dragonfall, the DLC whose remastered version will drop tomorrow, is just plain phenomenal.  And that's not even touching the free Steamworks fan-made campaigns, some of which are truly brilliant.  Harebrained Schemes, the devs of Shadowrun Returns, have reminded us that a great game doesn't need 60 fps or 360-noscopes. You just need solid mechanics, a fascinating setting, and some hardcore writing chops.Be sure to check out the pen-and-paper Shadowrun RPG, too!

Posted: October 17, 2014
												As a first time experience, this game had me really enjoying the whole concept of shadowrun. I must say as someone who wasn't a fan before, this game had really opened up my experience and mind to the world of shadowrun.Gritty, dark and futuristic environment really appeals to me as I was not a fan of cyberpunk before, however this game has really helped introduce this genre as its environment was well designed enough to keep me interested.However, some gameplay elements can be rather repetitive and the base storyline is rather bland, however the additional campaigns online makes up for it, thank goodness for indie campaign creators (do mind me if i used the wrong terms, am new at this)Overall, a 7/10, good game, and great way to introduce people to the cyberpunk genre.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												Finished Shadowrun returns last Monday.From my blog: http://www.dyle.org/blog/?p=233Played fully on Linux with Steam (native, no Windows Emulation).You play a character in the Shadowrun universe which is on the hunt to bring down a friend’s murderer. Time is around 2057 but due to the Awakening, the world is filled with science fiction high tech and fantasy elements alike. You have genetic modification, cyberplants and hacking warfare along with elves, orcs, dwarfes and trolls hurling magic bolts. A rich and fascinating universe.… you have to work trough yourself. The game can be summed up by the phrase “too less”. At first there is too less background for the setting, the story. You just start off creating a character, like an orc, with cybernetic implants. Yep, no explanation to this. If you want to find out more about the Shadowrun world you have to look elsewhere but not the game.Then there is too less RPG. Seldom you find something useful to pick up and equip. Also stats and skills are presented in a very sober way in a plain matrix. No introduction, no nothing. All at once, on page. Also you likely will spend points on attributes and skills you don’t need in future. Sorry, there is no turning back.Then there is too less adventure. The story is nice, but you got not real decisions to make. The storyline is very linear. There are some side-quests, but guess: too less.Then there is too less of a challenge. At the first two thirds of the game. I pimped my elf with quickness and assault rifles and the game was no real match at “normal” level. Strategic fighting is nice and … easy. Yeah, the games picks up some pace in the last third and starts to get harder. This is were the fun really sets in. But up to then it is playing a nice story …And someone always has the idea of something missing. Something’s missing at the RPG, at the adventure, at the combat game, at the grafics, animations.E.g. Harlequin is one of the coolest elves I’ve come along in playing games, but when he wields his sword he is animated as if someone had stiffed a broomstick right along his “back”. The in-game representation is missing the charisma and style this elf has in dialogues.Finally the save game mechanics are just bonkers. Actually you just can save at the start of a level, better: the game (hopefully) autosaves at this stage. Making a wrong decision at the end of a level requires to replay to whole level again.The pro: once you’ve delved into the universe the plot is great to play and the dialogs are really nice written, the combat is fun after all. It remains a nice game. Hopefully they fix this bad savegame mechanics and give more universe background information in the DLCs and patches to come.

Posted: July 25, 2013
												If you liked the Sega Shadowrun game, this will bring back a lot of memories. Love it. The new patch and DLC addresses the save anywhere issue. It's a great representation of the old pen and paper RPG on your PC.

												Your return to the 6th world is a triumphant one with this game. If you've played the old console games (specially the Snes game) you'll feel all your memories coming back to you; it's from the same people even!.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												For years now I've considered old-school isometric genres to be 'my' genre. That is to say, the one that strictly caters to my sensibilities as a player. I discovered them well after their golden age, and since this wave of kickstarted CRPGs began I've been eagerly awaiting their results.As the first one out of the gate from this batch, Shadowrun Returns does not disappoint. If you're like me and you've been aching for a deep and immersive roleplaying experience and actual agency when it comes to solving problems, this game is a steal at $20. Excellent writing, beautiful environments, and a fantastic soundtrack all tied together with engaging combat and character progression.The campaign will take you about 15 hours to run through, and there's sadly little in the way of extended diversions, and the game is rather linear in how it progresses. There's not much of a sense of an 'open world' that one would expect from this genre, but even still the world itself is one of the most well-realized and vibrant ones I've seen in a long time.They've got another campaign on the way, and you're going to see plenty of gameplay content coming out of the steam workshop, so I can guarantee you'll have your money's worth in actual meaty game.If you like RPGs at all you owe it to yourself to grab this game and play through it. You'll be really glad you did.

												Less than I hoped for.Shadowrun feels half-baked in a couple of ways:1) The writing was made with care, but there are far too many allussions and jargon phrases that are used without explanation. It feels like jumping into a conversation after its started2) The games menus and iventory don't seem to be finished or have all the detail other games might.3) The game is short. Like really really short. For an RPG, that's usually dissapointing.4) There's all kinds of class/skill options, but there usefulness seems questionable.But there's a silver lining!Combat system has potential, there could be great mods.Puzzles were clever and challenging.The universe is fascinating.Art style is beautiful.

Posted: December 24, 2015
												A lot of people say that Shadowrun Returns is not good and lacks in a variety of qualities. Maybe so, but it still felt like a breath of fresh air for the fans of RPGs when it came out. I totally recommend playing this one.

Posted: September 25, 2014
												Shadowrun is a fun turn-based RPG with unique classes and gameplay. The highlight of the game are its in-depth and aluring campaign that features an intricate, thought-provoking story -- something you don't see in many games these days. Turn based isn't usually my thing, but somehow Shadowrun manages to keep the combat fun and exciting.

Posted: July 28, 2013
												This game is absolutely great from top to bottom. The main game is a well written and well paced piece of murder mystery cyberpunk action, made with great writing and interesting characters. The writing is so good, in fact, that even characters that show up just once or twice feel really memorable. The graphic style and musical design are top notch and really help make the experience into a cohesive whole. The gameplay is a solid tactical RPG experience that's fun to play, if a bit on the easy side more often than not. The few downsides to the game start with the lack of manual saving. The game automatically saves at checkpoints (probably to prevent save scumming like some other tactical games) which can sometimes be frustrating. The locked angle camera usually is okay, but there are times where it's a problem. Some people will call a 12 hour, very linear main campaign a problem too, but I personally think that it's better to have 12 high-quality hours than 20-25 with lots of filler. So it's not perfect, but it's damned well done. And the inclusion of an editor means that in the end we'll hopefully see a lot more great content from the community.

Posted: November 23, 2015
												This is a fine piece of a turn-based RPG. I defnitely enjoyed this great, albeit short,  game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn-based rpgs, x-com enemy unknown/within, urban-science-fantasy settings and fantasy races. A surprisingly good mixture of sci-fi stuff with near-like contemporary settings filled with elves, orcs, trolls and dwarves.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												If you're new to Shadowrun, like me, and not sure whether it's worth buying, the questions is: do you like detective fiction? Because that's exactly what SR is. That means you have to read a lot.Another thing to consider is visual simplicity. Shadowrun Returns looks good, but don't expect much on that side. It won't show you stunning cutscenes or SFX. It'll describe all that in a text box instead. Yeah, just like in 90's.So if these things don't scare you, give it a try and maybe in half an hour or so you'll be completely immersed.

Posted: March 14, 2016
												A pleasant surprise. I picked up Shadowrun Returns a few years ago,  just coming off an XCOM-high and jumped the instant I heard "XCOM-style combat". Found plenty to stay for. The neat, if linear, story, highly customizable playstyles, and some very unique character designs/portraits.I do have a few gripes, one of which is the inability to rotate the camera, which made combat a bit of a hassel. This is understandable, though, given the hand-drawn backgrounds. Other wise, not bad. Get it cheap, finish it in a afternoon.

Posted: February 7, 2016
												Being new to the PC/Steam community, I was astoniished and a little overwhelmed when I began browsing the Steam store for the first time. Something I am sure many people have experienced.I kept at it and as I searched through the  of numerous titles available along came Shadowrun Returns.....Now, I have been gaming for many years and one of the highlights was playing Shadowrun on the SNES (Super Nintendo). This game was such fun and the world so diverce, it is one of those gaming experiences you never forget!To find this gem among so many other great titles on Steam made my day, a chance to return to the Shadowrun world.The setting is a future Cyber Punk world, centred around a strong story driven experience with RPG/Turn based action elements. It is a game you can play when you want to lose yourself for an hour or often more. It is not as complex as other turn based stratergy/RPG titles, but still as rewarding due to an excellent murder mystery story line. It is above all an excellent place to start for people wanting to give this type of game a go. I have not played the other subsequent titles that have been released, but fully intend to as they each in turn expand the game and it's complexity with new functionality. Just check out the reviews/videos for the rest of the series available! For the price it's a steal for any gamer and will open up a new exciting experiences. Just like the SNES game did for me many years ago.Give it a go, you won't be dissapointed.

												An easy buy if you enjoy xcom style gameplay and fantasy cyberpunk.I really enjoyed this game. ~10hrs of gameplay... well maybe half story and half dialogue. Posted: December 25, 2013
												I marathoned this game. It is fantastic. It reminds me of Infinity Engine games like Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's Gate, only the combat is much easier to wrap your head around. The setting is cyberpunk (William Gibson and Neal Stephenson specifically) mixxed with high fantasy. The module that is included in the game is a fun story, but don't be surprised if you call out plot points well before they happen. I've only played through it once, but my class choice (decker) seemed pretty useless in most situations. I am hoping Harebrained Scheme puts out a few more modules of their own.There is a module creator and it looks like the community has put out quite a bit of content on their own. I'm looking forward to sinking a few hours investigating that over the weekend.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												This game had an excellent sense of immersion in to the world of Shadowrun. I have enjoyed playing both the released main content of Shadowrun Returns as well as many of the player workshop campaigns. One of the biggest selling points was in shipping a very useful editor that put the power of creating these campaigns in the hands of the player community.That being said there are a few rough spots. The current save system (which appears to be replaced in the next DLC Dragonfall) only provided save points at the start of a map, which means in order to save ones progress you would have to complete the section you were on and move to the next load in area for it to record your progress. The replayability was also argueable. While I enjoyed some of the subtle changes each class could bring to the different dialogs and oppertunities that would arise, the game is unfortuantely very linear. Even with those subtle changes the overall story will progress the same way. The linear story did, however, showcase many different aspects of the Shadowrun world and in my opinion was successful in introducing players to different creative aspects they could explore while making their own content for the game. You have sections of story running through the matrix, attacking a corporation and even fighting through zombies. For 20$ I found the game to be worth my expectations and have played a total of 58 hours so far between main story and workshop content. I have no regrets with my purchase.

Posted: August 23, 2015
												I really enjoyed the game. Shadowrun has a very interesting world and good dialog. The combat system is okay, fairly standard for a turn based tactical game. Downsides were few: selecting things in combat can be clunky, leading to mis-clicks and an inability to move some characters where you want them: the game overall was quite easy as well. I didn't have a single character die, or even get close to death in the campaign and I don't think this is because I played particularly well. Money was very readily available, to the point where I could buy anything I wanted. Overall a good game, mainly for the story, novel setting and dialog.

Posted: July 25, 2013
												Amazing game. It looks beautiful, combat is fun, and characters are varied. Plus, the awesome campaign editor. A++++++ would play again.

Posted: July 26, 2013
												I was a backer for this game on Kickstarter and it has not dissapointed!  The game is fantastic!  Honestly I can't believe how polished it is with the small budget they had to work with.  With a built-in editor and Steam Workshop support I can't wait to start playing all the community content.For an old school RPG fan, for a Shadowrun fan, for a turn based combat fan, for a fan of excellent and entertaining writing and incredible setting, this game is for you!Update November 2016:Over three years later and Harebrained have released two much better Shadowrun games.  I am nominating Shadowrun Returns for the write-in vote on the Steam Awards because it was such a great comeback for a classic rpg setting.  Still a good game in its own right and absolutely worth a playthrough.

												The first new PC game I've actually felt compelled to complete in ages. An interesting story, solid gameplay mechanics, and an acceptable difficulty curve. Posted: August 2, 2013
												PROPER REVIEW PENDINGWhile I am enjoying this game so far, I cannot recommend this game to anyone except die-hard Shadowrun fans. The gameplay is quite shallow and almost completely linear, the interface is clunky and designed for tablets. There is no exploration, poor documentation, and equipment selection is limited. Dialog choices are meaningless for the most part, and you cannot save the game except for advancing checkpoints, which also means no going back if you missed anything. Fallen enemies disappear and cannot be looted, and class/skill balance is poorly implemented. For a 2 million dollar budget from kickstarter alone this is a disappointment.What Shadowrun Returns really is, is a game engine and development toolkit, whose true merit has yet to be seen, with a short adventure included. This could be a good thing, but only time will tell. I see the potential for great things with this game but in my opinion that is not a selling point at this time for anyone but modders.However, as a Shadowrun fan, I am thrilled to be back exploring the neon lit slums of 2055 Seattle. The level artwork is the highlight, with the music adding to the atmosphere. The 3d character models are quite crude but fit in with the world when you are actually playing, just don't expect to get interesting looking armour for your character. There is no voice acting, but for a video game the writing is a pleasant surprise though that isn't saying much.All said and done, I don't regret preordering Shadowrun Returns, but if you are curious about the setting I recommend picking up one of the books until this game goes on sale.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												After wanting to play Shadowrun for the longest time, tonight I finally finished it. The game was not that long with its 12 hours of game time, and to be honest, it was quite a disillusion. After finishing Baldur's Gate 1 for the first time two weeks ago, I was looking forward to another isometric RPG. Being a big Deus Ex fan, the cyberpunk theme of Shadowrun Returns was very alluring. Being unfamiliar with the Shadowrun franchise, the mix of cyberpunk and fantasy felt weird at first. But even in the end, I can't say that I like it better. I'll try to summarize my experience with this game in a pro/con list.PRO  The 2D backgrounds are from time to time quite beautiful  The user interface was quite ok, and looked sleek  The first half of the story was interesting  Interesting combination of combat going on in the matrix and in real life at the same time.  The game worked quite well on Linux (except for the remarks below)  The game was easy to play with keyboard and mouse, but also with the Steam Controller on my TVCON  The game did not handle "exotic" resolutions well. 3200x1800 on my linux laptop and 3440x1440 on my desktop were not manually selectable. Log files mentioned that the game detected the native resolution but a slightly different resolution was chosen. The drop down menu never showed the native resolutions in game. Full HD on my TV was easy.  When contacting the developer's support for the issue above, no support was given. I got an email confirming that they received my email, and that's the last thing that happened.  The loading screens took quite long for a "2D" game. I would expect it to be faster than games like Skyrim?  Classes seem very diverse, but they don't feel diverse.   Leveling is quite boring. Not a lot changes exect for some % to hit etcetera.  Fights are repetitive because there are not a lot of different tactics (necessary). The AI is not very bright.  During combat sequences the game goes turn-based, even when all enemies are killed you still keep walking turn based until you find new enemies in the same environment. Moving your whole team person by person is very tedious.  When going on missions you pay mercs to come with you. They are not very strong or optimal in their configuration, so they felt like dead weight compared to my maxed out SMG fighter.  Hacking/Matrix sequences are very repetitive. Both for the looks of the environment and the variation in enemies and variation in weapons. I just spammed my default attack and nothing else was needed.   The game is very linear. There are not a lot of side quests and you can't explore the world on your own. There is no open world to visit.  Because of the linear gameplay and uninteresting classes, replayability suffers a lot.  The story of the game started out great. It felt like a personal story compared to the "save the world" kind of stories from Skyrim and company. But from the middle of the game it felt like the writers had to keep making the story more elaborate to keep the gamers interested. They created some complex and unnecessary twists that ultimately made me just click faster through the conversation options because I became uninterested.  Those conversations were often very onesided. The choices you make in conversations almost never matter. Most answers are just different forms of the same answer, making conversations very uninteresting. There is no real impact on the game.  The writing of the game is obviously inspired by the Sprawl trilogy, and tiringly so. Every sentence tries to be drearier than the last one. I like film noir and cyberpunk, but this was way too cliché at times.  The world of Shadowrun combines cyberpunk and sci-fi with fantasy. Obviously a lot of people like this, but I'm not really fond of it. It gets worse when they try to mix even more classic (cliché?) game themes in the mix: violent crazy people in an asylum, undead ghouls, monsters and even spirits!! It just lacked some pirates and vampires...  The (hand drawn?) backgrounds were nice from time to time, but they are very empty. There is not a lot of animation or interactivity. The world feels dead.  The music is nice. I mean, the 3 or 4 tracks that are constantly repeated are nice the first time. They sound perfectly in line with the cyberpunk theme, but after having it on repeat for 12 hours, I just disabled the music altogether.   The game is quite short. I finished it in about 12 hours (thoroughly reading everything), and it seems like I'm slow compared to others. Some did it in 8 hours. Sadly, I was happy that it was over.I was looking forward to play the complete Shadowrun series, but after being let down by the first installment, I just can't bring myself to buy the sequels. Even if they are better... Too bad really! I hope that the other famous tactical 2D Kickstarter games like Wasteland 2 and Pillars of Eternity can make up for this game.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												Cyberpunk RPG with turn-based, tactical combat based on the pen and paper RPG for the same name. This game is a successor to the Genesis and SNES Shadowrun games, with references to both throughout and is set around the time of 1st/2nd edition Shadowrun - the 2050s. The soundtrack is actually composed by Sam Powell and Marshall Parker, the composers of the Genesis and SNES games respectively - hardcore fans of the SNES game will LOSE THEIR♥♥♥♥♥♥when they hear familiar melodies and phrases in the midst of some of the games tracks.That said it's a solid RPG with a great art style, the included campaign ends about 10-12 hours in but is well written and contains every Shadowrun trope there is (cyberware, shamanic totems, decking, runs on corporate facilities, slaughtering gangers, conspiracies, Harlequin, etc.)More importantly, the fully featured (and almost intuitive) editor it comes with lets you and other members of the community put out their own adventures. You are essentially purchasing not only the adventure that comes with the game but also the framework to play all the stuff the Shadowrun community will be putting together through Workshop.If you love Shadowrun, cyberpunk, RPGs, turn-based tactical combat and community content this is the game for you. If you want another triple-A shooter with RPG elements loaded celebrity voice acting, poorly-used military jargon and regenerating health, move along to the next publisher-funded bore.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												As mentioned in other reviews, character modeling could be better, and the music could have more variety, but I've greatly enjoyed playing it. It's not a long campaign, but it's not so short. It took me 15 hours to finish it, and I loved every one of them. The best points, imo, were the background (as I've been roleplaying since the 80's and I used to love the original paper rpg), and the story. I think this campaign had a lot of what Shadowrun players used to love, with a strong storytelling, beautiful sets and 2D artwork, and enough of the cyberpunk world to fit a story of this length (not too much, not too few).And for the weakest points, I've missed looting bodies after a shooting, and that kind of stuff, but I guess it's just a balance factor to get rid of and simplify the system. But as I started the game with a pistol, and my oponents had shotguns, I could have used one of those, and sell the others! xDAnyway, I highly recommed playing it, it was great fun and made me want to play the paper rpg again! :)

Posted: February 8, 2016
												Rating: 7/10Budget: Worth it. Replayability: Low - The story doesn't change enough to warrant an additional playthrough. Length: Good - Custom missions too. Shadowrun Returns is actually a really great game. I have a few issues with it. You have to pick a playstyle extremely early in the game, and it's very difficult to know what is the right choice for you - Especially seeing as you have no way of controlling what classes your companions in the game will have. This is actually a much bigger problem than one might initially think. I tried going for a non-combat build, actually. I wanted to be the "face" of my party, but have my goons fight for me. Didn't work out - impossible to play this way. You HAVE to be able to fight SOMEHOW, so this was a letdown for me. Especially considering how much of the game you can actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t your way through later on. It's also fairly easy to make a character who is simply so good at fighitng that you can kill everything the game ever sends your direction. The games combat system is a bit rough and while a good translation from actual shadowrun, there's a reason that system is a bit of a cult novelty - It's just very rough in general. Over-all good game, but read a guide or something to save some frustrations.

												I know who Jordan Weissman is and am aware of many things he's done, but I had no idea Shadowrun was anything more than a video game, much less something of his; all I've ever known it as was, until this version, a Super Nintendo game.  But then I went looking for a wiki for this game, and holy crap at the decades of history.How have none of the tabletop-playing, hard-RPG grocking people on my friend list showed me this?  Damn Magic: The Gathering ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, keeping the cool stuff all to yourselves <.< It hits like 20 of my sweet spots....its a cyberpunk Blade Runner-esq style (does anyone else remember Johnny Mnemonic? it smells a lot like that, only good.), its an isometric turn-based RPG like those of old (FALLOUT!!), etc. Now I gotta buy Dragonfall when it goes on sale, until then I'm gonna toy with some of the user-created campaigns on the Workshop to see what people can do with the tools available to them.I'd give an actual, proper review/recommendation, but honestly considering its age and history, if you care about Shadowrun (or anything else bearing Jordan Weissman's name) at all, you probably already know more about it than I do, I have to google certain words they use to understand what they're saying xD but I really dig the atmosphere and the gameplay is...well, Blade Runner-style isometric turn-based (AP system, not one move per turn, think Fallout rather than Final Fantasy) RPG, that about covers it. The thing you picture after reading that sentence is very close to being accurate.

Posted: February 9, 2016
												Love this game.  I originally got dragonfall thinking it included the first one (Shadowrun Returns) and having not played any of them before and not touching any turn based games in years it was, very hard to me.  After reading that SRR is a bit slower and better to learn from I got it and have been learning a lot more about playing.  Even as I'm not that great at it and still get killed a lot and have to redo parts, it's still an amazing game. I am hard pressed to want to read dialog in most games.  This one is interesting enough that even though it is very heavy on the dialog, I find that the writing is well done, enough that you don't wan to miss anything.  It's not a lot of empty writing like filler or fluff but it drives the story and most times there are details you don't want to miss, or you might not be able to get to the next part.  The characters have personality even without the fancy voice acting and 3d character animations and cutscenes.  I'm so impressed I plan to return to Dragonfall after this, and Hong Kong is already in my library too.  (those reviews to come later) Tip for new players in this game - pay attention to your builds, learn how to use the Karma points, search for tips and tutorials if you have to or it is indeed a frustrating game to the newb.  Stick with it, it is well worth playing through - even though i'm sure I have quite a ways to go, I'm enjoying every minute.  Highly recommended!

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Shadowrun Returns is a story-driven RPG with something akin to XCOM's combat system (albeit a few tweaks and more customization per character).  There isn't any choice that drives the plot in a different direction but there are multiple ways to deal with the smaller scenarios you're presented with, such as how to get into a blocked off area.  These ultimately do not affect the larger story but it's nice to have these smaller interactions in lieu of that.Also, some dialog options are locked behind choices you make during character creation, and occasionally others are behind skill checks.  So that plus the multiple routes in each level makes up for what I imagine were budgetary constraints that prevented a multi-path narrative.  It was a Kickstarter after all.  I don't know if this is the case for the future titles in the series, so don't judge those based on this.  I'm only talking about the base game.The skill system in this game is satisfying, using a steady stream of points instead of levels.  I like all the different ways I can customize my character.  The classes all feel varied and interesting, and they fit the world really well.Shadowrun is well written, even if the story is not revolutionary.  It has fast paced dialog and isn't overly wordy, like the aforementioned Pillars of Eternity, or most games which people claim are "well written."  It doesn't bog you down in detail, yet it also provides quite sufficient descriptions to give you a good understanding of everything.  Sometimes the world's "slang" feels a bit cheesy (like using 'frag' instead of ♥♥♥♥).  I love a world that has its own slang, like in Clockwork Orange, but that slang was far more believable.  I don't believe for a second that people would say frag and stop saying ♥♥♥♥.Even with a bad story, I'd still be interested because the world that this is set in is fantastic.  It's a cross of D&D, Blade Runner, and Deus Ex.  I've not played any of the other games/tabletop games in this ruleset before so the whole thing is new to me, and I really found myself drawn into it immediately.  The only critique is that it's too bleak to be plausible.  No society with the technological capability of this one could crumble to the place that this one does.  Still, it is a work of fiction, and it's established well enough to overlook the unlikeliness of it.  The story deals with serious subjects like drug addiction, racism, torture, etc. but it also manages to keep a lot of levity in there as well.  It takes itself seriously enough, but not to a point where it's brooding or depressing at all.Overall it's a nice little game which I've enjoyed far more than many other releases.  I avoided the game for its middling reviews, but I am upset that I did in retrospect.  I'd have liked to play these games earlier when I was searching for something to play.  I really love the XCOM type combat, the classes are all interesting, the story is sufficient, and the world is really great.And this is gonna seem strange, but there's some real oomph to when characters get shot, and that has made me want to play the game almost more than anything else about it.  There's something about when games make something feel right that I just love.  I played Spiderman 2 on PS2 for dozens and dozens of hours just because of how web slinging felt correct.  I remember playing San Andreas and thinking about how differently each of the cars felt from one another, and how they all felt right in their own way.  This game, the way it feels when you shoot someone and it makes impact, it just feels correctly made.  I realize that there's probably nothing more subjective than to say that I enjoy the way it feels to shoot enemies in this game, but it's my review, so whatever.  Get the game.

ShadowRun is the game you wish you had instead of playing DnDTL;DRRating: A soild 8/10Pros:  - Hours of playtime - Different play styles  - Many classes that suit all different kinds of play styles - A DnD feel to the game that all DnD players have to try - The story line is not narrow and you have choices on how to solve puzzels or kill enemies.  - Turn base combat system that is actually worth waiting for.  - Tons of ways to complete missions. - Complete charcter customization - Well priced for the contentCons: To begin with the game is not for people looking for a shootem up and kick everyones asses as soon as they get into the room. Posted: November 27, 2015
												TL;DR - Great story/setting, great character customisation, levels/gameplay is fairly linear which restricts the RPG elements of the game, overall a really fun game, worth the money, just have to take it as it is. Before I give my thoughts on this game, I'd like to make it clear that this is the first Shadowrun game I have played, although I am aware of the franchise and it's history. (Tabletop, PC/Console games etc.)Story/Setting: The game overall is pretty solid and good fun. It has a decent story with twists and turns and an amusing ending. You encounter likeable characters and the world is a great representation of Cyberpunk, with it's own take on things with the addition of magic.  Character Customisation:You get to make your own runner at the start of the game and there is a lot to work with from melee characters, armed characters, Deckers (hackers), Riggers (drones), Mages (spells, traps, heal), Shamans (Similar to mages, can also raise spirits, creatures and demons). However where this game shines is you really have the power to go all out with one type of class or mix any of them and make a unique build of your own. (I think I got all the classes correct there. Or near enough!) I'd say this game has great potential for replay value as you could try out all the different classes avaliable, however it wouldn't be something you'd jump straight back into after compleing in my opion, as the story and levels are fairly linear.Mechanics/Gameplay:Everything works as it should in this game and I encountered no issues at all. However I would say the game is a little lacking in RPG elements in my opinion. Let's call it CRPG-Lite! (That was terrible)A couple of areas that came to mind; In conversations you do have the ability to convice, bribe and use etiquettes to persuade and win people over to your side which you would expect with an RPG, but, what I feel was lacking was that you can't really♥♥♥♥♥♥someone off in dialogue or make them hate you and never talk to you again like you can in some RPGs, ultimately conversations (It would appear) all have the same conclusion, you just have little things you can do here and there if you spec'd in charisma, you bribe them or have the correct etiquette.I think this is because the levels and story are fairly linear for an RPG that it can't really give you that freedom. There are oppourtunities that you can miss out on if you give the wrong responses, but in an RPG I want it to be truly diverse in the sense that I can ♥♥♥♥ up an oppurtunity and then I have to go out of my way find another way to achieve my goal/quest. This game ultimately always seems to come to the same conclusion regardless. The other major area that felt a little lacking was the combat, it has the average top down, turn based combat mechanics but I wish it was more like Wasteland 2's. You can get behind cover, but some you can't shoot around, your character literally can't step out with one foot and shoot around a doorway or down a corridor. Just a bit more control over combat and the ability to make better stratergies would have made the combat near-perfect!Other little issues I had were things like not being able to examine the environments other than what the devs wanted you to see. Lack of dialogue/text box like in most RPGs, that displays examine text, Character thoughts and NPC dialogue etc.Overall:Overall this is a really fun game, I played it through in a few days and was pretty glued to it. At first I was a little disappointed with the lack of RPG elements I'm used to, but I quickly accepted that Shadowrun is it's own thing and does it a little differently. I'm really impressed with Harebrained Schemes and that they've successfully brought back Shadowrun. Now I have Dragonfall and Hong Kong to play, and from what I hear they've been improved a lot from this game!

The game worked quite well on Linux (except for the remarks below)  The game was easy to play with keyboard and mouse, but also with the Steam Controller on my TVCON  The game did not handle "exotic" resolutions well. 3200x1800 on my linux laptop and 3440x1440 on my desktop were not manually selectable. Log files mentioned that the game detected the native resolution but a slightly different resolution was chosen. The drop down menu never showed the native resolutions in game. Full HD on my TV was easy.  When contacting the developer's support for the issue above, no support was given. I got an email confirming that they received my email, and that's the last thing that happened.  The loading screens took quite long for a "2D" game. I would expect it to be faster than games like Skyrim?  Classes seem very diverse, but they don't feel diverse.   Leveling is quite boring. Not a lot changes exect for some % to hit etcetera.  Fights are repetitive because there are not a lot of different tactics (necessary). The AI is not very bright.  During combat sequences the game goes turn-based, even when all enemies are killed you still keep walking turn based until you find new enemies in the same environment. Moving your whole team person by person is very tedious.  When going on missions you pay mercs to come with you. They are not very strong or optimal in their configuration, so they felt like dead weight compared to my maxed out SMG fighter.  Hacking/Matrix sequences are very repetitive. Both for the looks of the environment and the variation in enemies and variation in weapons. I just spammed my default attack and nothing else was needed.   The game is very linear. There are not a lot of side quests and you can't explore the world on your own. There is no open world to visit.  Because of the linear gameplay and uninteresting classes, replayability suffers a lot.  The story of the game started out great. It felt like a personal story compared to the "save the world" kind of stories from Skyrim and company. But from the middle of the game it felt like the writers had to keep making the story more elaborate to keep the gamers interested. They created some complex and unnecessary twists that ultimately made me just click faster through the conversation options because I became uninterested.  Those conversations were often very onesided. The choices you make in conversations almost never matter. Most answers are just different forms of the same answer, making conversations very uninteresting. There is no real impact on the game.  The writing of the game is obviously inspired by the Sprawl trilogy, and tiringly so. Every sentence tries to be drearier than the last one. I like film noir and cyberpunk, but this was way too cliché at times.  The world of Shadowrun combines cyberpunk and sci-fi with fantasy. Obviously a lot of people like this, but I'm not really fond of it. It gets worse when they try to mix even more classic (cliché?) game themes in the mix: violent crazy people in an asylum, undead ghouls, monsters and even spirits!! It just lacked some pirates and vampires...  The (hand drawn?) backgrounds were nice from time to time, but they are very empty. There is not a lot of animation or interactivity. The world feels dead.  The music is nice. I mean, the 3 or 4 tracks that are constantly repeated are nice the first time. They sound perfectly in line with the cyberpunk theme, but after having it on repeat for 12 hours, I just disabled the music altogether.   The game is quite short. I finished it in about 12 hours (thoroughly reading everything), and it seems like I'm slow compared to others. Some did it in 8 hours. Sadly, I was happy that it was over.I was looking forward to play the complete Shadowrun series, but after being let down by the first installment, I just can't bring myself to buy the sequels. Even if they are better... Too bad really! I hope that the other famous tactical 2D Kickstarter games like Wasteland 2 and Pillars of Eternity can make up for this game.

Posted: August 2, 2013
												PROPER REVIEW PENDINGWhile I am enjoying this game so far, I cannot recommend this game to anyone except die-hard Shadowrun fans. The gameplay is quite shallow and almost completely linear, the interface is clunky and designed for tablets. There is no exploration, poor documentation, and equipment selection is limited. Dialog choices are meaningless for the most part, and you cannot save the game except for advancing checkpoints, which also means no going back if you missed anything. Fallen enemies disappear and cannot be looted, and class/skill balance is poorly implemented. For a 2 million dollar budget from kickstarter alone this is a disappointment.What Shadowrun Returns really is, is a game engine and development toolkit, whose true merit has yet to be seen, with a short adventure included. This could be a good thing, but only time will tell. I see the potential for great things with this game but in my opinion that is not a selling point at this time for anyone but modders.However, as a Shadowrun fan, I am thrilled to be back exploring the neon lit slums of 2055 Seattle. The level artwork is the highlight, with the music adding to the atmosphere. The 3d character models are quite crude but fit in with the world when you are actually playing, just don't expect to get interesting looking armour for your character. There is no voice acting, but for a video game the writing is a pleasant surprise though that isn't saying much.All said and done, I don't regret preordering Shadowrun Returns, but if you are curious about the setting I recommend picking up one of the books until this game goes on sale.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												A return to to Shadowrun is like coming back to an old friend. I used to play and love "Shadowrun" for the SNES - never played the P&P RPG - but I was too young to fully understand the world and lore. Getting back into it now, the memories have come flooding back to me, along with the old enjoyment I felt of exploring a cyberpunk world full of corporate elves and shadowrunning orks.This is a game without voice actors, without an advanced 3D engine, and without amazing particle effects. It is, however, a game with some fantastic and moody writing (and benefits from no voice actors because of this, IMO), a memorable story, and an ending with great closure. Before I get into pointing out a few things I liked and disliked, if you're a fan of RPGs with a focus on story and setting, this game is for you.I played once through the Dead Man's Switch campaign, and I'm still a little undecided on how I feel about the leveling system. It seems, to me, a little bit simple. It could definitely benefit from some type of "perks" system that you could put points into that allow the gameplay to vary some. As it stands, it's all a bit too straight-forward for my liking, without any real hard decisions to make. if you want to use SMGs and be a decker, you just put karma points into those two stat lines, and that's about it. It's not bad, just not great.The story, however, is wonderful, along with the characters. Coyote is memorable, and I hope to see her appear in the next expansion as well, and it was nice to see Jake Armitage make an appearance early. It really helped ground the game in the Shadowrun lore. There was a bit of a running red herring throughout the story (at least, I'm pretty sure it was), and I was genuinely happy to see the villain turn out a bit differently than I thought.The actual combat is a bit like a simplified version of X-COM. It's turn-based, it utilizes a rudimentary cover system, and it includes magic along with gunplay. It's fun enough, but, along with the leveling system, seems a bit on the simple side, without much variation. This could be alleviated some, I feel, by using scripting to make the combat encounters more interesting. The shoot-out in the cemetery, for example, was easily, IMO, the best encounter of the game as it added variety and surprise in the middle of the fight.And, of course, the editor! I dabbled in this for a number of hours, and it seems perfectly robust and easy to use if you've ever modded games in the past to any extent. I have experience creating modules for Neverwinter Nights, and the Shadowrun Returns editor is mercifully easier to use when scripting, as it gives you the language to select from, instead of you having to discover it yourself.All in all, I definitely recommend this game to those who are either Shadowrun fans, RPG fans that love a good story (and aren't afraid to read as it seems a lot of gamers are these days), or want to create your own stories using the editor. I would give Shadowrun Returns a 7.5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												The good: for a game from a small company, this is quite brilliant. Athmopshere is top-notch, story is very well written, UI and game mechanics are mostly very good, and while some character builds definitely make things much easier, it is possible to play the game through in many different ways.The ambiguous: the game has excellent, relentless pacing, it proceeds like a well-oiled machine. I did appreciate a lot that the playing time was not at any point artificially expanded by making the player travel back and forth in trivial missions of killing and/or collecting umpteen this-or-that. On the other hand, this could also be interpreted as lack of content by some, but the main storyline is so strong and offers so many hours of high-quality content that at least I felt I got my money's worth and then some. Also, given the small budget there is no voice acting; I did not miss it in the slightest, but some may have a different opinion.The bad: there's not much, really. Some aspects of the Shadowrun world are not in the game, but I never missed them, the game is really impressive and highly enjoyable as it is. And it would be nice to have an option to switch the fighting mode on and off, or at the very least be able to switch the active character when not in the fighting mode. Minor things that I almost feel ashamed to bring up, all things considered.TL;DR – 9/10, isometric RPG with very few downsides, loved it.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a digital translation of the pen and paper game. The Shadowrun rulebook contained a short adventure/module/run/gig that served to demonstrate the game's mechanics. In those days it was expected that the GM would make their own runs. In that same way Shadowrun Returns was released with a short run. Soon thereafter the workshop filled with community crafted runs.Please do not look at this game based solely on the released run, look at the community crafted runs as well.Full disclosure: I play this for nostalgic reasons and the low metascore bums me out.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												These still waters run deep.I could try to give this a # out of 10, but I'm not measuring up one game... This isn't just Shadowrun's return... as of this review there are hundreds of other 20+ hour hand-crafted adventures / "expansions" / free fan-made DLC that is every bit as legit as the official campaign.  I'm not quite sure you realize without thinking for a second what that implies.You're getting every "tabletop RPG" story that someone never got to DM physically- virtually and free with the Steam Workshop.  Buying in to a game that only ends if the content is stopped being made.  Even the developers are in on it and expanding the game with the community:https://www.youtube.com/user/HarebrainedSchemes/videosCustomized campaigns made by dedicated gamers including the original SNES title remastered for FREE!Infinite Baldur's Gate sessions with guns and a simpler X-com-esque cover system.Unlimited cyberpunk sagas made by fans for fans forever.There are only a few games like this, such as Torchlight 2, L4D2 where the community members develop the game further than the original team had a capacity for.This game will never end.  You will never EVER finish all of the possible content AND can choose your own adventure(s) in doing so.I LOVE games like this, where it's in our hands... but this time, the developers are here guiding us, building with us, and inspiring us all the while like a good DM does.I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ you thought this game was before reading reviews, but if you sell this title short, you are literally selling short the potential of imagination and role play that this game offers.  Go back to COD, if guns without a reason to fight means that much.  But I'm willing to bet you wouldn't be here reading this review if it wasn't for a well-deserved curiousity and interest, and this game is far more interesting than at first sight.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												As far as turn-based RPGs go, Shadowrun Returns doesn't bring anything new to the table, and its main story mission isn't very long. It makes up for it, though, by still being incredibly fun to play-- the dialogue is cleverly written, the game mechanics are solid, and the world is well-crafted. Fans of the Shadowrun roleplay game will enjoy this, and the fact that it allows for a lot of fan-created missions makes it that much better.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns tells a well-written tale of murder and conspiracy called The Dead Man's Switchstories in its long-dormant sci-fi/fantasy universe. Even though it seems like an open-world RPG, in reality it's really linear, directly funneling you from one mission to the next. There are some well-done puzzles that require information-gathering detective work, and some areas that have problems that can be solved in at least two ways – reprogram a blank access card or steal one. But very few of my decisions in dialogue had any significant impact on how events played out. I liked the great told story and the illustrated pdf with a bunch of stories. It had a cool setting I wanted to explore but couldn't because it was too linear. The light tactical combat on hard was fun and not too challenging. All in all it is a good classic RPG with some well told twists.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												5/10Great customization. Awesome "team-work" possibilities. Interesting and challenging enemies. Fun battles. Smart progression-influenced combat.Awesome tactical-strategy-battle game! Except there is no tactical strategy battles....In a simple analogy... this game is like a dish of Steak n'eggs. Steak, eggs, some fries, some salad and a nice sauce. The waiter comes, shows you a great steak, then place some beautiful sunny-side up eggs and then places the most golden peppered fries you ever seen... When you are watering with anxiety to taste that♥♥♥♥♥♥ he throws the lettuce and tomato salad right at your face and leaves with the rest. Why give me great customization, combat and progression and then throw me 80 hours of text and 5 minutes of battles...Seriously. this game has less than 1 hour of battle and you are still given the option to skip most of them... loli will recommend this game, since the tactical part is really good and worth trying if the game is with a 80% discount.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												After playing through the story of the game and trying a quick mod for it, I would say that I recommend this game.  The lore surrounds you as you play through the game, but isn't so quick to jargon or burying you in references and events non-fans of Shadowrun wouldn't know of that you get lost or overwhelmed.  I think this would serve as a nice introduction for anyone who might be curious about this fantasy world.  One aspect I appreciate most in the game are the various options available to you, depending on what race you play, though more importantly what skills you've focused on leveling.  It allows you to approach situations in different ways, giving greater flexibility.  There is a limit though, with some areas showing more versatility than others.  For instance, as I leveled up and spent my karma points (skill points essentially) I was disappointed that the pistol had so many perks and skills when levelling it up in contrast to any of the other guns.  I focused on the shotgun and I could rain death from afar, but it would have been nice picking up skills along the way instead of only doing more damage from further away.  Perhaps adding a bleeding status effect to enemies or lowering their movement as they limp off from being pumped full of lead.  I liked switching back and forth between the free exploration areas and combat, as having the two modes separated allows you to freely interact with your environment, sometimes just to nose around and other times to advance the story.  Again what is enjoyable is that you have a choice on how you progress in these areas.  Maybe you grease a palm here and there and sneak your way in or try to blow open an entrance.  Nothing huge per se, but you can play a character that way, instead of merely having to go forward in a single straight line.  The combat is pretty simple but it's certainly serviceable.  Once you familiarize yourself with the UI it makes simple sense and allows you to take cover, draw the enemy in, rush them, chuck grenades, cast spells, summon avatars, use melee weapons, or do as I did and blast away with the best guns money can buy.  I'd say my biggest complaint in the game is that there aren't more optional side missions to tackle.  With the way the programming works, with missions having options built-in I can see why it doesn't, but it would be nice to grind more money (not that you'll need it, if you're frugal), earn more karma, and have more to experience.  I kept expecting to see better armor, guns, and body mods available and was disappointed that they seemed to hint at really potent modifications you could use but never built up to.  I held off on getting any for a long time for that reason, wanting to save up my funds for when I could get the really choice items.  Having another level or two of gear would have built up a greater sense of advancement, as by the end you don't have anywhere else to go.All in all I did enjoy the game though and am looking forward to trying other games from this series.  Plus I can try more mods in this one sometime as well.  Maybe run through it all again with a new character build and race.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Shadowrun Returns is in many ways a half-baked game. It's short, not terribly deep, not particularly pretty, and often reminds you that it's a game. Despite this, there's a fantastic deal to like about Shadowrun Returns.Shadowrun Returns (SR) is the second of the major profile video games funded via crowdfunding platform Kickstarter while still in the pre-planning stages to be released. The campaign ran in April 2012, and pulled in about 1.83 million dollars, well over its minimum funding goal of 400,000 dollars. SR is the fourth video game based on the pen-and-paper roleplaying setting Shadowrun, and is the first to not be called simply by its setting's name. The game builds on the story of the first two Shadowrun games - the first released for the SNES, the second on the Genesis - and disregards the third one - released for the 360, PS3 and the PC - on account of it being a multiplayer game with no story.At first glance, Shadowrun is one of the most archetypical cyberpunk settings available in tabletop gaming. It's perpetually rainy, everything is owned by soulless megacorporations, poverty is widespread and the Internet is a world in itself. In a market saturated with these kinds of settings, you need a special something to stand out, and what makes Shadowrun one of the most popular games in the genre is its overlap with standard fantasy. In 2012, magic unexpectedly returned to the world, transforming many humans into dwarves, elves, orcs, trolls, and more. Many were gifted with magical abilities, while dragons awakened from their deep slumber. Two generations later, magic and technology coexist in a society rife with racial (specieal?) tensions and little hope in sight.The game casts you in the down-on-your-luck shoes of one of the eponymous Shadowrunners - a sort of mercenary-slash-master criminal that lives in the cracks of society. Work has been scarce lately after a botched shadowrun, and you are down to your last saved Nuyens when a colleague contacts you about a job. Or, more specifically, the recording of a colleague - as it turns out, your old acquaintance got himself killed, and is contacting you to let you know that his life insurance payout is yours if you will bring his killer to justice. Having no other options, you accept, taking the first step towards unravelling the convoluted mystery behind his death.The simple motivation of trying to get at a former coworker's insurance money is a great story hook. Even the best Shadowrunner is little more than a pawn on the big corporations' boards, and, to mix metaphors, you're little more than a deuce in the Suit of Pawns at this point. As a result, the story is largely personal, and it's up to you if you're just in it for the money, justice or revenge. The interaction is reminiscent of Planescape: Torment, in that much of the environmental interaction is done via dialogue trees or by reading text hovering over the environment, although SR never comes close to Torment's sheer verbosity. All in all, the story is excellently told - it's well-written, has good twists, ups the stakes at the right spots, and has interesting characters. That said, the last third isn't as interesting as the preceding material, as the focus starts to move away from your own story, and it must be noted that there is a complete absence of voice acting in the game - a shame, as the dialogue is superb.Who your character is is up to you - the character creation system is open-ended, and doesn't restrict skills to certain character classes like many RPGs do. Although you may opt to choose one of the ready-made decks, such as the melee-centric Street Samurai or the hacking-oriented Decker, there is no penalty for distributing skill points according to your own preferences instead. You can pick your own name, be male or female, and may choose to be human, elf, dwarf, troll, or orc. The choice of race (species) gives certain minor bonuses and affects the maximum level a particular stat can reach (each skill or subskill is tied to a particular stat, and can't be higher than the stat or skill it's nested under), and you will be treated differently in-game depending on your choice of race (species) and gender. All in all, it's pretty standard stuff for an RPG, but the system is very open, and if you feel like playing as a troll Decker who dabbles in shamanism, go for it.The game is controlled from an isometric perspective, and is divided into two discrete sections: exploration and combat. While exploring, you can only control your own character, and mostly click on objects or non-playable characters to interact with them. There is usually not a lot to interact with, but there is usually just enough to keep exploration rewarding, even if it's just in the form of another description of the environment. Skills and stats are frequently used to solve problems in ways that give better results, although since the game is fairly short, most skills are only used once or twice each. The game is also fairly rigid; the player has little input on how the story plays out, aside from the details. Interestingly, SR does not use an experience point-based system; instead, "karma points" are doled out after completing certain tasks. These points are then spent in the skill tree, improving your character directly. Oddly, "evil" decisions will apparently not yield karma points, which is a strange design choice. That said, there are more than enough karma points to go around.Unlike most CRPGs, SR is a very linear game. Each level is its own microcosm that can't be exited until the game tells you to, and while there are a number of recurring levels throughout the game - most notably the Seamstresses Union, the town-equivalent you visit between missions - most of them occur in sequence; as such, it doesn't feel as if you're returning to places already visited, but rather to different versions of them. This plays into how the game rewards the player as well: on certain levels, skill checks will have become noticably harder, and equipment upgrades will usually by straight numerical improvements. It's somewhat immersion-breaking, as it feels as if you're just being rewarded for the sake of it. In combat, the game switches to what might be termed XCOM-lite mode. The combat is turn-based, with each participant moving their entire party on their turn. Each character has two or three action points, and each point allows you to move a certain amount of squares or perform some other action, such as attack or cast a spell. Scattered throughout the environment are walls and objects that can be used for partial or full cover. If a character is outfitted with a "datajack" they may access the Matrix (the Internet); however, Matrix gameplay is little more than an underdeveloped version of normal combat, and it is a mixed blessing that it is used only maybe half a dozen times, mostly in the second half of the game. Overall, the combat is not outstanding, but it does the job, and it can be rewarding to successfully play off each character's attributes to achieve optimum results. Graphically, the game looks alright. The backgrounds are high-res images, and while not fantastic-looking, they do contribute a great deal artistically to the atmosphere. Sound effects are what you would expect, and the music is mostly moody synthesizer tunes that complement the setting well.Shadowrun Returns may have its rough edges and be a fairly shallow experience at times, but the superb writing, great atmosphere and satisfying gameplay makes it well worth the low price that matches its length. Finally, since tradition dictates I say it: never, ever, cut a deal with a dragon.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Summary:  This is probably the best ShadowRun adaptation to a video game I've ever played.  Fun RPG sci-fi experience packed into a small game.  Gameplay and innovation over pretty effects and graphics.  The game also has a toolset you can use to create your own adventures, which is a bonus.  Even better, you can use the Steam Workshop to download cool stuff other people have made to add massive replay value to the game.  For the price, this game is definitely worth it.Cons:  Short.  I think it took me less than 20 hours to finish.  The graphics are unimpressive, and there is no voiceover or flashy effects that you see in most modern games.  This definitely has a "shoestring budget" feel to it.  Pros:  Great story.  Great storytelling.  It had a very nostalgic feel, and I liked it.  The gameplay was a lot of fun, which trumps everything I listed in the Cons section.  It doens't matter how pretty the game is if it's not any fun to play.  I love turn-based strategy and RPG, and this game blends the two together very nicely.  Lots of latitude on how to shape your character, and multiple ways to finish challenges in the game.  The Shadowrun universe was nicely represented.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I am told Dragonfall is the good stuff, while the original campaign is crude and crappy? Well, I have not played Dragonfall (yet), but I can tell you the original campaign is one of the best RPG stories I have played in a long time. It's a solid (linear) story. Just like the old pen and paper Shadowrun I used to play, you never know where the rabbit hole ends, and if you don't try to rush through it, you are in for one hell of an epic tale that will keep you engaged for several days. There are some difficulty spikes, but never had to retry a mission more than once. You will adapt easily.The engine is functional and effective, the graphics are beautiful, the writting is more than good. The modding tools a huge bonus.One negative aspect: while the atmosphere is well developed, the music is terribly repetitive, specially in combat.EDIT, AFTER PLAYING DRAGONFALLSadly I didn't finish Dragonfall, so what I can say about it is limited. What I can say, however, is that it appeared uninteresting to me to the extent of ultimately dropping it. I didn't really care for the characters and the atmosphere was kind of out of place in my opinion.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Dragonfall is an elegantly constructed true roleplaying game. I have been playing roleplay for 25 years, and I would most definately recommend this plot. The storyline is surprising and detailed. For instance playing the standard nice-paladin-nice and getting all bonus quests etc. simply will not work, you will get comments like "kissass" and will help maniacs if you do. You really have to make true choices all along.NPC interactions are well constructed, but not as good as in Dragonage.Graphics is still primitive, like Baldurs gate 1, with very limited interaction possibilities.The cybersamurai with an Ares Alpha still rules, but if you want more challenge, try playing a mage.Mostly you can use the skills of your team, but sometimes it is impossible to do certain things like looking at a panel in astral space despite having a mage on the team. Total evaluation is 10 on the story. 4 on the graphics. A must-play for true roleplaying fanatics like myself.

Note: This is for the base game only, Dragonfall review is on the standalone Dragonfall game.+: Great graphics for what it is, creates the Shadowrun atmosphere and feel very well.+: The story is pretty great until the end, not that it gets really bad but they just didn't do it as well as it could have been done.+: The gameplay is really solid and this is a solid recreation of the tabletop experience as a turn based strategy RPG.+: People who played the original SNES game will enjoy their homage to it. :)+: Workshop has a bunch of new campaigns you can play for free, some of which are really good.-: There isn't enough choices in this game. Not too much you can do to change the ending much and some skill trees are just out right not useful or far too useful.-: Party members aren't as engaging or as likeable as they should be. Some of them kind of just feel like they are there to round out your party and be better than the people you could hire. Also kind of lame that you can't change their skills or equipment really.-: For anyone who is a Shadowrun fan, they did Harlequin absolutely terribly, it is actually absurd how bad he is in comparison to his tabletop character. This is actually the thing I like the least about this game, but if you aren't a big fan of Shadowrun you won't care/notice the issue.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Returns is wiz. Definitely worth the full $20, and maybe more.Though it lacks many of the finer details and nuances Shadowrun fans expect, Returns is an ambitious jump that promises to bring the world of Shadowrun to a wider variety of players through its accessible gameplay and campaign-building tools. The official campaign is a fast-paced crash course through a uniquely colorful noir world, with the writing and artwork delivering a healthy injection of personality, cosmopolitanism, and humanity to a modern sci-fi genre in dire need of an alternative to geometrically recycled blockbuster epics. Even if the simplistic game mechanics can sometimes seem underutilized or frustrating, Returns opens the gate for a broad range of Shadowrun experiences while providing a definitive introduction to newcomers and welcoming diehard fans.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												I just purchased this during the Autumn sale and I have greatly enjoyed it.  The art style, sound, and gameplay are all great.  The combat is turn-based and very similiar to X-Com: Enemy Unknown.  The story is engrossing and well presented, always leaving me wanting more. I have a few gripes with the game, however.  First, there is no way to currently save your game during missions, which can make for some long and frustrating gameplay sessions.   Secondly, there are some bugs with melee combat.  On one mission, I would use a melee attack and it would not register for 10 seconds.  It's a minor bug but after enough times, it is an annoyance.All and all, for the price, I recommend it and certainly look forward to checking out some of the Steam Workshop mods.EDIT:  Be forewarned, the lack of a quick-save feature can be a major annoyance in missions.  For example, during missions where you go into the Matrix, if you trigger the alarm, you will forever be hutned by more powerful foes.  It is extremely annoying and chances are once you trigger it, you will not be able to overcome the alarm.  The ability to save and reload would have easily negated unnecssary frustration.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game for "old school" gamers who like old school  turn based RPG's :DIt has an awesome art design, and soundtrack, but most important for this type of games, it has tons of text a good quality dialog.Some say it's a short game. Maybe....but i put in 37 hours, and you will find interesting content created by fans with that awesome Editor that comes with game.Story is good. It can keep you on some sort of tension until you reach half of the game. After this moment the story begin to be previsible.It has no loot, and almost zero exploration. Yep, it's quite  linear and story driven game.On the other hand the combat system works flawless, and the skills tree it's original and interesting. But because you can control all your party members, you will play with almost all classes available from first playthrough. So....re-playability is not so good.I recommend this game to those who look for an old school turn-based RPG placed in an original cyberpunk world.

The actual campaign is decent and kept me playing through it to its conclusion, however, the real gem in this game is the level editor.  The ability to create my own content with very few restrictions is what makes a game for me.  There are few developers that give such creative freedom to their fans so I am very pleased that Hairbrained Schemes have gauged their audience well and given us what we desired out of a Shadowrun video game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												Isometric western-style RPG fans rejoice, Shadowrun is back and this time to stay. Comprehensive character creation begins the hero on  their quest to help an old friend. Numerous ways to complete missions in a sprawling city filled with gritty fururistic realism and magical fantasy bring the world of Shadowrun to life unlike has been seen before. The feel of tabletop and the accesability of PC gaming mesh perfectly to make an easy to play and emersive enviroment for the gamer. The characterization of the main character and the runners you choose for your missions can drasticaly alter how you can complete a run. Hack into the matrix to shut down defences while your team defends you and clears the area, cast wild shaman magic to cleanse the technological jungle, construct fireballs from the will of Street Mages to quell thugs: nearly anything is possible.If you are a fan of pen and paper games, the Dungeons and Dragons style isometric PC games (i.e. Baulder's Gate series, Torment) this game will fit nicely into your collection of story-driven RPGs.
