number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												It's really damn good. My opinion is pretty biased though, because I grew up playing Fallout 1 and 2 and other turn-based strategy games with RPG elements.Now, I can't say Shadowrun Returns is excellent in every aspect and it has flaws. Probably the main disappointment about the game is the fact that it's incredibly linear. I think there is only a couple of side-levels and everything else is pretty much traversing through areas from point a to b while killing enemies or talking to people and exploring. All 3 of these aspects are also dumbed down (I can't compare to the original Shadowrun because I haven't played it but the closest that it gets to is Fallout 1/2 for me, actually thinking of it, it's more like Fallout: Tactics). The fighting system is very close to the X-COM one and you've got AP, HP, 2-3 weapon slots and special abilities. Special abilities are presented in a wide variety though: you've got all sorts of♥♥♥♥♥♥- from being a shaman who summons stuff to a decker who can hack computers and transfer himself into cyberspace.Dialogues and social interactions aren't voiced (obviously) and suffer from being linear too. Most of the time you'll find yourself looking at 3 options and they all mean the same but the NPC reacts differently to each one. There are also some special charisma/etiquette-based options that pop-up every now and then, too.Exploring is stripped to its bare minumum as you've got levels filled with NPCs and sometimes promps would show up telling that there's something lying in a room: either a quest item or equipment. I've just covered all of the negative things. That's it. Everything else that's in the game provides a really cool experience: let it be the soundtrack of the game, its story or its world. It also has workshop support! Final verdict: if you see this game below 10$ and even just a tiny bit interested - go ahead and check it out.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a beautifully crafted game, with an amazing job with the story and setting. Based off of the roleplaying game, Shadowrun; You the player create your own Runner. A freelancer. A Merc. A person who's whole purpose is to make money doing the seedier things that society dust under the carpet.With this game, it provides an interesting media to portray your antics. Allowing for most situations to be handled however you want to. Want to hack a turret to fight for you? You can. Want to mow down enemies with a machine gun? Have fun trying. Want to charm enemies into allies, or summon elementals to fight for you? Get started sparky. This game does a great job bringing in just about every aspect of the roleplaying game. Mind you, it does have some constraints.You are following a premade story, so there are limits on what you can and can't do. But with the addition of Daggerfall, you get a little bit more freedom with how you do the story.In the end, the graphics are nice. Music is very fitting for the setting, and the story is wonderful. The fact that it has a user workshop and the tools to make your own story is also greatly appreciated. There are many nicely made user stories out there, and most allow you to bring in your Runner from the main campaigns. Which really does fit well with the idea of the original game. So overall, I give it a 8.5/10. And remember kids, don't trust anybody. Not even your closest friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												“Deux Ex” meets “Arcanum” — and there are few ways to see that.Most obvious is the setting. Cyperpunk with magic, elves, orcs, dwarves, etc. Though I am not a huge fan of fantasy, it goes perfectly in such a blend. And the world lives. People react to latest events, there is a sense in visiting your acquaintances over and over.Then, “Shadowrun” has a great story with lots of thoroughly written dialogues, impressive characters and plot bends, turns and twists. The tale that is told is mature, but not over the top gore fest (just the right amount of gore fest!). And the soundtrack is appropriately nice.Then, there are many ways to complete each task. They depend on what class you choose — there are some of more classical ones and some more setting-specific, or you can create your own character build, selecting your own mix of skills. Beside that game gives you many choices to solve tasks — governed by how much you are willing to explore, dive into story and the world, in wide sense — globally, and narrow — in a current mission and location.Overall a great experience for someone who like aforementioned classics and doesn’t mind reading lots of text. Like a book, y’know. Where you shoot and burn people.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												These still waters run deep.I could try to give this a # out of 10, but I'm not measuring up one game... This isn't just Shadowrun's return... as of this review there are hundreds of other 20+ hour hand-crafted adventures / "expansions" / free fan-made DLC that is every bit as legit as the official campaign.  I'm not quite sure you realize without thinking for a second what that implies.You're getting every "tabletop RPG" story that someone never got to DM physically- virtually and free with the Steam Workshop.  Buying in to a game that only ends if the content is stopped being made.  Even the developers are in on it and expanding the game with the community:https://www.youtube.com/user/HarebrainedSchemes/videosCustomized campaigns made by dedicated gamers including the original SNES title remastered for FREE!Infinite Baldur's Gate sessions with guns and a simpler X-com-esque cover system.Unlimited cyberpunk sagas made by fans for fans forever.There are only a few games like this, such as Torchlight 2, L4D2 where the community members develop the game further than the original team had a capacity for.This game will never end.  You will never EVER finish all of the possible content AND can choose your own adventure(s) in doing so.I LOVE games like this, where it's in our hands... but this time, the developers are here guiding us, building with us, and inspiring us all the while like a good DM does.I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ you thought this game was before reading reviews, but if you sell this title short, you are literally selling short the potential of imagination and role play that this game offers.  Go back to COD, if guns without a reason to fight means that much.  But I'm willing to bet you wouldn't be here reading this review if it wasn't for a well-deserved curiousity and interest, and this game is far more interesting than at first sight.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Linear BEV solo(offline) RPG.  With that said, worth about 12 hours of entertainment if you're into the genre.  Be you a street tough cyberer'd Samurai dicing up thugs with your sword, or an elite decker hacking the matrix to make your Nuyen.  Nostalgic fans will enjoy a shadowrun leveling system with a few new tweaks.There may be a few flaws.  There's little replay value in the campaign, as the storyline pushes you through with almost no sandboxing.  The game gives you freedom to pick your shadowrunners, yet seems to lack a certain feel of customization and increasing gains like most other RPG types.  No real stopping to grind out some shadowruns for Mr. Johnsons as in previous video game incarnations.  Some obvious bugs and crashes, but nothing to get too worked up over.All in all, a pretty decent reboot.  (P.S. the deluxe version doesn't include an additional campaign - just some soundtracks & PDF text)

content:
Posted: March 9
												After playing through the story of the game and trying a quick mod for it, I would say that I recommend this game.  The lore surrounds you as you play through the game, but isn't so quick to jargon or burying you in references and events non-fans of Shadowrun wouldn't know of that you get lost or overwhelmed.  I think this would serve as a nice introduction for anyone who might be curious about this fantasy world.  One aspect I appreciate most in the game are the various options available to you, depending on what race you play, though more importantly what skills you've focused on leveling.  It allows you to approach situations in different ways, giving greater flexibility.  There is a limit though, with some areas showing more versatility than others.  For instance, as I leveled up and spent my karma points (skill points essentially) I was disappointed that the pistol had so many perks and skills when levelling it up in contrast to any of the other guns.  I focused on the shotgun and I could rain death from afar, but it would have been nice picking up skills along the way instead of only doing more damage from further away.  Perhaps adding a bleeding status effect to enemies or lowering their movement as they limp off from being pumped full of lead.  I liked switching back and forth between the free exploration areas and combat, as having the two modes separated allows you to freely interact with your environment, sometimes just to nose around and other times to advance the story.  Again what is enjoyable is that you have a choice on how you progress in these areas.  Maybe you grease a palm here and there and sneak your way in or try to blow open an entrance.  Nothing huge per se, but you can play a character that way, instead of merely having to go forward in a single straight line.  The combat is pretty simple but it's certainly serviceable.  Once you familiarize yourself with the UI it makes simple sense and allows you to take cover, draw the enemy in, rush them, chuck grenades, cast spells, summon avatars, use melee weapons, or do as I did and blast away with the best guns money can buy.  I'd say my biggest complaint in the game is that there aren't more optional side missions to tackle.  With the way the programming works, with missions having options built-in I can see why it doesn't, but it would be nice to grind more money (not that you'll need it, if you're frugal), earn more karma, and have more to experience.  I kept expecting to see better armor, guns, and body mods available and was disappointed that they seemed to hint at really potent modifications you could use but never built up to.  I held off on getting any for a long time for that reason, wanting to save up my funds for when I could get the really choice items.  Having another level or two of gear would have built up a greater sense of advancement, as by the end you don't have anywhere else to go.All in all I did enjoy the game though and am looking forward to trying other games from this series.  Plus I can try more mods in this one sometime as well.  Maybe run through it all again with a new character build and race.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												The good: for a game from a small company, this is quite brilliant. Athmopshere is top-notch, story is very well written, UI and game mechanics are mostly very good, and while some character builds definitely make things much easier, it is possible to play the game through in many different ways.The ambiguous: the game has excellent, relentless pacing, it proceeds like a well-oiled machine. I did appreciate a lot that the playing time was not at any point artificially expanded by making the player travel back and forth in trivial missions of killing and/or collecting umpteen this-or-that. On the other hand, this could also be interpreted as lack of content by some, but the main storyline is so strong and offers so many hours of high-quality content that at least I felt I got my money's worth and then some. Also, given the small budget there is no voice acting; I did not miss it in the slightest, but some may have a different opinion.The bad: there's not much, really. Some aspects of the Shadowrun world are not in the game, but I never missed them, the game is really impressive and highly enjoyable as it is. And it would be nice to have an option to switch the fighting mode on and off, or at the very least be able to switch the active character when not in the fighting mode. Minor things that I almost feel ashamed to bring up, all things considered.TL;DR – 9/10, isometric RPG with very few downsides, loved it.

												5/10Great customization. Awesome "team-work" possibilities. Interesting and challenging enemies. Fun battles. Smart progression-influenced combat.Awesome tactical-strategy-battle game! Except there is no tactical strategy battles....In a simple analogy... this game is like a dish of Steak n'eggs. Steak, eggs, some fries, some salad and a nice sauce. The waiter comes, shows you a great steak, then place some beautiful sunny-side up eggs and then places the most golden peppered fries you ever seen... When you are watering with anxiety to taste that♥♥♥♥♥♥ he throws the lettuce and tomato salad right at your face and leaves with the rest. Why give me great customization, combat and progression and then throw me 80 hours of text and 5 minutes of battles...Seriously. this game has less than 1 hour of battle and you are still given the option to skip most of them... loli will recommend this game, since the tactical part is really good and worth trying if the game is with a 80% discount.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												A very loyal take on the the ol' dice-n-paper RPG I begrudgingly played during high school and college. I had a strong dislike for FASA's SR family-friendly cyberpunk lite (at the time I was reading a lot of Gibson and Sterling), and I always found its allusions street culture hokey and painfully suburban; also a pretty good description of my college RPG group.That was a long time ago, however. Now I can just enjoy this for it's silliness, which SR RETURNS has in abundance! This game moves along well, has a very low learning curve, and is fun right away. If you grew up on SR like me, you will be delighted to see plenty of NPCs from the earliest editions of the dice and paper game. A fun diversion for about 20 hours or so; I am looking forward to acquiring new stories / campaigns to play.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Very good turn-based game, but not so good as an rpg, I expect more of the next campaings since I cant use the workshop (it simple crashes after i try to make a new content). As for my opinion concerning the rpg genre, the thing is: in the main story your choices doesnt really matter, because it is pretty strait-foward you do as your told, or you cant progress. It is like a GM that doesnt know really how to embrace multiple possibilities. For instance, you cant change alliances, jobs, take a lot of side quests (almost none, almost), fully specialize your character (obs.: it will cost you a lot of patience, since you always need to explore, out of combat, in the front lines - a support mage doesnt explore in the front lines, period). The same problem about specialization happens in player-made content, not to mention that ranged combat is far superior than melee in this game, to have a good melee combatant, on par with a ranged, you need twice as much karma and money, I think it is pretty unballanced, but possible to fix it.One important thing to mention is: browsing through the player-made content it became pretty obvious that the publishers can make the game much more interesting in terms of choice, exploring, loot, etc. They did a very good job on the writing, but not so much on the rpg.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												The good:+ The world is interesting, and looks great. Has this kind of style that feels gritty, dark, and unique.+ You can really seem to play whatever kind of character you want (at least on normal).+ Combat on normal is not hard, but just hard enough that you might die randomly. I feel like it’s a good mix for just a casual gamer.+ Not too long. No unnecessary grinding. To the point. Play through took like 12 hours or so.The story:- The story isn’t anything special. There are some nice twists, but parts feel sort of disjointed like there was bigger ideas that just never quite made it in to the game.- The game does not always do a good job explaining some of the mechanics but really if you are playing on easy or normal you’ll pick it up relatively quickly and many of the mechanics are present in future games.- I feel like even scaled up the text is generally smaller than I would like.- Ssome wonky interface stuff. For example healing other team members in between combat.TLDR;An interesting 2d isometric cypberpunk rpg. Not the greatest RPG I have played, and certainly not the worst. I don’t have very strong feelings on the game, others in the series are better, but this one is OK and probably worth a play.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												A solid game, but not as amazing as a lot of sources seem to say.On the upside, it's very well-written, the setting is well-realized, and there is a lot of room for modding and extra scenarios and whatever. The core system is bland, but playable, and the game did not feel too hard or too easy - things were fairly easy on normal difficulty so long as I moved tactically, used cover, and had my team give each other cover.On the downside, combat all gets very samey, and turn-based combat is not the fastest thing The story the game comes with is awfully linear and does not feel, for lack of a better term, very 'Shadowrun-y' to me. Those two things may be related, as being a Shadowrunner is kind of about freedom, isn't it?Anyway. Good game. Not great. Certainly reccomend giving it a try for fans of turn-based RPGs.

												Shadowrun is good. Making a kitchensink setting isn't always easy (after all, this is magic AND cyberpunk) and making Shadowrun games is even harder. But this is good. I liked the first campaign a little more than Dragonfall, but that might be a side effect of some technical issues (and some incredibly bad luck at dice rolling). The main issue I have with the game is visuals. While the character portraits are supremely good and backgrounds look good more often than not, combat leaves a lot to be desired. While the character models are good enough, especially when viewed from so far away, the combat animations are lacklustre. And the greatest shame is how spells bland and impactless the spells look. Other thant that, it's a very good RPG that should not be missed.

												If you enjoy tactical turn based combat and compelling storylines this game is for you.Pros:-Great writing-Fun turn based tactical combat-Greater than average ability to feel like your character's skills and the choices for specialization matter-Unique setting that if you're not familiar with may definetly be worth losing 30-40 hours in-Great RPG giving a mix of storytelling and classic character building-Player generated content that adds replayabilityCons:-Lots of writing (do not play if reading text makes you bored)-No multiplayer (I sincerely hope they add in co-op multiplayer in future DLC, but I understand why it is not currently a part of the game as they have focused on creating an immersive single player environment with compelling companions, but as anyone who has played tabletop RPG's in the past knows, a large part of the fun of these games is being able to run around with your friends attempting to complete the various tasks of a shadowrunner)Other Points of Interest:-I strongly recommend not playing Dragonfall until you have completed Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign) Not only is dead man's switch a better intro to the universe + mechanics, but after playing Dragonfall you will not want to go through Dead man's switch because it will feel like a tracked, clunky version of Dragonfall-If you're not really sure if you're interested in the gameplay go look up the Shadowrun Universe, because a large part of what makes this game great is how well they portrayed it, and if off the bat you don't like things like the idea of decking, the implementation of magic, or the way that orks, trolls, elves, and dwarves came into existence, chances are that you will continue to be annoyed by whatever annoyed you in a text based RPG.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I'm proud to say that I contributed to this game's initial Kickstarter campaign.  It delivers a solid turn-based-tactical-RPG experience, and it paints a beautiful-if-grim-and-gritty image of the Shadowrun setting, and it tells a solid story in the process.For the uninitiated, the setting of Shadowrun is a dystopian future in which corporations rule the world and governments are beholden to the whim of these international corportations.  Magic, and all the fantastic creatures that come with it, reentered the world in the early 2000s.  And in all of this, a 'shadowrunner' is a mercenary who is hired to use their guns, magic, muscle, computer hacking, or remote-controlled drones on a job-by-job basis.One of the neat tricks that this game pulls is that different types of character literally see the world differently.  A mage can see ley lines on the ground that can bolster their magic (or that of their enemies!) if they stand on them.  A shaman can see spirits lingering in the world, ready to be called into battle.  A decker (read: hacker, who have neural interfaces in this world) can see hackable computers.  Okay, I think that anyone can see hackable computers, but you need a decker to get into them.Without revealing any spolers, I'd like to say that the story in the original game is solid.  It's nothing to write home about, but it makes for a great introduction to the setting, and fans of Shadowrun video games will see a familiar face.  The story in the expansion - which, by the way, was at least as long as the original campaign, and I've sunk 82 hours between the two of them - is, on the other hand, phenomenal.  Both games have great characters, although be warned that there's no voice-acting - if you demand that from your stories you should be aware of its absence.  The dialogue is similar to Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights - style, although if your character doesn't have the skills needed to engage in a particular line of dialogue, that line and its requirement show up, greyed out, so you know how to build your character next time.Of course, the game also comes with a level editor, and Steam Workshop support.  This was one of the big features touted during its Kickstarter.  I'm not immediately seeing a link to the editor from Steam but it's in the same folder as the game files.  I have not put this to the test but I'm told that it's a very powerful toolset.The combat system is interesting.  The greatest depth can be found in building your main character and selecting a squad for each mission as there is quite a bit of variety available in a character's skill-set.  Once you're on the ground there's still quite a few decisions to make, from where to take cover, to how tightly to pack your squad, to when and where to expend your consumable resources.  Personally, I found the game to be a smidge too easy on Normal difficulty, even when I realized that my character concept wasn't a particularly strong one in this universe.  There were two harder (and one easier) difficulties that I didn't try.Visually, the game performs solidly.  It's a nice, clean (well, grimy) - looking game, but it won't turn any heads for reasons other than the unusual setting.  The developers had other priorities, and they're priorities that I happen to agree with.Shadowrun Returns delivers a passable audio experience.  The game sounds great, all of the effects sound like I imagine they should...but there could really, really be more variety in background music.  What is there sounds wonderful, but I for one was tired of hearing the same music for every battle by the end of it.  Again, if you can't stand reading text, pass this one up, because it has no voice-overs whatsoever.All in all, I would heartily recommend this game to RPG fans, turn-based strategy fans, and Shadowrun fans alike.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Rather simplistic but fun RPG in the world of Shadowrun. It's simplistic because you can't change anything in the story, there is no branching you can't take different directions. There are no side quests. It's also rather short.Yet i'd say that it's easily worth playing, because what Harebrain does well is imagining the world, creating a story in that world, putting interesting characters in that story, writing fascinating background stories for the characters, etc. etc.. And these are all here and very well done.The combat is turn based and it works quite well, although it gets a bit boring at the endgame, where ther's basically no talking involved just shotting through dozens of baddies. The leveling system is plain, but gets the job done, you can create very divers characters from the shaman through the decker (hacker) there are lots of variations....and then there's the Dragonfall campaign:They listened to their fans and vastly improved upon the original campaign. The writing, the characters (my companions here are the most memorable video game characters since I don't even know when), the story, hell even the gameplay is a lot better. There is a central hub now, where you can take side quests, make donations, buy stuff or just converse with random residents. Almost every main mission involves at least one serious choice too.Everything that was missing from the original campaign is right here in an almost perfect package. Definitely one of the best DLCs I've ever played.One important warning though: There's lots of reading involved in both campaigns, so if you want non-stop action this is not for you!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												7.5/10Excellent story.  Very interesting campaigns.Gameplay is a little wanting.Graphics aren't the best, but they could be worse.  A lot of animations are reused and somewhat boring.Access to steam workshop so there is replayability and extra gameplay.Story:The original campaign "Dead Man's Switch" is relatively well written with an interesting plot which morphs and changes the further you go starting with something mundane and ending with bizarre.  It is extremely linear with very little in the way of optional quests not related to the story.  The ones that do exist often times are just there for flavor giving no benefit to the player.  However the finale to the campaign was very entertaining, though the ending was somewhat of a let down compared to the build up.The DLC campaign "Dragonfall" was a surprisingly well written story.  It ties together a number of different plots in such a way as to make the whole much greater than the sum.  There is a lot more in the way of optional quests compared to "Dead Man's Switch", but the story is still pretty linear since your likely going to have to do most of those "optional" quests in order to advance the story anyway.  This isn't to say that it's a bad thing.  Like I said, the plot for Dragonfall is very satisfying with excellent pacing, a surprising amount of flavor, and a number of plot twists which send a shiver down your spine including an ending with interesting ramifications for the world.  As a side note, the game played excellently in hard mode, though there are two sections in the game which I know a lot of people had trouble on.Gameplay:The gameplay is shallow compared to more familiar RPGs.  The selection of skills is rather small and the abilities associated with the skills are very basic.  Magic is a little more interesting, but for the most part many spells are very similar with many offensive spells having little variation between them.  Fighting in Shadowrun can be satisfying, but what really detracts from it is the way your character gains experience.  Instead of the basic XP system your character gains a resource called "Karma" as you complete quests, optional objectives, and other events.  The problem I have is that fights give you virtually nothing in terms of Karma.  This makes a number of fights just something to get through knowing that your likely not to get a reward.  I assume it has something to do with the nature of the resource in the game.Issues:There are a number of gameplay mechanics that are either under utilized, not working, or simply missing.  Etiquettes are a way of slightly customizing your character giving you access to some player decisions and conversation topics which almost always gives you either some sort of advantage or extra flavor to the game.  However in both campaigns, certain etiquettes are virtually ignored throughout the entire story making its choice a complete waste to the player.  For some reason some abilities available to a player are not shown in the character skill progression.  An example is all of the throwing skills you can use despite nothing indicating that they are available when increasing your throw skill.  Another thing I found issue with is the complete inability to decide which of my characters would pick up an item when out of combat.  That's right, your able to manually get your individual characters to pick up items in combat, but as soon as your out of it those items may as well be useless if your main character has a full inventory while your partners sit there with empty slots.  Which also brings up the topic of why aren't you able to enter the combat phase at will?  This would let you set up for fights such as getting in position, setting up buffs, and being able to get your partners to do things that you can't such as pick up an item or using their character skills.  The game gets around some of this by forcing the combat phase, but it would be better if you could manually enter combat phase yourself.Despite these issues which make the game seem as if it was left undone in some areas the story is, again, excellent.  It may not be worth the current full price to some, but if it's on sale I would recommend trying it out.  This is especially true in the case of Dragonfall, which will require the base game.  It should also be noted that you will also have access to the steam workshop which has a number of community made campaigns and scenarios available as well as the ability to make your own campaign should you so wish it.7.5/10Excellent story.  Very interesting campaigns.Gameplay mechanics are a little wanting.Graphics aren't the best, but they could be worse.  A lot of animations are reused and somewhat boring.Access to steam workshop allowing for replayability and extra gameplay.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a science fantasy turn based tactical RPG. It takes place in the Shadowrun universe from the fantasy tabletop RPG game. It was successfully crowd funded through Kickstarter and it peaked my interest. I hadn't played a game that fit this discription before and was a little hesitant. A friend of mine highly recommended it to me. Later I got it on sale and had a quick look. I loved it. I finished the first campaign; 'Dead Man's Switch' over a few days. I was fully immersed in this new universe and I loved every second of it. I had control over my character, I decided who I wanted to be and what I wanted to train in. Then I learnt about a DLC for the game called 'Dragonfall'. I thought it might just be a small add on to the game. It's not it's another full length campaign. The Dev's listened to the feedback of the Shadowrun community, what they liked and what they didn't. From there they started to make a second campaign; 'Dragonfall'. I started playing that and it was even better than the first campaign. I thought, could this get any better? Well it did. The Dev's are in the process of releasing a Directors Cut of 'Dragonfall', which includes even more improvments and changes that the community have been asking for. Plus for people who have already bought the original 'Dragonfall' you can get the Directors Cut for free. So I highly recommend this game. It has an amazing, immersive storyline which has been brought to life by people who want to stay true to their fans and the original Shadowrun universe.

Posted: August 12, 2014
												The setting is new to me, so I can't comment on it, other than, you know, it's got sodding orks and elves in it, like every other vaguely fantasy setting, even if this one is cyberpunk. The combat is very new x-com-esque, and will probably scratch that itch if you're needing a tactical fix. I rather enjoyed it.Pros:- Functional story with a few twists and good writing (we're not talking Torment good, but there's nothing to cringe at)- Good range of character options with no single thing being mega OP- Deep without being overwhelming turn-based combat system which offers plenty of options- Lets you choose your team of level-appropriate mercs, freeing you from managing loads of characters skillsheetsCons:- Leaves you to read the tutorials tucked away in the menu rather than explaining the systems (possibly a plus if you're old school and find modern tutorials slow)- Decker classes are probably awesome the 2 or 3 times you need them to do their matrix thing, but have limited options in the real world, largely due to the lack of computers in most environments and effectiveness of shooting things instead- Arguably too easy if you use the options available to you: none of my characters ever came close to dying in the campaign, but this was normal mode and it's possible I'm a tactical genius and didn't notice.- A special weapon required for the final mission is intentionally short ranged and small-magazined. This is slightly annoying.- (Possibly a tiny bit on the short side for those used to epic RPGs, but there's no filler here, so I'll take no issues with it)I'm told the new campaign is even better, which sounds pretty good to me: wishlisted, as the cool kids probably don't say.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Imagine a world filled with your wildest imaginations. A futuristic world where humans, trolls, dwarves, elves, and orks exist and live together. Imagine the presence of mages, cybernetic freaks, skilled hackers, deadly swordsmen, chi-casting masters, wicked shamans, and one-shot marksmen. No, let's not stop there! Imagine an organized group of people called Shadowrunners, who take missions from clients, avoid the influences of corrupt businesses, and lurk in the shadows. All of these ideas I mentioned are the world of Shadowrun Returns.   Shadowrun Returns is an immersive, intelligent, and fun game that is influenced by many references. It's a strategy cyberpunk RPG game that gives you freedom. In order to keep this review short and sweet, I'll make a Positives vs. Negatives list of Shadowrun Returns. POSITIVES:   -Main campaign has an engaging story that dives you into the mystery of your friend's murder. DLC campaign also has an engaging story that makes you uncover the secrets about an infamous dragon and the chosen one who defeated it.   -Twists and turns occur just when you think the story is over   - Lots of Races to choose from right from the get-go (Human, Elf, Troll, Ork, Dwarf). Each have special qualities and set-ups.   - Lots of Classes to choose from right from the get-go (Street Samuari, Decker, Shaman, Mage, Physical Adept, Rigger). Each have special qualities and differ in gameplay.   -A wide cast of characters who are surprisingly relatable and interesting   -A DLC campaign (Purchased Separately) that explains an aspect of the story more and provides a different experience from the main campaign. The DLC campaign is about as long as the main campaign. The DLC can be longer if you do all the side content there.   - Complex world with interesting atmopsheres. Game created its own terms (ex; chummer, nuyen) and has its own glossary in-game. Shadowrun is a combination of A LOT of influences. The decker class is heavily based on a book.   - Karma system (Skill tree) that enhances gameplay and abilities   - Game allows you to choose multiple conversation paths, making the plot more immersive.   - Depending on what class, race, and ability you pick, you will have more options to choose from when you converse with NPCs   - Some side content is avaiable in both campaigns   - Has a User-Generated Content system, which adds replayability value and allows the players to create their own stories and levels (just like the developers!)   - You can save ALMOST anytime (Can't save between conversations). There are also autosaves.   - You can hire other Shadowrunners to experience other classes and accomplish missions.   - Solid and unique RPG gameplay that is easy to learn   - Difficulty is scaled well, especially at the end of the game   - About 20 hours of content in main campaign. About 30 hours of content in DLC campaign. More hours of content when playing/making user-generated content.   - Solid musicNEGATIVES:     -Game doesn't have a lot of side content, making it seem linear at times.    -Sometimes, the game can get too complex in background story. (Might be just me)    -Occasional glitches and bugs, especially with the user-generated content.Of course the game has negatives, but look at how the positives outweigh them! I played about 50 hours of this game by playing the main campaign, the DLC campaign, and one of the user-generated content. I could easiy generate more hours by replaying the campaigns with a different class or trying out a new user-generated content. This game is worth trying out and it's definitely worth the price. I'll say the DLC is recommended too because it does flesh out some background of the story and it gives a fresh approach to the world of Shadowrun. Also, I'm sure I'm missing some positives and negatives because this game has a TON of content to explore. This game is amazing and I'm glad to play it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												So, I never played the paper based version of this game although it was something I was aware of in my teens,  I picked this up in the Steam Summer Sale as something of an impulse purchase and, idly lookng for something to play fired it a week or too back and I've been playing it ever since.It's set in a sort of post-apocalyptic future world where after magic reawakens and the world is suddenly awash with Magic, Elves, Dwarves, Trolls and all the trappings of standard fantasy tropes, but retains guns, computers and technology. If you have ever read William Gibson's Neuromancer (and if not, why not?) then it's that world. But with magic. Governments have seemingly collpased, Dragons run rampant and Mega-Corporations now run the world. Into this your little band of mercenaries - shadowrunners - instigate heists, perform assassinations and generally do whatever they can to survive.Gameplay wise it's basically the Fallout & Fallout 2 model - you explore your environment and find stuff to do and, more often than not, end up in a turn based combat system. There are plenty of different character classes to choose from, ranging from street samuri (your tanks) to battle mages, shamen, Deckers (these guys are your computer experts and hack into "the matrix" (which is exacly what it sounds like)) and RIggers - guys who control robots to do their fighting. There are others too, and you can specialise how you like even mixing classes if you want to - although the jack of all trades is master of none, especially in this world. As you progress you earn Karma to spend on skills that your character class uses to improve and become much more effective in-game.The game is very solid - graphics are solid  for a kickstarted game, there are few minor bugs but nothing major - and the game stands very much on the quality of it's writing, which is very good indeed. The first campaign from the kickstarter (Dead Man's Switch) is very involving, and although I thought it lost its way towards the end at least gets you there - you'll want to know how it's all going to end. The combat system works as well - you'll be using cover, buffing your team mates and working out how to get the drop on your opponents. However it lacks some character development (for example you can only hire other shadowrunners, so you don't develop a team you get to know) and outside of the main quest there isn't much else to do. You can explore a bit, maybe find a few fetch quests but that's it. The expansion DLC Dragonfall is where this game is at though. It maintains the quality of the writing, it's got proper character development and you get a team of shadowrunners to get to develop and know as the game progresses. There are plenty of missions outside the main mission, with some real decisions (and consequences) to work through as you take them on. The main hub you retreat too a large area with plenty of other NPCs to chat to, some of who will give you some side missions, others of whom need you help.  It is a great little RPG and really deserves a lot of praise. Where game falls down is in two areas - there are too many character classes to choose from and to be honest many of them are essentially identical - only one set of classes use technology and other use magic. The only distinct class are the Deckers, but unfortunately the Matrix sections of the game are distinctly underwhelming - you basically run around a white wireframe world while red blobs shoot at you - and it doesn't really work. I have a lot of sympathy for the developers there - short of developing an entire differnt game for the Matrix bits I'm not sure what else they could have done - but it does sell the game very short.However don't let that put you off - there aren't many of them and the Dragonfall campaign leaves them entirely optional.Finally th developer has released a full editor suite of tools for you to make your own campaigns and release for public consumption. As good as they are, the developer campaigns aren't that long (Maybe 12 hours or so to complete) and so having fans with the ability to make their own efforts gives this game a lot more replayability. Some of the ones released so far are pretty damn good - Ashron's 'From the Shadows, Run' being a particular stand out.So yes, this is a good game with a lot of longevity. If you liked the original fallouts, Jagged Alliance, XCOM etc then you'll love this. It's got a few rough edges to be sure but they don't detract from the main game and it is more than worth a purchase.

												This is a xcom-like tactics game RPG. You control one main character that can hire mercenaries to attack various corporations. It is important to know that the game is extremely linear and that the original campaign doesn't have any forks. The levels themselves are tiny usually made out of less than 10 rooms. The combat is really fun with lots of special skills and weapon choices. However for some reason there is no shared inventories and you cannot trade except outside of mission. Also decker mercenaries (hackers) for some reason cannot assist you when you need something hacked. If your main char does not have the skill you are out of luck. I would say skip shadowrun returns and only play Dragonfall expansion. But that is not possible unfortunately. 7/10

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Review from a perspective of somebody who never played the original.  I guess this is also like a D&D tabletop thing too?  I came in pretty clueless.  It's a fun RPG with an interesting combat system, lots of skills and abilities, and several races with different stats and whatnot, so you've got the standards down.  The murder mystery campaign mode that comes with the game is good, although extremely linear, most sidequests come down to maybe opening a door or talking to an NPC slightly to the left.  Characters are also lacking, most of the interesting ones never join your party, leaving you with a few named characters from the story and a barrage of filler with one line each.The game universe is this weird mishmash of things, where I suppose the writers decided to throw every setting (Post Apocalyptic, Cyberpunk, Magic, Tolkeiny Fantasy Creatures, Urban Underworld) they could think of together.  And to their credit, it's not bad.  It's certainly weird, but not bad.  Some of the "standard future slang" makes its way in, though, so if you cringe like me everytime you read "fracking", some characters will be intolerable.  Shotgun toting dwarves and troll hackers aside, there's a lot to work with here, and the campaign editor is apparently fairly robust, so some good stuff should come out, likely for free on the Workshop.  Mechanically there are some mistakes.  I would have liked to rotate the camera in the fight scenes, and the saving system pretty much requires you to play through a single scene in one sitting, but there's a lot of fun to be had here.  The combat works well, kinda like XCOM or Final Fantasy Tactics, and the story has kept me interested so far.I wouldn't pay full price, but on sale, if it sounds interesting, pick it up and try it out.  I haven't even touched the usermade stuff yet, but it looks promising.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is an amazing game that has changed nothing from the deep and storied flavor of classic Shadowrun.  As a matter of fact, the original story mode from the SNES game that this iteration is based off of is available as a downloadable mission in the game's Steam Workshop.  Shadowrun will leave you empowered, deadly, and begging for more distopian Seattle to conquer.  Gameplay is perfect in that it gives the player the option to perform actions as they see fit, in whatever order they want, much in the vein of Final Fantasy Tactics.  For example, where as a lot of turn based strategy games require that the player move, and then attack in phases, Shadowrun Returns allows player characters to take their turns together, and spend action points in any order the player wants.  You can move a character and then attack, attack and then move, attack multiple times, use multiple abilities, or move as much as you want, provided you have the action points for it.  Want to heal a character and attack with them?  Spend an action to move them to your medic, switch to your medic to heal them, then switch back to the first character, and walk them back in to combat guns blazing.  Not all fighting revolves around gunplay and magical blasts of death however.  Tired of only having the choice to convince the bad guy to give him self up of his own volition, or decide for him at gun point?  Plug into one of the cyberpunk futures numerous netscape access-points, hack police scanners and lead them to him, all while draining his bank accounts so he can't run, and forwarding his personal emails to the press so no-one wants to help him.  Just watch out for police and bank corporation hired player eating AI that roam the netscape looking for unwary hackers to slay.  But combat isn't all that Shadowrun Returns has to offer; where it really shines is it's role playing element.  Based off of the original pen and paper game that made Shadowrun so popular, you will spend most of your time in dialogue with other characters.  Don't expect the "wall of text" storytelling present in most "story driven" games though.  The player doesn't watch the story unfold, but instead dictates what happens next through their own brand of in-character interaction with their world.  Don't like the way that gang banger is shaking down that poor shop owner?  Flex your muscles, and smile a fanged grin to let him know that no matter how much he steals, it won't be enough to pay for his hospital bills, or if that's not your style give him a heads up about the police cruiser making rounds around the block to convince him that it's not worth his time.  Or if that's still not your style, and you'd rather make an example of him to other gang bangers, let him know that he's disappointing his mother, and lead him hand in hand to an early grave when he reacts poorly to the comment about his mother.  The best part is, no matter which version of conflict resolution you choose, you're going to get experience from it.  That's right, you don't actually get much in the way of experience from fighting, but from getting your character to grow as a person.  With few mandatory responses, and even fewer characters that won't respond differently to a specific kind of treatment, Shadowrun Returns boasts a story mode that feels like sitting across the table from a game master, trying to balance social politics while desperately seeking to solve a murder mystery.  Oh yeah, by the way, that's exactly what the standard starter story is, a murder mystery.  Gone are the days of "go here, kill villain, save world" role playing games.  In Shadowrun Returns, your character growth takes on the form of solving your own characters personal problems that lead to new friendships and adversaries, while saving the world is a side effect of beating the game, not the goal of it.    Shadowrun Returns may appear to be just an update to a classic SNES game, but with the plethora of official support, and the vast multitude of free user created content, it's clear that Shadowrun video games will never need an update again.  Now if you'll excuse me, it's raining in Seattle right now, and my cyber implants aren't waterproof.  If you need me, I'll be inside playing Shadworun Returns.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												As someone going into these games with *zero* experience with the Shadowrun universe beforehand, I was pretty overwhelmed with the notion of a setting that essentially exists at the intersection of BLADE RUNNER, NEUROMANCER, and THE LORD OF THE RINGS. Where one can meet a street-wise elven bartender, turn around, and project your consciousness into cyberspace -- all done in the shadows of massive mega-corporations that happen to run most of the world. Also, there are dragons.And seeing how this game is based on a pen and paper campaign setting that has been expanding and refining itself over the course of 25 years, the depth and breadth of the universe can most definitely be felt as you walk the streets of Seattle and Berlin. This is an outstandingly versatile and exciting setting, and the two campaigns currently available to a fantastic job of exploiting it to its fullest.SHADOWRUN RETURNS: DEAD MAN'S SWITCH - (8/10 Stars)Campaign Length: Approx. 12 HoursWhen you purchase the base game, SHADOWRUN RETURNS, you'll be purchasing a campaign titled DEAD MAN'S SWITCH, which has you tracking down a murderer in Seattle after an old acquaintance of yours turns up dead. The story takes a lot of twists and turns, as getting closer to the truth seems to be hazardous for your health. Along the way, you'll run into a number of very interesting characters (albeit, sometimes for far too short a time), including a few that fans of the SNES/Genesis/Pen and Paper games will find familiar.As others have pointed out since launch, DMS is a tad linear compared to most other RPGs on the market. There will be dialogue options aplenty, allowing you to play your character the way you want, but ultimately there are few choices that make a real impact on the story, and you'll feel the invisible hand of the narrative tugging you along without much room for sidequests or exploration.Regardless, the story of DMS is *more* than worth the price of admission. The writing and attention to detail do the setting a great service and it acts as a great introduction to the Shadowrun universe.DRAGONFALL - (9/10 Stars)Campaign Length: Approx. 18 - 20 HoursThat being said, it's a shame that most people have been judging the overall package on the weaknesses of DMS, because DRAGONFALL really is the definitive Shadowrun experience so far, and more than worthy of being counted among the best RPGs to be released in recent years.This time around, you play as a citizen of the Berlin Flux-State, where anarchy reigns (or doesn't reign?) and the nation's stability waxes and wanes as gangs, corporations, and political clubs fight for controlling interest in the chaos. As a shadowrunner, your latest mission goes horribly wrong, leaving you and your team kicked to the curb with no explanation as to what just happened. As you start peeling back the layers, you uncover conspiracy after conspiracy, and find yourself getting caught up in an F-State conflict that may very well lead to disaster for Berlin.As I said, many of the "weaknesses" of DMS have been rectified this time around. The linearity is not completely gone, but it's certainly well hidden, providing plenty of sidequests with multiple ways of accomplishing each, a more permanent group of companions with rich backstories, and a greater emphasis on choice. And, like DMS, DRAGONFALL does a fantastic job of playing up its setting, and making Berlin feel suitably unique in comparison to Seattle. There is just a greater sense of effort all around, including a more engaging story on top of it all.The base game and the expansion are presented anthology-style, with individual sets of characters and stand-alone stories, so if one hold more appeal than the other, feel free to play DRAGONFALL first. (Though, you will still need to purchase the SHADOWRUN RETURNS base game.)In the last few years, we've been seeing an RPG renaissance by way of Kickstarter, and SHADOWRUN RETURNS was among the first out of the gate. Neither game is completely perfect, but there's an attention to detail and a reverence for the source material -- not to mention some fantastic writing -- that makes the game and its expansion an absolutely immersive experience. I sincerely hope we get to see more of this universe, and judging by the dramatic leap in quality between DEAD MAN'S SWITCH and DRAGONFALL, the next game will surely be something to keep a close eye on.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I'm proud to say that I contributed to this game's initial Kickstarter campaign.  It delivers a solid turn-based-tactical-RPG experience, and it paints a beautiful-if-grim-and-gritty image of the Shadowrun setting, and it tells a solid story in the process.For the uninitiated, the setting of Shadowrun is a dystopian future in which corporations rule the world and governments are beholden to the whim of these international corportations.  Magic, and all the fantastic creatures that come with it, reentered the world in the early 2000s.  And in all of this, a 'shadowrunner' is a mercenary who is hired to use their guns, magic, muscle, computer hacking, or remote-controlled drones on a job-by-job basis.One of the neat tricks that this game pulls is that different types of character literally see the world differently.  A mage can see ley lines on the ground that can bolster their magic (or that of their enemies!) if they stand on them.  A shaman can see spirits lingering in the world, ready to be called into battle.  A decker (read: hacker, who have neural interfaces in this world) can see hackable computers.  Okay, I think that anyone can see hackable computers, but you need a decker to get into them.Without revealing any spolers, I'd like to say that the story in the original game is solid.  It's nothing to write home about, but it makes for a great introduction to the setting, and fans of Shadowrun video games will see a familiar face.  The story in the expansion - which, by the way, was at least as long as the original campaign, and I've sunk 82 hours between the two of them - is, on the other hand, phenomenal.  Both games have great characters, although be warned that there's no voice-acting - if you demand that from your stories you should be aware of its absence.  The dialogue is similar to Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights - style, although if your character doesn't have the skills needed to engage in a particular line of dialogue, that line and its requirement show up, greyed out, so you know how to build your character next time.Of course, the game also comes with a level editor, and Steam Workshop support.  This was one of the big features touted during its Kickstarter.  I'm not immediately seeing a link to the editor from Steam but it's in the same folder as the game files.  I have not put this to the test but I'm told that it's a very powerful toolset.The combat system is interesting.  The greatest depth can be found in building your main character and selecting a squad for each mission as there is quite a bit of variety available in a character's skill-set.  Once you're on the ground there's still quite a few decisions to make, from where to take cover, to how tightly to pack your squad, to when and where to expend your consumable resources.  Personally, I found the game to be a smidge too easy on Normal difficulty, even when I realized that my character concept wasn't a particularly strong one in this universe.  There were two harder (and one easier) difficulties that I didn't try.Visually, the game performs solidly.  It's a nice, clean (well, grimy) - looking game, but it won't turn any heads for reasons other than the unusual setting.  The developers had other priorities, and they're priorities that I happen to agree with.Shadowrun Returns delivers a passable audio experience.  The game sounds great, all of the effects sound like I imagine they should...but there could really, really be more variety in background music.  What is there sounds wonderful, but I for one was tired of hearing the same music for every battle by the end of it.  Again, if you can't stand reading text, pass this one up, because it has no voice-overs whatsoever.All in all, I would heartily recommend this game to RPG fans, turn-based strategy fans, and Shadowrun fans alike.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												I was a big fan of the Paper & Pencil RPG since its first edition for its unique and immersive world of cyberpunk-meets-fantasy.  I just finished playing both pre-made campaigns (yes, you can also write & share your own campaigns) called "Dead Man's Switch" in the original game and "DragonFall" in the DLC update.  They fully deliver the atmosphere of the shadowrunner experience in these campaigns, and both storylines play out like good novels - I *highly* recommend playing this game, especially with the DLC update to allow mid-scenario game saves.It is generally a turn-based combat system where you have several "classes" but you are free to hybridize.  The archetypes include an offensive-spell-wielding Mage, a spirit-summoning Shaman, a computer-hacking Decker, a drone-controlling Rigger, a Chi/martial-artist Physical Adept, and of course the cyberware-laiden Street Samurai.  You also have a choice of playing a human, a dwarf, an elf, an ork or a troll - each with advantages and limitations.  Scenarios are written with multiple ways of success, but choosing a well-suited team for each mission is still critical.  I personally played a human detective-type character who was generally a Physical Adept but with a more diverse skillset, and made sure I had at least a spellcaster and Decker on my runs to cover my bases when possible.  The character generation system is not as detailed as the RPG but you will find the balance and flavor of the development makes the same kind of characters with most of the possible character concepts reconstitutable if you wanted to relive your gaming heydays.All dialog is text-based, so you only need speakers to listen to the theme music and sound effects.  I am a Linux user, and being able to play this game without a reboot was a *big* plus for me (but I still need Win 7 to make my own campaigns).  The storyline really flows, and I often found myself spending hours non-stop trying to unravel secrets and plan out a larger strategy.  Expect a game to take 50 hours or more to complete - I did Dragonfall in just under 60 hours on Easy without any redos of battles.One big drawback - this is Single Player only.  No co-op or competitive play.One word of caution - you play street-savvy shadowrunners (i.e. black-ops for hire) so it is a gritty world with lots of moral grey zones, foul language, blood-spilling violence and innuendo.  This is supposed to be a dystopian future of the mid 21st century, so be ready for some hard-luck stories and tough choices between jepardizing your pay or your conscience, with no hope of making a dent in the struggle between the urban poor and the ultra-rich puppet-master megacorps.  Also, be careful with your choices - they will impact later game play.  Fun times! :DTake a gander at the game, and review some Let's Play videos to see if you'd get into a game like this.  Personally, it was well worth the price.  Thanks for reading.(Edit: fixed some typos.)

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a decent romp through a cyberpunk world.  It does a good job of making the world seem much larger than it is at first, and personally I really liked the characters, missions and story.  Since the cyberpunk community is rather small as far as selection goes, this is a no-brainer for anyone hoping to get some good PnP-lite action in.  The stories are told well enough and with community mods, you'll have plenty to dive into if you really like it.  So for the price is isn't a bad deal.If that seems like a general compliment, it is.  The game itself is a bit too simplistic for its own good, and fails to standout beyond its initial premise and art style.  This is a game with roots in the pen and paper role-playing world making it impossible to not ask 'where is the rest of it'?  Whether your character uses throwing knives, magic spells or a shotgun the gameplay is identical.  Levelling feels arbitrary because the skills are almost identical for any 'specialty' and there seems to be little reason to really diversify your party.  It's that mentality which does the most damage.  Character customization is highly limited outside of some nice details such as cyberware that becomes visible on your character, and weapons are as bog standard as you can get and don't even seem to have unique models.It's an average budget RPG with decent replayability and a fantastic setting.  The biggest mistake here was not trying for anything better.  Instead of a unique game in a unique setting, we got one that would be right at home on your cellphone next to Candy Crush.  It isn't a bad game, which explains the recommendation, but there's too many oversights or just plain missed opportunities to stand out that keep this game from being much more than a casual enjoyment.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall is a solid, entertaining game.  I got Shadowrun Returns back at release, and the base game was frustrating, unforgiving, and bug laden.  I eventually stopped when an error prevented me from progressing on a map after over an hour of playtime.  I shelved it until now, expecting to come back once the errors were cleaned up.  Trying to pick up where I left off was fruitless, as my game was now corrupted.  I attempted to start from scratch, but Deadman's Switch wouldn't load at all after character creation.  Instead of giving up, I skipped to Dragonfall to see if it worked.  It did.  And it was amazing.  I can't say if Deadman's Switch ever got cleaned up or fixed or if it was any good, but Dragonfall made everything worth it and then some.  If you have this game, and the base story didn't grab you, get Dragonfall, because that is a slick DLC.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												The setting is new to me, so I can't comment on it, other than, you know, it's got sodding orks and elves in it, like every other vaguely fantasy setting, even if this one is cyberpunk. The combat is very new x-com-esque, and will probably scratch that itch if you're needing a tactical fix. I rather enjoyed it.Pros:- Functional story with a few twists and good writing (we're not talking Torment good, but there's nothing to cringe at)- Good range of character options with no single thing being mega OP- Deep without being overwhelming turn-based combat system which offers plenty of options- Lets you choose your team of level-appropriate mercs, freeing you from managing loads of characters skillsheetsCons:- Leaves you to read the tutorials tucked away in the menu rather than explaining the systems (possibly a plus if you're old school and find modern tutorials slow)- Decker classes are probably awesome the 2 or 3 times you need them to do their matrix thing, but have limited options in the real world, largely due to the lack of computers in most environments and effectiveness of shooting things instead- Arguably too easy if you use the options available to you: none of my characters ever came close to dying in the campaign, but this was normal mode and it's possible I'm a tactical genius and didn't notice.- A special weapon required for the final mission is intentionally short ranged and small-magazined. This is slightly annoying.- (Possibly a tiny bit on the short side for those used to epic RPGs, but there's no filler here, so I'll take no issues with it)I'm told the new campaign is even better, which sounds pretty good to me: wishlisted, as the cool kids probably don't say.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Disclaimer: I never played the old Shadowrun game. Ever. Never even heard of it.If you missed the description, Shadowrun Returns is an isometric tactical turn-based RPG. Think XCOM: Enemy Unknown's battle system simplified a bit. It's set in a cyberpunk world in which magic has resurfaced after hundreds of years. You're essentially playing detective for your dead friend in this environment, almost entirely by battling street gangs and corporate security.The graphics, for an isometric game, are spectacular. The sound, too is pretty good. The game's fun, and the battle system feels functional, though at times I was a bit frustrated by the difficulty.I have one major complaint and two minor ones.This is my one major complaint: Why is there magic? At no point in the game does it feel like the sacrifices to the integrity of the story are worth the inclusion of magic in this universe.My minor complaints are that the game is too short and linear (this is mostly rectified by Workshop content) and the Native American characters seem stereotypical, which is a bit off-putting.I recommend Shadowrun Returns, but with the caveats that it's under $15 and you go in knowing you'll have to play workshop content to get your money's worth.

												I've always been a huge fan of Shadowrun, and as such played most of the videogames based on it (except that FPS for the 360, and no tears were shed). So when I heard of a new game (actually a series of new games) being developed, yeah, I was REALLY EXCITED. And it kinda turned out to be just that, with many features missing from the final game that were promised to be included.That being said, what came out of it is definitly worth playing and a worthy game in the Shadowrun line of games.At the time of this review there were two official campaigns, Dead Man Switch and Dragonfall, the second being sold as an expansion. Don't play Dragonfall until you play Dead Man Switch. Not because the stories are connected (they aren't really) but rather because Dragonfall's story is even better than Dead Man Switch (which was already excellent) and the gameplay is much less linear and improved.Plus, theres lots of fan made campaigns and more coming out over time.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is pretty faithful to the table top role playing game. The language and the atmosphere is spot on.The Deadman's Swicth campaign is an interesting and deep story which I found absorbing.I enjoy turn based combat so this just felt right for me. The upgrading of skills is of a depth and variety that can appeal to all types of RPG players. I rolled with a human "Face". High on inteligence and charisma. Which meant I didn't have to fight in every situation, I could at times use diplomacy or just blag my way through some scenarios. Which incidently is very much how I play the table top version.For me this was a top experience and for was a 92% game. Obviously deduct some from the score if you do not like turn based combat, rich stories or have no interest in the SHadowrun Universe. But if you love all these things then it is a must buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												A very linear but very fun RPG, The game consists of three main components Combat, exploration, and conversations Combat consists of a very basic turned based strategy, it isn’t the most unique system but it carries the game well enough through its roughly 11 hour playtime.Moving around the world is perhaps the most disappointing part of the game; you have little to no interaction with the environment beyond clicking yellow objective prompts, there’s also very little exploration beyond a few slightly more expansive environments for the most part the game consists of linear corridors, although admittedly very nice looking corridors Dialogue options are varied but ultimately lead to the same conclusions, they exist more to allow you to develop your characters personality and role within the shadowrun universe. Dialogue for the most part is well written. A bulk of the game comes from lengthy NPC exposition; most of the characters aren’t very memorable but the overall murder mystery has enough turns to keep it interesting until the conclusion Even with its faults it’s still a surprisingly fun game that quickly eats away at your time, if you can overlook the faults and just enjoy the cyberpunk charm that I’d fully recommend the game and its standalone expansion “Dragonfall”

But if you are expecting mass effect level production value, look for EA or Bioware. They got nice looking shells, true, but they lost their essence on the way.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												If you enjoy tactical turn based combat and compelling storylines this game is for you.Pros:-Great writing-Fun turn based tactical combat-Greater than average ability to feel like your character's skills and the choices for specialization matter-Unique setting that if you're not familiar with may definetly be worth losing 30-40 hours in-Great RPG giving a mix of storytelling and classic character building-Player generated content that adds replayabilityCons:-Lots of writing (do not play if reading text makes you bored)-No multiplayer (I sincerely hope they add in co-op multiplayer in future DLC, but I understand why it is not currently a part of the game as they have focused on creating an immersive single player environment with compelling companions, but as anyone who has played tabletop RPG's in the past knows, a large part of the fun of these games is being able to run around with your friends attempting to complete the various tasks of a shadowrunner)Other Points of Interest:-I strongly recommend not playing Dragonfall until you have completed Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign) Not only is dead man's switch a better intro to the universe + mechanics, but after playing Dragonfall you will not want to go through Dead man's switch because it will feel like a tracked, clunky version of Dragonfall-If you're not really sure if you're interested in the gameplay go look up the Shadowrun Universe, because a large part of what makes this game great is how well they portrayed it, and if off the bat you don't like things like the idea of decking, the implementation of magic, or the way that orks, trolls, elves, and dwarves came into existence, chances are that you will continue to be annoyed by whatever annoyed you in a text based RPG.

												I highly reccomend picking this DLC up if you are a fan of deep storytelling and fun turn based combat.A few pros and cons:Pros:-Fun turn based combat-Great storyline with a sense of player agency-Party member are interesting with good backgrounds (you actually care about them)-Music is excellent, I especially love how they saved a unique piece for the last battle-The artwork is well done and set apart from the original campaign-Great use of non-combat skills and stats in conversationsCons:-No control over party equipment and progression-Environments needs a bit more animation and life-Some inconsistencies in party skill use in dialogueAll in all a huge step above the original campaign, any newcomers should play this first. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												I gotta say, I was pretty disappointed with Shadowrun Returns when it arrived last year. BUT. Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall completely turned me around. I had backed the Kickstarter so I received both and on a lark decided to give Dragonfall a try when it showed up in my library.I played on very hard because one of my complaints was that the Dead Man's Switch campaign was far too easy. Very hard is what I would recommend for anyone who enjoys tactical rpgs, otherwise the difficulty isn't there.This time around the game has a hub system, and a save anywhere system. Both were desperately needed. The writing is just good. The characters remind me of old-school Bioware characters. Personalities you get quite attached to.Its not super deep. But its deeper than you expect. On very hard it took me about 20 hours. My only real gripe is not being able to equip items or gear on your other runners. I still don't quite get that but it's not a deal-breaker. You get over it.If you're looking for a fun summer game. You like tactical rpgs, you like Shadowun, don't pass it up. My final advice is play Dragonfall first. I didn't finish Dead Man's Switch initially but liked Dragonfall enough to go back and squeeze some fun out of it. The two are COMPLETELY unrelated so it doesn't matter which order you play them in.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												Yeah, this is definitely a game you are going to want to play. There was some debate as to what style of game this is amongst my gaming peers. This was resolved in my opinion by describing this as a fairly perfect video game emulation of the table top gaming experience. It has elements in common with games like XCOM:EU, Dragon Age, Baldurs Gate, and plenty of other aweome games. However, it really stands alone by virute of its comletely intuitive gameplay, deep and yet simple customization system by way of karma points, and a pretty gripping story. The graphics are cool looking for a top town style game, and do a great job of depicting the world in whuich Shadowrun resides. There are plenty of conversation options, and a touch of morality decsion making, but for the most part, all choices lead to the same place. Overall, I felt this to be a completely engaging game, so much so that the 21 hours or so I put into it only really felt like 8 or 9 hours. I look forward to future expansions and such and am keen to try out the user generated content.Pretty much the perfect game for the subject matter and genre.Enjoy!!!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is fun, has great writing, and is a good match for any classic CRPG fan. If you liked Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, or any other similar game, you'll probably like this.That being said, don't expect too much from this game. When compared to the classics, Shadowrun Returns isn't just short - it's light. VERY light. Expect to solve puzzles quickly and easily. Choosing gear doesn't involve much more than buying the most expensive gun. Combat is actually quite dull. Speccing out your character is kind of fun, but I was left wishing I had more options. It's a surprisingly simple game overall.I played as a Decker, which was great for the story but left me relying on the tried-and-true (and boring) combat tactic known as "shoot things with guns a lot." Mages seem a bit more interesting, since placement in battles was somewhat more important, but since you can't use hired Deckers to interact with objects outside of combat you're somewhat hamstringed if you go with a non-Decker class. Each area could have definitely used a LOT more alternative solutions.I've only played the basic campaign so far, and I will probably pick up the DLC, but the fact is that most of these problems are with mechanics and game design, not with the campaign itself. Still, the writing is good - really good. Combined with the rich built-in lore, it makes an otherwise mediocore game a fun experience worth your time and money.
