Posted: October 5, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a fairly short experience, but well worth it. The "Dead Man's Switch" campaign that the game comes with really feels like a Shadowrun tabletop RPG campaign, and is well written. On top of that, the game comes with the tools to make user generated content - something which a lot of people have already taken advantage of - and you can therefore find a wealth of player-made campaigns as well, giving this game more longevity than just the campaign it ships with. If you're a fan of cyberpunk and roleplaying games, this is one to get!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												I was a big fan of the Paper & Pencil RPG since its first edition for its unique and immersive world of cyberpunk-meets-fantasy.  I just finished playing both pre-made campaigns (yes, you can also write & share your own campaigns) called "Dead Man's Switch" in the original game and "DragonFall" in the DLC update.  They fully deliver the atmosphere of the shadowrunner experience in these campaigns, and both storylines play out like good novels - I *highly* recommend playing this game, especially with the DLC update to allow mid-scenario game saves.It is generally a turn-based combat system where you have several "classes" but you are free to hybridize.  The archetypes include an offensive-spell-wielding Mage, a spirit-summoning Shaman, a computer-hacking Decker, a drone-controlling Rigger, a Chi/martial-artist Physical Adept, and of course the cyberware-laiden Street Samurai.  You also have a choice of playing a human, a dwarf, an elf, an ork or a troll - each with advantages and limitations.  Scenarios are written with multiple ways of success, but choosing a well-suited team for each mission is still critical.  I personally played a human detective-type character who was generally a Physical Adept but with a more diverse skillset, and made sure I had at least a spellcaster and Decker on my runs to cover my bases when possible.  The character generation system is not as detailed as the RPG but you will find the balance and flavor of the development makes the same kind of characters with most of the possible character concepts reconstitutable if you wanted to relive your gaming heydays.All dialog is text-based, so you only need speakers to listen to the theme music and sound effects.  I am a Linux user, and being able to play this game without a reboot was a *big* plus for me (but I still need Win 7 to make my own campaigns).  The storyline really flows, and I often found myself spending hours non-stop trying to unravel secrets and plan out a larger strategy.  Expect a game to take 50 hours or more to complete - I did Dragonfall in just under 60 hours on Easy without any redos of battles.One big drawback - this is Single Player only.  No co-op or competitive play.One word of caution - you play street-savvy shadowrunners (i.e. black-ops for hire) so it is a gritty world with lots of moral grey zones, foul language, blood-spilling violence and innuendo.  This is supposed to be a dystopian future of the mid 21st century, so be ready for some hard-luck stories and tough choices between jepardizing your pay or your conscience, with no hope of making a dent in the struggle between the urban poor and the ultra-rich puppet-master megacorps.  Also, be careful with your choices - they will impact later game play.  Fun times! :DTake a gander at the game, and review some Let's Play videos to see if you'd get into a game like this.  Personally, it was well worth the price.  Thanks for reading.(Edit: fixed some typos.)

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Shadowrun is good. Making a kitchensink setting isn't always easy (after all, this is magic AND cyberpunk) and making Shadowrun games is even harder. But this is good. I liked the first campaign a little more than Dragonfall, but that might be a side effect of some technical issues (and some incredibly bad luck at dice rolling). The main issue I have with the game is visuals. While the character portraits are supremely good and backgrounds look good more often than not, combat leaves a lot to be desired. While the character models are good enough, especially when viewed from so far away, the combat animations are lacklustre. And the greatest shame is how spells bland and impactless the spells look. Other thant that, it's a very good RPG that should not be missed.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												There are some VERY heavy caveats going into this overall positive review.Shadowrun started as a pen & paper RPG in the 80s that set a lot of the trends for the cyberpunk genre. You have a future sci-fi world where cybernetics, magic, computer hacking, and fantasy races all exist side by side. No one has really attempted a Shadowrun video game since the Super Nintendo and Genesis versions over 20 years ago. The classic Shadowrun missionn usually consisted of your team raiding a mega corporation building to get somethig valuable. You broke into the building, fought your way through security, covered your decker (hacker) as he broke into the computer to steal valuable data, then made a getaway. The Genesis version did this particularly well with random generated missions and a separate, detailed combat system for hacking.Enter Shadowrun Returns. On its own, it's a solid RPG. It would best be describe as a linear version of the old Fallout games meets the combat system from X-COM Enemy Unknown. The writing is also very good and is probably close to being up there with stuff like Deus Ex. If that alone is good enough for you, then go for it and get this. $20 might be a bit too much though and you might want to wait for a sale.Now, the negatives.Linear: There is no open mission system. You get ONE very short optional mission the entire game. There is only one classic "corp raid" mission in the entire game.Hacking: Has always been a huge part of the Shadowrun universe. The Genesis version did a great job with it. In Shadowrun Returns, it is useless and poorly implemented. There are only 3 points in the whole game where you need a decker (hacker), and the game will tell you in advance as well as provide you with one for free. Aside from that, there are only 2 optional decking areas in the whole game that will only open up a single room for measly rewards that won't add up to even a fraction of the money and experience you put into the decking skills to get them. It's a total waste to invest in any decking skills for your main character or spend money hiring deckers. Worse, the hacking portions are just an exact copy of the regular combat only with a virtual reality reskin. It's disappointing because all they had to do was copy the Genesis version hacking system and it would have been great.Guns guns guns: Shadowrun has always been about a huge range of combat choices. Guns, remote control drones, melee weapons, martial arts, and 3 different branches of magic. In this game, guns are vastly superior to any other combat path that it's not worth bothering with anything else. And out of the different gun types, only shotguns and rifles are worth it. The combat systme is similar to X-COM but it literally becomes X-COM when all you use is rifles and shotguns. 90% of the combat options and a huge part of Shadowrun are uselss here. Deal 22 damage at range with a gun, or use magic to lay down traps the enemy has to walk over for 12 damage? 22 damage with a single gunshot, or spend your whole turn summoning a spirit that does less damage and might break free to attack you? Spend action points casting spells to inflict minor status effects, or spend the same amount of action points flat out killing an enemy with guns? They're all no brainer choices and the choice is always "guns".Hit percentage: The game will tell you your percentage chance to hit each target. That number is always always B.S.  You're going to constantly be missing 4 times in a row on attacks that had a greater than 70% chance to hit (5 misses at 85% was my record), while anything under 50% is a guaranteed miss. It's way too consistent to chalk up to bad luck. There has to be some hidden factor that the game never tells you and it makes weighing tactical options a pain.Useless conversation skills: You can put points into charisma which earns you conversation skills in certain areas like "security", "gang", "socialite", and so on. Getting even half of the areas requires a huge experience investment in charisma, and each conversation skill only comes up a grand total of ONCE the whole game. Some let you get past a plot obstacle, but it's unnecessary because the alternate solution will be sitting literally right next to the obstacle. The other conversation areas will get you maybe an extra 200-400 bucks the whole game. That's it.Tight money: Money is ridiculous tight in the game. You get around a total of $14k over the first 6 hours of the game. Spells cost 200-1200 each. Grenades and medkits run up to 500 each. Hiring party members is 1000-3000 each PER MISSION. Armor is 2000-4000. Cybernetic implants will run you up to 5000 each for very minor bonuses. This just further cements guns as your only combat option because they're by far the best money value when just $2000 will set you up with best guns to breeze your way to victory. You can't grind for more money; 80% of all the money you get will be handed out at pre-determined stages of the plot and the other 20% isn't worth investing in the skills needed to get the extra. In the final quarter of the game, it finally gives you enough money to buy stuff, but at the same time it gives you the best stuff for free, meaning it makes money pointless at the same time it gives you enough to do anything.The final note about this game is that while it's still a decent linear Fallout experience on its own, every single thing it does is done much, much better in Shadorun Dragonfall to the point where I'd say you should just skip it and go straight to Dragonfall. I still give this game a positive recommendation since it's not bad, but it's pretty much made obsolete by the Dragonfall sequel.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns offers a single pre-loaded story called Dead Man's Switch as well as the tools to produce your own stories and content or play others' creations. Focusing on just Dead Man's Switch as that's all I've done so far you will find a fairly interesting story of about 10 hours worth of gameplay (on the normal difficulty) with a small set of jobs that are exceptionally linear. It feels more like an introduction to the systems and setting of Shadowrun than a full fledged game, but it's very fun nonetheless! The music is very appropriate to the environments, and the character dialogue is entertaining to read. The combat and progression systems are easy to pick up so it doesn't take long to get right into the game, and because of the many ways in which you can improve your character for both combat and non-combat roles replayability seems high. I'd definitely recommend picking this game up!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												This is a pretty fun 12 hours, they did a good job getting the current version of the old pen and paper game in there. There's no classes, so early on the best thing is to have a gun skill, a magic skill and some cyber skill because the game equips you before the second fight based onm what skills you start with. On your first playthrough, make sure you examine the whole interface for you and each character in your team, a lot of skills give special abilities you won't know about if you don't dig a little to find them (different attacks with their favorite weapon, different magic spells). The dev kit and Steam Workshop for this game already seem really promising, too.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												The good:+ The world is interesting, and looks great. Has this kind of style that feels gritty, dark, and unique.+ You can really seem to play whatever kind of character you want (at least on normal).+ Combat on normal is not hard, but just hard enough that you might die randomly. I feel like it’s a good mix for just a casual gamer.+ Not too long. No unnecessary grinding. To the point. Play through took like 12 hours or so.The story:- The story isn’t anything special. There are some nice twists, but parts feel sort of disjointed like there was bigger ideas that just never quite made it in to the game.- The game does not always do a good job explaining some of the mechanics but really if you are playing on easy or normal you’ll pick it up relatively quickly and many of the mechanics are present in future games.- I feel like even scaled up the text is generally smaller than I would like.- Ssome wonky interface stuff. For example healing other team members in between combat.TLDR;An interesting 2d isometric cypberpunk rpg. Not the greatest RPG I have played, and certainly not the worst. I don’t have very strong feelings on the game, others in the series are better, but this one is OK and probably worth a play.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												An accessable, isometric cyberpunk RPG? It would be a crime to *not* like it. It's generally well-written and thought-provoking, there's quite a bit of variety in character-building and the combat is challenging and varied without being overwhelming.It's all over quickly - less than 10 hours - but not every RPG has to be a 50+ hour epic. It's nice to have a focused storyline, a clear objective and to not have to sort through endless loot for a change. There's at least a degree of replayability through vastly different character builds and some choices, so the game should be good value for money.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												First of all, I'm not a long-time fan; My first contact with the Shadowrun franchise was with this game. Though of course you miss out on stuff if you're not familiar with the lore, it's easy enough to catch on. Cleared Dead Man's Switch and Dragonfall. Ten hours for the former, twenty for the latter. Combat is a turn-based tactical thing that would be best described as a slightly more streamlined but also dumbed-down version of XCOM's battle system. It's okay.DMS is pretty linear and has a relatively barebones story, but gives room for roleplaying. I played a decker, however, and it's really unfortunate that decker skills are pretty much useless in it.Dragonfall is much better, with more options to end each quest, well-written characters with their own backstories who stick with you throughout the game (this might not sound like much, but it's what DMS was sorely lacking), and chances for all character classes to shine (my decker/rigger actually did awesome stuff!.I VERY highly recommend this.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Definitely a sleeper.  In a world of gaming flash and pomp, and very little meat, Shadowrun is a refreshing throwback.  There's no voice acting here, nor is there any movie quality cutscene, not even at intro or outro.  What Shadowrun is is a turn based RPG that ranks up against the best of the classics (D&D Gold Box, for example).  The campaigns are a little short, but well worth the investment in time, money, and effort to play through.  Fair warning, the graphics are lush and pretty much competitive, but the dated audio (including lacking voice talent), inability to rotate the camera, and other qualities make the whole game feel very dated.  A great dated game, mind you, but dated nonetheless.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2013
												The top-down Kickstarter-funded RPGs are starting to come out of development, and if this is any indication, it's gonna be ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. This particular game captures the feeling of the old console games and it plays like XCOM: Enemy Unknown (which I'm not about to give it♥♥♥♥♥♥for, XCOM did many things right when it came to turn based combat.). The included campaign, Dead Man's Switch, is a solid module but has issues with its constant gunplay and slightly bruised writing. And there's also a mission editor and the ability to plug different mechanics in with different user-written modules. It's a good game now, and if the modding community gives it a lot of love, it's going to be a fantastic game later on.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Shadowrun Returns had the potential of being a great game, however, they fell painfully short. First off, the game is incredibly linear. Make sure you complete EVERY task as you come across it because you can't go back to do it later. Second, there is no save feature other than a waypoint system that autosaves the game when completing quests and changing areas. So if you need to step away from the game you either let it sit open until you come back, or you lose playtime when the game reploads your last autosave. Third, the game was on the short side. I was able to complete the entire game in about 12 hours.Now on to the good stuff...I really like the skill based system that lets you pick and choose what you want to do with your character. There really needs to be more games with this function. The game also had some interesting characters (I especially liked Dresdan). I like that NPC attitudes changed based on how you responded, and that your skills actually swayed them one way or another. I would recommend the game to others, but to be honest, I'd wait for it to go on sale first. $20 for a 12 hour extremely linear game is a bit on the steep side in my opinion.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												3/5 Not everyone can enjoy a game and sadly I was not blessed with an interest in this game.The storyline was oh so bland. I started this game years ago (and decided to resume and finish it today) but I can still recall how easy you walked into the story, witnessing everyone play their scripts and all you had to do was blow them away or allow them to live for one reason or another.I tried to like my character and his pursuit to help a friend ------ Not that this game catered to the user's ability to customize the personality of the character he made, but I don't quite enjoy playing a game that gives you limited options for responding to encounters. You act as some sort of mercenary so you're supposed to be rough around the edges, but it seems every conversation just reeks of one writer half-assing all your responses. Let alone the cheesy NPCs that don't know who the hell you are and should smoke your♥♥♥♥♥where you stand, but instead they want to give you a chance because hell, the society that works in the "shadows" has nothing but secrets  and tours to give about their secret organization.Lore/Environment was lost on me as well ----- This game is lovely that it tries to make a new fantasy world away from the redundant DnD aspects of Baldurs Gate and Icewind Dale (two of which I adore), but for a newcomer it was just too much to process, not that it was well explained why the things around me existed anyway.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2013
												This game will appeal to a particular gamer. Remember the old SNES version of Shadowrun? If you liked that game, you will love this. It plays in mostly the same way, with mostly the same watered-down rules to the classic pen-n-paper roleplaying game of the same name.On the plus side, the game embodies the essence of what Shadowrun is: cyberpunk meets magic. There are plenty of "class" features to play as and the runs themselves are entertaining. The combat is fun and takes a marginal amount of tactical skill. There is an editor built into the game, so if you're handy with such things, you too can create your own games. And there are some characters from the old game as well as Shadowrun lore that make an appearance. The game also necessitates that you hire shadowrunners yourself to complete jobs, thus creating a team party. This is fun.On the negative side, there is only an auto-save feature after you complete a run. So if you're in the middle of an hour+ jaunt and you gotta leave for work - guess what - either leave the game running or start over. The game also ignores some of the major mechanics of the pen-n-paper game such as essence and magic. Cyberware (machine augmentation in a character's body) lowers essence in the old game. Low essence means that one's magic rating starts reducing as well. Put in too much cyber and you'll eventually be such a weak mage that you can't light a candle with a fireball spell. In Shadowrun Returns, you can do both with only a spell cooldown modifier. The mixed side is that the game is rather short and has a fairly linear story. A good story, but it's pretty straight to the point. I wanted more when I was done. This is a good compliment in reference to how fun the game is to play. It's a negative though in the sense that there isn't more. But for $20 (or $18 that I got it for on sale), the game ended up costing me $1/hour to play from start to finish. Of course I can download user-generated content or make my own if I so wish, so at least there's that.Ultimately though, if you liked the old SNES version, this will be a nostalgic blast from the past. If you're a fan of the pen-n-paper game, this might annoy you, but overall it encompasses the feel of the original game.. so, give it a shot. You'll probably like it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												 This new release is is more lot more complicated and move involved than the Sega Genesis game I played a long time ago but I do miss the ability to just visit the streets and grind out a level or two against whatever baddies I find out there.  I don't think I've found any treasure other than keys on dead opponents so plan on buying everything you need because other than a couple grenades, healing items or a boost of some sort you'll be shelling out for all those fine items you want. There's a certain linearity to this version that might not be noticeable if you have never played the Sega Genesis version but maybe I'm still complaining about not being able to walk the streets whenever I want to. Yeah, that's probably it. The story so far is pretty cool and they do wait for you should you pick up a side quest BUT, don't skip any 'likely fights' you see while on the streets because chances are good you won't get back to them or at least I haven't yet. I'd recommend this game. It's a 75+ out of 100.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns marks a return to the Shadowrun universe in video game form after a really long hiatus. And it is indeed a brilliant return. The gameplay itself isn't much to shout about. If you've played games like XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you'd already figure it out although XCOM's gameplay was still more refined than the one in Shadowrun Returns. This, being a Kickstarter-funded game, there's no voice-acting, just text-based dialogue. Text-based, but very well-written. In fact, the story is the game's strongest point. A cyberpunk conspiracy with all sorts of twists and turns while also showing off the different types of creatures or people who populate the world. As of now, the main game's price has been reduced a few dollars, so I see no reason why you shouldn't purchase it. Don't expect a revolution in gameplay and you'll definitely enjoy this game as it is.EDIT: I already played Dragonfall and I agree with the majority of players, it is better than the base game. So a purchase of the Director's Cut is a definite must.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Shadowrun does some awesome storytelling as if you're sitting with friends around the table and listen to the GameMaster telling the story. This feature really shows that some of the original FASA people are involved and I really like it as old-school RPG lover....old-school RPG-lover... But yet I've never really gotten into Shadowrun :( And when playing this RPG I'm sad that I never did. Damn, the setting just rocks and the game mechanics are pretty neat.About the computer game itself... Graphics aren't that great though, but the way the story is presented and told makes up a lot! It feels more like the old 80s text-adventures with painted surroundings and animations, like the early BioWare adventures (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and such).Music is also a so-so for me. There's not too much, the effects are simple, but it all fits just fine in the whole Shadowrun setting.A very good point I found at start is the editor and the amount of adventures (runs) already available for this RPG. When you're done with the actual story (and the upcoming DLC soon), there's tons of other adventures to choose from.I'd say, if you're an old-school RPG lover - BUY THIS ONE!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												It's a tricky endeavor to build a game mainly on story and narrative - but Shadowrun Returns handles this with success. Shadowrun is a lore-rich cyberpunk/fantasy mashup universe which has been explored since the 90s. There are more than 40 novels in English, 5 video games and countless table-top campaigns. There is also an MMO being developed. Having it's back on this lore, this game offers a very compelling story, rich characters and and immersive game play. One downside, however, is the linearity. Even though character and class variations are well balanced and of satisfactory variety, the playthrough is linear. This wouldn't necessarily be a downside if this game was an action/adventure game; but over the years we've come expect at least some sort of openworld gameplay. I hear, however, the upcoming expansion will be addressing this.The additional plus for this game is its workshop. You can download user made content (which exist, and are pretty good) from new classes to new campaigns. Go ahead chummer, you'll like this one. Wiz.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												Lays down the foundation for a really good game... and then leaves you wanting.Can't say I had a bad time. I have really enjoyed my whole 10~15 hours of Shadowrun.The art and music are good and true to the cyberpunk universe. The fighting is simple yet quite tactical and enjoyable, and while you will miss your 93% hit chance suspiciously too often, it's not too frustrating (definitely not as much as X-com) even in hard mode. The storyline is the big star of the show, with a rivetting plot that you cannot miss or forget, simply because there is only one straight line throughout the game.This is possibly the most linear RPG I've ever played, so if you are looking for open world or side quests, stay away from this. There is literally just one side quest in the entire game, and it doesn't seem to change anything.There is however a lot of freedom on how to spec your character and its class, but this is also where it builds up excitement to leave you wanting at the end. There are so many options to choose from, which seemingly open many doors... most of which never become of use. If you want an example, you get rewarded a whopping 15 skill points after defeating the last boss, after which..... credit roll !All of this feels like a prologue to something greater, like the devs just lay the bare foundations of the game and then vanished hoping the community would build up on it....and they have! The game has an editor and there are lots of community levels to choose from, finally offering you a way to use those interesting mechanics  which were underexploited in the main campaign, like the matrix hacking.Whether you call it a cheeky dev serving you a teaser, a greedy dev letting the community do the work, or a wishful dev trying to unleash the public's imagination in true table top RPG fashion, the end result is still, a very well rounded game which will keep you entertained without overstaying its welcome.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2013
												Откладывал прохождение этой игоры как только смог, знал, что веселье будет коротким, а новых модулей от сообщества ещё толком нет, от разработчиков только в октябре, но не смог больше тянуть - сел и взахлеб прошел последнюю битву. Чувство детской радости и настоящего разочарования вперемешку, хотя на этом можно и закончить короткую заметку, но все же.Когда проект увидел на кикстартере, начал активно ждать - в арты сразу же влюбился, сеттинг был знаком по игре на сеге, врать не буду, ничего тогда не понимал, просто бегал и исследовал локации. Появился предзаказ в стиме, сразу захотелось приобрести, но, учитывая прошлые разочарования, решил сначала таки ознакомиться с геймплейными видео и прочими штуками из интернетов. Вот тогда и случился приступ ярости - восьми-десяти часовая флешка, без какой-либо реиграбельности, абсолютно линейная с боями без челленджа.После долгих и мучительных сомнений все же приобрел. Начал исследовать ролевую систему - проста, изящна и гибка, освоить её можно просто поглядев на древо умений, ничего сложного нет. Сама игра дерзко устраивает покатушки по киберпанк-рельсам, свернуть никуда не удастся - как выяснилось, не только из-за лени разработчиков сделать что-то огромное и массивное, сам движок и его особенности не позволяют. Пока что. Бои в самом начале никакущие - можно лениво тыкать на все подряд, осваивая механику (так сильно похожую на последний xcom), в самом конце хочется размахивать руками и громко ругаться, внезапные перемены сложности выбивают из колеи.К слову, в концовочке и последних эпизодах самый смак.Но веселье, как я выше писал, было недолгим. Нуар закончен, дело об убийстве бывшего коллеги раскрыто, у каждого персонажа своя концовочка (ах, какие персонажи!) и вот собственно все, печальные титры идут безмерно долго, мельтеша записями никнеймов всех бейкеров.Ждем-с октября! Думаю кампания в Берлине будет куда более массивной.Как итог: если фанат изометрического олдскула - можно взять, понастальгировать. Не стоит расчитывать на глубокость арканума, скорее фаллаут тактикс в киберпанке. Только короткий. Очень короткий.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												I liked what I was able to play of this game, but considering I keep hitting a bug that won't let me continue with the campaign, I think it's fair to say that I wouldn't recommend buying this game. If you got it for free, sure - just know that this bug may turn your game into an extended demo. I can put up with the UI that will only respond to 1/3 of your clicks, but I can't get past a game that won't let you play it (or even close it) once you've hit the bug.The developers have known about this bug for years, but still haven't fixed it. I don't think it's going to be fixed anytime soon. Makes me glad I didn't waste my money on their new Kickstarter.A quick edit: Oh, and I almost forgot: the save system is useless - when you want to save the game, you can't, and relying on the checkpoint save system is useless, as it doesn't save after key moments (completing objectives, etc).

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												TL;DR version:+Awesome and immersive setting with an engaging story and characters+Nice artstyle and visual design+Big variety in classes, races, weapons and combat styles+Don't have to make a certain class to experience playing as that class+Fun and traditional turn-based combat, with a lot of possible combinations of classes in your party+A lot of good dialogue which can be affected by your character's skills and etiquette-Linear and short-Too little gear upgrades and loot-Fairly easy overall-A lot of dialogue, should you not like reading a lotFull version:Shadowrun is a Cyberpunk strategy RPG game, with a very interesting setting, and a crazy but engaging plot. I like the artstyle, and it feels just right for this setting. The areas you visit look good and are designed nicely. It features turn-based combat, with an AP system which determines how many things you can do in a single turn. It also features a cover and line of sight mechanic, and the longer the distance between you and the enemy, the lower your accuracy.The game also has a very big variety when it comes to classes to play as and combat styles or weapons to use. This might be my favorite aspect of the game, just because it gives you so much freedom and so many options in creating your character. It's a shame the game turned out to be very linear aside from some side jobs and your character skills influencing specific parts of missions. But since you can upgrade every stat as you want, and hire characters to join your party, you don't have to play through the game again to experience all of the different combat styles and class skills. I would really have liked to see an actual loot system in this though. There are only a few different weapons and about two or three armours in each category, which felt like too little. There are some more spells, but that's because there are better versions of the same spell. It would have made it a lot more fun to me if there were more gear upgrades altogether, or it could have featured a Diablo-like loot system to make it even deeper and more varied.There is a LOT of dialogue in this game, which can be a good or bad thing depending on how much you enjoy reading. But if you do enjoy reading, then you'll like the dialogue too. It's pretty well written and it makes this setting feel even more engaging and immersive, but it does have typos here and there. Having certain skills at certain levels or having certain etiquettes and also influence how a conversation goes. For example, you might be able to encourage a guard to let you in, or tell him something to distract him, or just intimidate him or knock him out. I personally liked the dialogue, since I also liked the plot and the characters, so I wanted all the background information I could get about this world and the characters I met. But I will say that there should have been some more actual gameplay relative to the amount of dialogue there is.Overall, this game was a great experience and I loved it. I recommend this game to both casuals and veterans when it comes to RPG games. Actually, I might recommend it the most to the more casual RPG players, since the game is short and pretty easy overall, unless you play on the harder difficulties. This low-ish difficulty makes it easy for inexperienced people to get into the game, but will probably leave the more experienced to not feel truly fulfilled with this experience. The story, character building and good - albeit linear - gameplay which belong in an RPG are all there, but it does lack the difficulty and length you would want or expect from a game like this.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												The first hour or two of play really drew me into the Shadowrun world I remember from playing the tabletop RPG. The mood, the story, the visuals, the combat. I really loved the interpretation of decking into the Matrix. If you enjoyed the RPG then this is a great trip down memory lane.But I don't think I'll finish playing the game through. The scripted dialog is moody and the storyline is interesting, but every dialog choice feels like it leads to the same conclusion. The combat feels arbitrary and doesn't seem to have the nuance of other turn-by-turns I've played like xcom.7/10.

												A slight disappointment wrapped in a satisfying outer shell. It's not open world and it might not even be an RPG, depending on how you define the genre, but the tactical combat and wonderful writing both combine with the Shadowrun setting to form a game that makes me ever so happy anyway. The editor is well done and should lead to brilliant fan campaigns as well. Worth the money, just don't expect Baldur's Gate 2.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I haven't played the pen and paper Shadowrun, but I've played various other P&P RPGs. Shadowrun scratches that same itch. The story is on par with some of the best campaigns I've played with my friends and my noir pistol-wielding ex-cop-turned-detective is one of my most memorable RPG characters now. If the production values were higher, I'm sure we'd see NPCs on par (or better) than in even Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines.If you're busy with work, studying and generally real-life, Shadowrun Returns gives you a quality roleplay experience wrapped in a 12-hour package.
